Goals: Improve Flexibility & Mobility, Improve Posture and Balance
Contraindications: Acute wrist injury, recent abdominal surgery
Steps to Perform: 1. Start on hands and knees (tabletop), hands under shoulders, knees under hips. 2. Exhale: Round spine toward ceiling (Cat), drawing naval in. 3. Inhale: Arch spine, dropping belly toward floor, lifting head (Cow). 4. Move slowly between the two, matching movement to breath.
Safety Cue: Move slowly and gently, especially if low back is tight. Avoid forcing the arch or round.

Goals: Improve Posture and Balance, Rehabilitation & Injury prevention
Contraindications: Acute knee/ankle sprain, severe vertigo
Steps to Perform: 1. Stand tall next to a stable support. 2. Shift weight to one foot and slowly lift the other foot a few inches off the floor. 3. Hold balance for the prescribed duration, then switch legs.
Safety Cue: Keep a support nearby and use it as needed. Focus eyes on a non-moving spot in front of you.

Goals: Increase overall strength, Improve Posture and Balance
Contraindications: Acute knee/hip pain, recent back surgery
Steps to Perform: 1. Hold weight vertically at chest height, feet slightly wider than shoulder-width. 2. Push hips back and descend into a deep squat, keeping chest lifted and core braced. 3. Drive through heels to stand, squeezing glutes at the top.
Safety Cue: Keep heels flat and ensure your chest stays lifted throughout the movement; don't let the back round.

Goals: Increase overall strength, Improve Posture and Balance
Contraindications: Acute shoulder pain, wrist injury
Steps to Perform: 1. Place hands on an elevated surface (bench/wall), slightly wider than shoulders. 2. Keep body in a straight line (plank position). 3. Lower chest toward the surface by bending elbows. 4. Push back up to the starting position.
Safety Cue: Maintain a straight line from head to heels. Avoid letting the hips sag or rise.

Goals: Improve cardiovascular fitness
Contraindications: Acute knee/ankle injury, unmanaged high blood pressure
Steps to Perform: 1. Stand tall, core engaged. 2. Alternately lift your knees toward your chest at a brisk, controlled pace. 3. Use a strong, rhythmic arm pump for momentum.
Safety Cue: Land softly on the balls of your feet, then quickly drop the heel. Control the movement; no jumping.

Goals: Rehabilitation & Injury prevention, Improve Posture and Balance
Contraindications: Acute back flare-up, wrist sensitivity (use fists)
Steps to Perform: 1. Start on hands and knees (tabletop). 2. Brace core, then slowly extend one arm forward and the opposite leg straight back. 3. Maintain a level pelvis (don't let hips rotate). 4. Slowly return and alternate sides.
Safety Cue: Focus on keeping the core stable and back flat, like balancing a cup of tea on your lower back.

Goals: Improve Posture and Balance, Increase overall strength
Contraindications: Acute shoulder instability, inflamed elbow joint
Steps to Perform: 1. Sit with legs extended, loop band around feet, holding ends with hands. 2. Sit tall, keep back straight, and pull elbows straight back, squeezing shoulder blades together. 3. Slowly return hands forward, maintaining tension in the band.
Safety Cue: Avoid shrugging shoulders up toward ears. Keep your chest open and tall.

Goals: Improve Posture and Balance, Reduce Stress
Contraindications: Severe dizziness/vertigo
Steps to Perform: 1. Stand tall with feet grounded, spine long, and shoulders relaxed down. 2.Engage thighs gently, keep knees soft, and balance weight evenly., 3. Let arms rest by your sides, palms forward, and breathe steadily.
Safety Cue: Gently sway side to side to find your center of gravity. Avoid locking the knees completely.

Goals: Improve Flexibility & Mobility, Rehabilitation & Injury prevention
Contraindications: Acute knee injury, recent hip replacement
Steps to Perform: 1. Stand next to a support, grab one ankle or foot with the same hand. 2. Gently pull the heel toward the buttock, keeping the knees close together. 3. Stand tall, engaging the glutes to deepen the stretch in the front of the thigh.
Safety Cue: Do not yank or bounce the leg. Stop if you feel sharp knee pain.

Goals: Rehabilitation & Injury prevention, Improve Posture and Balance
Contraindications: Acute back pain, neck strain (support head with hands)
Steps to Perform: 1. Lie on your back, knees bent 90 degrees over hips, arms straight up. 2. Brace core, slowly extend opposite arm and leg toward the floor without arching back. 3. Exhale and return to the start. Inhale and switch sides.
Safety Cue: Ensure your lower back remains pressed into the mat throughout the entire movement.

Goals: Rehabilitation & Injury prevention, Increase overall strength
Contraindications: Acute hip bursitis, recent hip surgery
Steps to Perform: 1. Lie on your side, knees bent, feet together, and head supported. 2. Keeping feet touching, squeeze glutes to lift the top knee toward the ceiling. 3. Slowly lower the knee back down with control.
Safety Cue: Keep hips stacked and avoid rolling the top hip backward as you lift the knee.

Goals: Improve cardiovascular fitness
Contraindications: Severe joint arthritis, stress fractures
Steps to Perform: 1. Stand tall, feet together, arms at sides. 2. Step right foot out to the side while simultaneously raising arms overhead. 3. Return right foot and arms to start. Repeat on the left side, alternating quickly.
Safety Cue: Maintain an upright posture and control the pace. Keep the movement gentle on the joints.

Goals: Increase overall strength
Contraindications: Shoulder impingement, rotator cuff tear
Steps to Perform: 1. Lie on a bench, holding dumbbells above your chest, palms forward. 2. Inhale and slowly lower the weights to the sides of your chest. 3. Exhale and powerfully push the weights back up, squeezing the chest.
Safety Cue: Keep your shoulders pressed down into the bench and away from your ears. Control the descent.

Goals: Improve Flexibility & Mobility, Improve Posture and Balance
Contraindications: Acute shoulder injury, nerve pain radiating into the arm
Steps to Perform: 1. Stand with feet shoulder-width apart. Inhale and reach one arm straight overhead. 2. Gently lean to the opposite side, keeping hips stationary. 3. Feel the stretch along the side of the body. Return and switch sides.
Safety Cue: Keep the neck relaxed and avoid hunching the shoulders during the side bend.

Goals: Increase overall strength, Improve cardiovascular fitness
Contraindications: Recent knee replacement, patellar tendonitis
Steps to Perform: 1. Lean back against a wall, then walk feet out and slide down until knees are at a 90-degree angle. 2. Press lower back flat against the wall and brace the core. 3. Hold the position for time.
Safety Cue: Ensure knees are directly over ankles (forming a right angle). Do not let your knees move past your toes.

Goals: Improve Flexibility & Mobility, Rehabilitation & Injury prevention
Contraindications: Acute knee pain, unhealed groin strain
Health Benefit: Relieve Hip Flexor Tightness & Low Back Stress
Steps to Perform: 1. Kneel in a lunge position with the back knee on the mat. 2. Gently tuck the tailbone under (posterior tilt) and shift hips slightly forward. 3. Lift the chest and hold the stretch in the front of the back hip.
Safety Cue: Keep the front knee aligned over the ankle. Avoid leaning too far forward and stressing the knee.

Goals: Reduce Stress, Improve Oxygen Efficiency
Contraindications: Severe GERD (Acid Reflux), unmanaged anxiety
Steps to Perform: 1. Lie on your back, knees bent, one hand on chest, one on belly. 2. Inhale deeply through the nose, focusing on the belly hand rising (not the chest hand). 3. Exhale slowly and completely through pursed lips.
Safety Cue: Focus on a slow, deliberate exhale to fully engage the diaphragm and promote relaxation.

Goals: Rehabilitation & Injury prevention, Increase overall strength
Contraindications: Acute knee/hip pain, severe balance issues
Steps to Perform: 1. Place a resistance band around your ankles or just above your knees. 2. Stand in a slight athletic crouch (knees slightly bent). 3. Step sideways, maintaining tension on the band with slow, controlled steps. Repeat in the other direction.
Safety Cue: Keep your toes pointing straight forward and avoid letting your knees cave inward.

Goals: Increase overall strength, Improve Posture and Balance
Contraindications: Acute shoulder or low back pain, unhealed abdominal separation
Steps to Perform: 1. Kneel behind the ball, forearms on the ball. 2. Slowly roll the ball forward, extending arms and torso without letting the lower back arch. 3. Brace the core and pull the ball back to the start using your abdominals.
Safety Cue: Stop the motion immediately if you feel any strain or discomfort in your lower back. Maintain a neutral spine.

Goals: Improve Flexibility & Mobility, Increase overall strength
Contraindications: Unmanaged high blood pressure, late-stage pregnancy, acute wrist injury
Steps to Perform: 1. Start on hands and knees. Tuck toes and lift hips up and back, forming an inverted 'V'. 2. Press palms down, driving hips toward the back wall. 3. Gently pedal the feet (bending one knee, then the other) to stretch the calves and hamstrings.
Safety Cue: Keep a slight bend in the knees if hamstrings are very tight to prioritize lengthening the spine.

Goals: Improve Flexibility & Mobility, Improve cardiovascular fitness
Contraindications: Acute hip/knee pain, severe unmanaged balance issues
Steps to Perform: 1. Stand tall, core engaged. Alternately lift your knee toward the opposite hand. 2. Touch the knee to the hand (or as close as comfortable) to engage the core. 3. Maintain a consistent, marching rhythm.
Safety Cue: Control the descent of the foot back to the floor. Focus on posture and avoid leaning side-to-side.

Goals: Improve Flexibility & Mobility, Improve Posture and Balance
Contraindications: Rib fracture, severe osteoporosis, acute back pain
Steps to Perform: 1. Lie on the mat, roller placed horizontally under your upper back (avoiding the neck/low back). 2. Support head with hands. Roll slowly up and down from the base of the neck to the mid-back. 3. Pause on tight spots and take a deep breath.
Safety Cue: Keep glutes slightly lifted off the floor to prevent excessive pressure on the lumbar spine (low back).

Goals: Increase overall strength, Improve Posture and Balance
Contraindications: Acute knee pain, ankle instability, recent hip surgery
Steps to Perform: 1. Place one foot on a bench behind you, holding dumbbells at sides. 2. Lower hips straight down, ensuring the front knee tracks over the mid-foot. 3. Drive through the front heel to return to the starting position.
Safety Cue: Ensure the front knee stays aligned over the ankle. Use a mirror or wall to check your form.

Goals: Improve Posture and Balance, Increase overall strength
Contraindications: Unstable blood pressure, recent stroke, severe hip weakness
Health Benefit: Deep Core Engagement & Hip Flexor Endurance
Steps to Perform: 1. Sit on mat, feet flat, hands behind thighs. 2. Lean back slightly, lift feet, balancing on tailbone. 3. For advanced: release hands and fully extend legs into a "V" shape.
Safety Cue: Protect your low back by maintaining a straight (not rounded) spine. Stop if you feel strain in the back.

Goals: Rehabilitation & Injury prevention, Improve Posture and Balance
Contraindications: Acute SI joint pain, unhealed pelvic injury
Steps to Perform: 1. Lie on back, perform a standard Glute Bridge (hips up). 2. Keeping hips level, slowly lift one foot a few inches off the floor. 3. Lower the foot and repeat with the other leg, marching slowly.
Safety Cue: Keep hips level and avoid letting them drop or shift side-to-side as you march.

Goals: Reduce Stress, Improve Flexibility & Mobility
Contraindications: Late-stage pregnancy, acute knee injury/pain (use padding)
Steps to Perform: 1. Kneel on the mat, sitting hips back toward heels. 2. Fold forward, resting torso between (or outside) thighs. 3. Extend arms out, rest forehead on the mat, and breathe deeply into the back.
Safety Cue: Use a pillow or block under your forehead if it doesn't reach the mat comfortably.

Goals: Increase overall strength, Improve cardiovascular fitness
Contraindications: Acute back injury, unmanaged hernia, unstable shoulder
Steps to Perform: 1. Hinge at the hips (like a RDL) to grip the bell. 2. Hike the bell back, then aggressively snap hips forward, squeezing glutes to propel the bell upward (to chest height). 3. Let the bell fall back into the hinge position.
Safety Cue: It is a hip-driven movement, not a squat. Keep the back flat and avoid letting the arms lift the bell.

Goals: Improve Posture and Balance, Rehabilitation & Injury prevention
Contraindications: Severe vertigo, unstable ankle/foot injury
Steps to Perform: 1. Stand near a wall. Place one foot directly in front of the other (heel touching toe). 2. Walk forward slowly, maintaining the heel-to-toe contact for each step. 3. Look forward, not down at your feet.
Safety Cue: Take your time and use the support surface only for fingertip balance if possible.

Goals: Improve Flexibility & Mobility, Rehabilitation & Injury prevention
Contraindications: Acute Achilles tendon injury, Deep Vein Thrombosis (DVT)
Steps to Perform: 1. Face a wall, place the ball of one foot against the wall (heel on the floor). 2. Gently lean your hips forward until you feel a comfortable stretch in the calf. 3. Hold and then repeat on the other side.
Safety Cue: Keep the back leg straight for the deep calf (gastrocnemius) stretch.

Goals: Increase overall strength, Improve Posture and Balance
Contraindications: Recent abdominal surgery, severe back pain
Steps to Perform: 1. Lie on your back, press your low back into the mat. 2. Lift head, neck, and shoulders off the mat. Extend arms overhead. 3. Lift legs slightly off the floor, keeping the low back glued to the mat.
Safety Cue: If your low back arches, raise your legs higher toward the ceiling or bend your knees.

Goals: Improve Posture and Balance, Rehabilitation & Injury prevention
Contraindications: Acute shoulder impingement, unhealed rib fracture
Steps to Perform: 1. Stand against a wall, pressing your lower back and head against it. 2. Place forearms/elbows against the wall, forming a goalpost shape. 3. Slowly slide arms up the wall, keeping the back and forearms in contact, then slide back down.
Safety Cue: Keep your wrists and elbows touching the wall as much as possible to ensure scapular engagement.

Goals: Increase overall strength, Improve Posture and Balance
Contraindications: Acute low back pain, shoulder instability
Steps to Perform: 1. Pick up heavy weights, stand tall, and brace core. 2. Walk slowly and deliberately for the prescribed time or distance. 3. Maintain perfectly upright posture, resisting the urge to lean or slump.
Safety Cue: Do not lean away from the weights. Keep your shoulders back and down, chest up.

Goals: Improve cardiovascular fitness, Increase overall strength
Contraindications: Acute knee/ankle pain, severe ligament laxity
Steps to Perform: 1. Stand facing a sturdy box/step. Place one foot completely on the box. 2. Step up using the front leg, bringing the back foot up (or just tapping it). 3. Step down slowly with the back leg, then the front. Alternate or complete all reps on one side.
Safety Cue: Push through the heel of the foot on the box. Avoid pushing off the floor with the back foot.

Goals: Improve Posture and Balance, Rehabilitation & Injury prevention
Contraindications: Acute biceps tendonitis, shoulder pain during abduction
Steps to Perform: 1. Stand tall, holding the band straight out in front of you with a shoulder-width grip. 2. Keeping arms straight (or slightly bent), pull the band horizontally apart, squeezing shoulder blades together. 3. Slowly return to the starting position.
Safety Cue: Keep arms at chest height and avoid shrugging your shoulders toward your ears.

Goals: Improve Flexibility & Mobility
Contraindications: Acute elbow or wrist pain, shoulder surgery history
Steps to Perform: 1. Stand next to a wall, place your palm flat on the wall behind you at shoulder height, fingers pointing backward. 2. Gently rotate your body away from the arm until you feel a stretch in the front of the shoulder and biceps. 3. Hold and switch sides.
Safety Cue: Do not force the stretch if you feel sharp pain in the elbow or shoulder joint.

Goals: Rehabilitation & Injury prevention, Improve Flexibility & Mobility
Contraindications: Unhealed hip labral tear, acute hip joint pain
Health Benefit: Hip Joint Health & Range of Motion
Steps to Perform: 1. Lie on your back, knees bent, feet flat. 2. Keeping your feet together, slowly let one knee fall open to the side (external rotation). 3. Use hip muscles to pull the knee back up to the center.
Safety Cue: Keep your pelvis steady and avoid letting your hips tilt or rock as the knee moves out.

Goals: Improve Flexibility & Mobility, Reduce Stress
Contraindications: Acute sciatica, recent spinal fusion surgery
Steps to Perform: 1. Sit tall with legs extended. Bend one knee, stepping the foot over the opposite leg. 2. Place the hand behind you for support. Wrap the opposite arm around the bent knee. 3. Inhale to lengthen the spine, exhale to gently twist and look over the back shoulder.
Safety Cue: Twist from the torso, not the neck. Use gentle pressure to deepen the stretch with each exhale.

Goals: Increase overall strength, Improve cardiovascular fitness
Contraindications: Spinal disc issues, acute shoulder injury
Steps to Perform: 1. Stand holding the ball. Raise it explosively overhead, fully extending the body. 2. Hinge hips and slam the ball hard into the ground between your feet. 3. Catch the rebound and immediately repeat.
Safety Cue: Protect your back by driving the slam with your hips (like a hinge/squat) and bracing your core.

Goals: Increase overall strength, Rehabilitation & Injury prevention
Contraindications: Unmanaged hernia, acute rib pain
Steps to Perform: 1. Stand perpendicular to the cable/band anchor, gripping the handle with both hands at your chest. 2. Slowly press the handle straight out in front of you. 3. Hold for 2 seconds, resisting the force trying to rotate your body away from the anchor. Slowly return.
Safety Cue: Brace your core tightly and avoid letting your hips or shoulders rotate toward the anchor point.

Goals: Improve Posture and Balance, Reduce Stress
Contraindications: Severe GERD, late-stage pregnancy
Steps to Perform: 1. Lie on your belly with forehead resting on stacked hands or a cushion. 2. Inhale through the nose, feeling the belly press gently into the floor. 3. Exhale slowly, feeling the belly draw back in.
Safety Cue: Ensure your body is completely relaxed except for the gentle movement of the diaphragm.

Goals: Increase overall strength, Rehabilitation & Injury prevention
Contraindications: Acute knee replacement (check surgeon protocol), unmanaged high blood pressure
Health Benefit: Safe Lower Body Strength & Bone Density
Steps to Perform: 1. Sit in machine, feet shoulder-width on the platform. Unlock the safety handles. 2. Push the platform away using your heels and glutes until legs are nearly straight (do not lock knees). 3. Slowly return the platform to the starting position with control.
Safety Cue: Never lock your knees out completely at the top; keep a micro-bend. Control the speed on the way back.

Goals: Rehabilitation & Injury prevention, Increase overall strength
Contraindications: Acute Achilles tendon injury, Deep Vein Thrombosis (DVT)
Steps to Perform: 1. Sit in machine, place balls of feet on platform, adjust pad over knees. 2. Lower heels as far as comfortable to stretch calves. 3. Drive up onto your toes, holding the contraction briefly at the peak.
Safety Cue: Maintain control throughout the movement. Avoid bouncing at the bottom stretch, which can strain the Achilles.

Goals: Increase overall strength, Rehabilitation & Injury prevention
Contraindications: Acute knee/hip pain, recent knee/hip surgery
Steps to Perform: 1. Sit tall in a sturdy chair, feet flat and knees bent 90 degrees. 2. Lean slightly forward, push through feet to stand up (using hands for support as needed). 3. Slowly and with control, lower back down to the seated position.
Safety Cue: Choose a chair with armrests for safety and support. Control the speed, especially when lowering back down.

Goals: Rehabilitation & Injury prevention, Increase overall strength
Contraindications: Acute shoulder instability, rotator cuff tear
Steps to Perform: 1. Lie on back, band looped under back, holding ends in hands, arms out wide. 2. Press hands straight up toward the ceiling, engaging chest and shoulder muscles. 3. Slowly return to the starting position.
Safety Cue: Keep your shoulders pressed down into the floor and avoid shrugging up toward your ears.

Goals: Improve Flexibility & Mobility, Rehabilitation & Injury prevention
Contraindications: Acute shoulder impingement, recent neck surgery
Steps to Perform: 1. Hold the kettlebell upside down (bottoms-up) at chest height. 2. Slowly move the bell in a controlled circle around your head. 3. Reverse the direction and repeat. Maintain core engagement throughout.
Safety Cue: Keep the bell close to your head and move slowly to maintain control and protect the neck.

Goals: Rehabilitation & Injury prevention, Increase overall strength
Contraindications: Acute SI joint pain, wrist pain (use fists)
Steps to Perform: 1. Start on hands and knees (tabletop). 2. Keep the knee bent at 90 degrees. Lift one leg up toward the ceiling (foot facing ceiling). 3. Squeeze the glute at the top, then slowly lower the leg.
Safety Cue: Avoid arching the low back. The movement should only come from the hip joint and glute muscles.

Goals: Increase overall strength, Improve Posture and Balance
Contraindications: Acute shoulder injury, tennis/golfer's elbow
Steps to Perform: 1. Sit at the machine, grip the bar slightly wider than shoulders. 2. Brace core, lean back slightly, and pull the bar down toward your chest, squeezing shoulder blades together. 3. Slowly raise the bar back up with control, feeling the stretch in the lats.
Safety Cue: Keep your chest tall and avoid letting your entire body swing or rock backward to assist the pull.

Goals: Rehabilitation & Injury prevention, Improve Flexibility & Mobility
Contraindications: Acute back flare-up (perform gently), unstable pelvic fracture
Steps to Perform: 1. Lie on your back, knees bent, feet flat. 2. Gently flatten the lower back into the floor by tilting the pelvis up (tucking the tailbone). 3. Slowly release and let the low back return to a neutral position.
Safety Cue: The movement is small and subtle. Avoid pressing down so hard that your butt lifts off the floor.

Goals: Increase overall strength
Contraindications: Shoulder impingement, unhealed AC joint separation
Steps to Perform: 1. Sit upright on a bench with back support, holding dumbbells at shoulder height, palms forward. 2. Press the dumbbells straight overhead until arms are nearly locked. 3. Slowly lower the weights back to the start.
Safety Cue: Keep your core tight and avoid excessive arching in the lower back as you press the weights overhead.

Goals: Improve cardiovascular fitness, Rehabilitation & Injury prevention
Contraindications: Open wounds, fear of water, unmanaged ear infection
Steps to Perform: 1. Stand in chest or waist-deep water. 2. Begin walking normally, using the water's resistance. 3. Use an arm swing to increase the cardiorespiratory effort.
Safety Cue: Wear water shoes for traction. Maintain an upright posture and control your speed.

Goals: Improve Posture and Balance, Rehabilitation & Injury prevention
Contraindications: Acute shoulder pain, significant rotator cuff damage
Steps to Perform: 1. Stand against a wall (head, shoulders, and hips touching). 2. Bring arms up with elbows bent 90 degrees, palms facing forward (like a goalpost). 3. Slowly slide arms overhead, attempting to keep arms and hands touching the wall.
Safety Cue: Keep your lower back as flat as possible against the wall. Do not let your ribcage flare out.

Goals: Improve Posture and Balance, Reduce Stress
Contraindications: Acute knee/ankle injury, severe dizziness
Steps to Perform: 1. Stand tall. Shift weight to one foot. Place the sole of the opposite foot on the calf or inner thigh (avoid the knee). 2. Bring hands to prayer position at the chest or extend them overhead. 3. Gaze at a fixed spot and hold.
Safety Cue: Engage the core and gently push the foot into the inner thigh (and the inner thigh back) to lock the balance.

Goals: Increase overall strength, Improve Posture and Balance
Contraindications: Unhealed abdominal hernia, acute lower back pain
Steps to Perform: 1. Sit at machine, feet on platform, slight bend in knees. Grip handle. 2. Pull the handle toward your abdomen, squeezing shoulder blades together. 3. Slowly extend the arms back out, maintaining an upright torso.
Safety Cue: Keep the torso upright and avoid excessive rocking back and forth to maintain muscle isolation.

Goals: Improve Flexibility & Mobility, Rehabilitation & Injury prevention
Contraindications: Recent hip/knee surgery, acute piriformis syndrome
Steps to Perform: 1. Lie on back, knees bent, feet flat. Cross one ankle over the opposite thigh (forming a '4'). 2. Gently pull the bottom thigh toward your chest. 3. Feel the stretch in the outer hip of the crossed leg. Hold and switch.
Safety Cue: Keep your head and neck relaxed on the mat. Never pull so hard that the stretch becomes painful.

Goals: Rehabilitation & Injury prevention, Increase overall strength
Contraindications: Acute knee swelling, unhealed patellar fracture
Steps to Perform: 1. Sit tall in a chair, feet flat on the floor. 2. Slowly extend one knee until the leg is straight, contracting the quad muscle. 3. Slowly lower the foot back to the floor. Alternate legs.
Safety Cue: Ensure you are sitting fully upright and using the quadriceps muscle to straighten the leg.

Goals: Increase overall strength, Improve Flexibility & Mobility
Contraindications: Acute lumbar disc injury, severe hamstring tear
Steps to Perform: 1. Stand holding dumbbells, soft bend in knees. 2. Hinge at the hips, pushing glutes back, lowering the weights along the legs until a stretch is felt in hamstrings. 3. Drive hips forward, squeezing glutes to stand tall.
Safety Cue: Keep your back flat throughout the movement. The weights should stay close to your legs (like shaving your shins).

Goals: Improve Flexibility & Mobility, Reduce Stress
Contraindications: Acute knee pain, recent hip replacement
Steps to Perform: 1. Stand with feet wide, squat down into a deep squat (use a block under hips if needed). 2. Rest elbows on the inside of the knees, pressing gently to open the hips. 3. Take slow, deep, diaphragmatic breaths in this position.
Safety Cue: Ensure your knees track in line with your toes. If heels lift, place a rolled towel under them.

Goals: Increase overall strength
Contraindications: Spinal disc issues, unhealed oblique strain
Steps to Perform: 1. Stand perpendicular to a sturdy wall, holding a medicine ball at your chest. 2. Rotate away from the wall, then explosively rotate toward the wall, throwing the ball hard into the wall. 3. Catch the rebound and repeat quickly.
Safety Cue: Pivot the back foot to allow the hips to rotate fully and protect the knees and low back.

Goals: Rehabilitation & Injury prevention, Increase overall strength
Contraindications: Acute hip joint pain, recent hip surgery
Steps to Perform: 1. Sit in the machine, position pads on the outside of your knees. 2. Slowly press your legs open, pushing against the resistance. 3. Slowly return the legs to the starting position with control.
Safety Cue: Maintain an upright posture and avoid leaning forward or backward to generate the force.

Goals: Rehabilitation & Injury prevention, Improve Flexibility & Mobility
Contraindications: Acute shoulder pain, severe hip weakness
Steps to Perform: 1. Lie on your back, knees bent, feet flat. Place arms by your sides. 2. Gently lift your head and shoulders, reaching one hand toward the heel on the same side. 3. Tap your heel, then slowly lower back down. Alternate sides.
Safety Cue: Keep your chin slightly tucked and avoid straining the neck. The movement is a gentle crunch to the side.

Goals: Increase overall strength, Improve Flexibility & Mobility
Contraindications: Acute low back pain, severe ankle instability
Steps to Perform: 1. Stand holding one dumbbell in the hand opposite the standing leg. 2. Hinge at the hip, lowering the torso while extending the back leg straight behind you. 3. Maintain a flat back. Drive through the standing heel to return to standing, squeezing the glute.
Safety Cue: Maintain a neutral spine; focus on pushing the hips back. It's a balance challenge, so move with control.

Goals: Increase overall strength, Improve Posture and Balance
Contraindications: Acute shoulder pain, recent abdominal surgery
Steps to Perform: 1. Get into a forearm plank position with your elbows resting on the stability ball. 2. Walk feet back until your body forms a straight line from head to heels. 3. Brace your core and glutes tightly, resisting the urge to let the ball shift or spin.
Safety Cue: Keep your hips level and avoid letting your low back arch or sag. The body should be rigid like a board.

Goals: Improve cardiovascular fitness, Increase overall strength
Contraindications: Acute knee/ankle pain, severe osteoporosis
Steps to Perform: 1. Stand beside a low, sturdy box. Lower into a quarter-squat. 2. Explode sideways, landing softly on top of the box. 3. Step or jump back down and immediately repeat, alternating sides or sets.
Safety Cue: Always land softly with bent knees to absorb impact. Ensure the box is sturdy and will not slip.

Goals: Improve Flexibility & Mobility, Improve Posture and Balance
Contraindications: Acute knee pain, unmanaged high blood pressure (look down)
Steps to Perform: 1. Stand with feet wide, turn one foot out 90 degrees and the back foot slightly in. 2. Bend the front knee to 90 degrees, tracking over the ankle. Extend arms out parallel to floor. 3. Sink hips down, gazing over the front fingertips.
Safety Cue: Ensure the front knee tracks directly over the middle of the foot; do not let it collapse inward.

Goals: Increase overall strength
Contraindications: Acute elbow or shoulder pain, unhealed rotator cuff tear
Steps to Perform: 1. Stand tall (or sit), holding one dumbbell overhead with one hand. 2. Slowly lower the dumbbell behind your head by bending the elbow. 3. Extend the elbow fully, pressing the weight back up. Keep the elbow pointing forward.
Safety Cue: Keep your core braced and avoid arching your lower back as the weight moves overhead.

Goals: Improve Flexibility & Mobility, Rehabilitation & Injury prevention
Contraindications: Acute spinal disc injury, unhealed oblique strain
Steps to Perform: 1. Sit tall on the edge of a chair, holding a light medicine ball at your chest. 2. Slowly twist your torso to one side, maintaining an upright posture. 3. Twist back to center, then slowly twist to the opposite side.
Safety Cue: Keep feet flat on the floor and avoid using momentum; twist slowly and with control from the torso.

Goals: Improve Flexibility & Mobility, Rehabilitation & Injury prevention
Contraindications: Acute hamstring tear, knee ligament injury
Steps to Perform: 1. Lie on back, loop towel around one foot. Extend leg toward ceiling. 2. Pull on towel to feel a stretch (30 sec). Push foot against towel (5 sec). 3. Relax and pull the foot slightly higher for a deeper stretch. Repeat.
Safety Cue: Never stretch into sharp or burning pain. Keep the lower back flat on the mat.

Goals: Improve Posture and Balance, Rehabilitation & Injury prevention
Contraindications: Acute knee/ankle sprain, severe vertigo
Steps to Perform: 1. Stand on one leg. Imagine a clock face around you. 2. Keeping the standing knee slightly bent, reach the free foot/hand out to the '12', '3', and '9' o'clock positions. 3. Maintain balance and avoid letting the standing knee collapse inward.
Safety Cue: Focus on keeping the hip of the standing leg stable and avoiding excessive side-to-side wobbling.

Goals: Increase overall strength, Rehabilitation & Injury prevention
Contraindications: Acute hamstring tear, recent low back surgery
Steps to Perform: 1. Lie on your back, place heels on the stability ball, and bridge your hips up off the floor. 2. Keeping hips lifted, slowly roll the ball in toward your butt and then slowly roll it back out. 3. Keep core and glutes engaged throughout.
Safety Cue: Keep your hips lifted high and avoid letting your low back arch as you roll the ball out and in.

Goals: Reduce Stress, Improve Focus
Contraindications: Unmanaged respiratory condition (consult physician)
Steps to Perform: 1. Sit or lie comfortably. Exhale all air out. 2. Inhale slowly through the nose for 4 seconds. 3. Hold breath for 4 seconds. 4. Exhale slowly through the mouth for 4 seconds. 5. Hold empty for 4 seconds, then repeat.
Safety Cue: Focus entirely on the count. If the hold is uncomfortable, adjust to a shorter duration (e.g., 3-3-3-3).

Goals: Increase overall strength, Improve Posture and Balance
Contraindications: Acute shoulder or elbow injury, unhealed abdominal separation
Steps to Perform: 1. Hold handles, lean back with body straight. The closer your feet are to the anchor, the harder it is. 2. Pull chest up toward the handles, squeezing shoulder blades together. 3. Slowly lower back down to full arm extension with control.
Safety Cue: Keep your body perfectly straight (rigid plank). Avoid letting the hips sag or arching the low back.

Goals: Improve cardiovascular fitness, Mobility
Contraindications: Acute shoulder instability, severe arthritis in hands/wrists
Steps to Perform: 1. Stand in a staggered stance, knees soft. 2. Perform light, controlled punches (jabs, crosses) with alternating arms. 3. Move feet lightly, shifting weight side-to-side, avoiding impact.
Safety Cue: Keep knees soft and your elbows tucked near your ribs between punches for joint protection.

Goals: Increase overall strength
Contraindications: Acute lumbar disc injury, unmanaged hernia
Steps to Perform: 1. Stand over the bar. Hinge at the hips, grip the bar, ensuring a flat back. 2. Drive through the floor with feet, standing up by powerfully extending hips and knees. 3. Lock out hips and shoulders at the top. Lower the bar with control by hinging hips back.
Safety Cue: Maintain a perfectly flat, neutral spine throughout the entire lift. If the back rounds, the weight is too heavy.

Goals: Improve Flexibility & Mobility, Improve Posture and Balance
Contraindications: Shoulder surgery (check protocol), acute rotator cuff injury
Steps to Perform: 1. Stand facing a corner. Place forearms (or just hands) on the walls on either side, elbows slightly below shoulder height. 2. Gently lean your chest forward until a stretch is felt across the chest. 3. Hold and breathe deeply.
Safety Cue: Do not lean excessively to avoid overstretching the shoulder joint. Keep neck relaxed.

Goals: Rehabilitation & Injury prevention, Increase overall strength
Contraindications: Acute shoulder inflammation, unhealed labral tear
Steps to Perform: 1. Hold a band with both hands, elbow bent 90 degrees and tucked close to the side. 2. Keeping the elbow stationary, pull the hand away from the body against the resistance of the band. 3. Slowly return the hand to the starting position.
Safety Cue: Keep the working elbow pinned to your side (use a towel if needed). Avoid shrugging the shoulder.

Goals: Improve Posture and Balance, Rehabilitation & Injury prevention
Contraindications: Recent chest or abdominal surgery, neck pain
Steps to Perform: 1. Lie face down, forehead resting on the floor or a towel, arms by sides, palms down. 2. Gently squeeze shoulder blades together and slightly lift arms a few inches off the floor. 3. Hold for 2 seconds, then slowly lower.
Safety Cue: Keep your neck relaxed and avoid lifting the head or arching the low back. Focus only on the shoulder blades.

Goals: Increase overall strength, Rehabilitation & Injury prevention
Contraindications: Acute knee pain, unhealed meniscus tear
Steps to Perform: 1. Place a resistance band above your knees. Stand feet hip-width apart. 2. Descend into a shallow squat, driving knees outward against the band. 3. Hold the squat and take 3-4 small, controlled steps to the side. Repeat on the other side.
Safety Cue: Keep tension on the band at all times by actively pushing your knees outward.

Goals: Improve Posture and Balance, Improve Flexibility & Mobility
Contraindications: Acute hip/knee pain, unmanaged low blood pressure
Steps to Perform: 1. Start standing. Hinge forward into a single-leg T position (Warrior 3). 2. Place one hand on the floor (or block). Rotate the torso and hips open to the side. 3. Extend the top arm toward the ceiling and gaze toward the floor (or ceiling for advanced).
Safety Cue: It's okay to bend the standing knee. Use a block to bring the floor closer to maintain a flat back.

Goals: Increase overall strength
Contraindications: Acute elbow joint pain, biceps tendonitis
Steps to Perform: 1. Sit upright on a bench, holding dumbbells at your sides, palms facing forward. 2. Curl the weights up toward the shoulders, flexing the biceps at the top. 3. Slowly lower the weights back down to the starting position.
Safety Cue: Keep your elbows pinned to your sides. Avoid rocking your body or shrugging your shoulders to lift the weight.

Goals: Improve Flexibility & Mobility, Dynamic Warm-up
Contraindications: Acute hamstring strain, severe low back pain
Steps to Perform: 1. Stand tall, place one heel on the floor in front of you, toes pointed up. 2. With a flat back, slightly bend the back knee and gently sweep your opposite hand toward your raised toes. 3. Stand back up and repeat the gentle hinge/sweep motion dynamically.
Safety Cue: Keep the knee of the sweeping leg straight to engage the hamstring. Keep the back flat; avoid rounding.

Goals: Improve Posture and Balance, Increase overall strength
Contraindications: Acute wrist pain, severe shoulder pain
Steps to Perform: 1. Sit on floor, legs straight, hands behind you, fingers pointing forward. 2. Push through hands and heels to lift hips off the floor, forming a straight line from shoulders to heels. 3. Squeeze glutes and hold the position.
Safety Cue: Tuck your chin slightly to maintain a neutral neck alignment. Avoid letting your hips sag.

Goals: Improve Flexibility & Mobility, Rehabilitation & Injury prevention
Contraindications: Recent hip surgery, unhealed groin strain
Health Benefit: Hip Joint Health & Range of Motion
Steps to Perform: 1. Sit tall on the floor (or edge of a chair). Bend one knee to 90 degrees in front of you. 2. Keep the hip still and slowly rotate the lower leg inward. 3. Return to the start. Only move within a comfortable range.
Safety Cue: Maintain an upright, stable torso. The rotation should come solely from the hip socket.

Goals: Increase overall strength
Contraindications: Acute shoulder pain, chronic sternum/rib pain
Steps to Perform: 1. Sit in machine, back flat against pad. Position arms on the pads (or grip handles). 2. Slowly bring the hands/pads together in front of your chest. 3. Slowly return to the starting position with control.
Safety Cue: Keep a slight bend in your elbows throughout the movement. Focus on squeezing the chest muscles.

Goals: Increase overall strength, Rehabilitation & Injury prevention
Contraindications: Acute low back pain, unhealed hernia
Steps to Perform: 1. Kneel beside the cable/band anchor. Grip the handle with both hands high and to the side. 2. Pull the handle down and across your body diagonally (chopping motion). 3. Resist the rotation as you slowly return to the start.
Safety Cue: Ensure the movement is controlled. Pivot your hips slightly to protect the knees and lower back.

Goals: Dynamic Warm-up, Improve Flexibility & Mobility
Contraindications: Acute hamstring strain/tear
Steps to Perform: 1. Stand tall, take a small step forward with one leg, keeping it straight, toe pointed up. 2. Sweep the hands forward and down (as if scooping up water) past the front foot. 3. Step forward and repeat with the opposite leg, maintaining a fluid movement.
Safety Cue: Keep the front leg straight as you sweep. It's a gentle, dynamic movement, not a static stretch.

Goals: Increase overall strength, Improve Posture and Balance
Contraindications: Acute shoulder instability, inflamed elbow joint
Steps to Perform: 1. Sit tall at the cable machine, grip one handle. 2. Pull the handle toward your ribs, focusing on squeezing the shoulder blade toward the spine. 3. Slowly extend the arm back out, maintaining an upright torso.
Safety Cue: Avoid rotating your torso excessively; the goal is to keep the trunk stable and pull with the back.

Goals: Rehabilitation & Injury prevention, Increase overall strength
Contraindications: Acute shoulder injury, unstable wrist/hand fracture
Steps to Perform: 1. Stand arms' length from a wall, hands flat against the wall at chest height. 2. Slowly bend elbows and lean your chest toward the wall. 3. Push back strongly to the starting position.
Safety Cue: Maintain a straight line from head to heels. Use a wide stance for more stability.

Goals: Rehabilitation & Injury prevention, Increase overall strength
Contraindications: Acute knee pain, unhealed meniscus tear
Steps to Perform: 1. Stand against a wall, place the ball between your low back and the wall. 2. Walk feet out slightly. Lower into a squat, rolling the ball down your back. 3. Drive through the heels to return to standing.
Safety Cue: Keep your feet positioned so your knees do not go past your toes at the bottom of the squat.

Goals: Reduce Stress, Rehabilitation & Injury prevention
Contraindications: Acute whiplash, unhealed cervical spine fracture
Steps to Perform: 1. Sit tall. Slowly lower chin toward chest (nod). Return to center. 2. Gently tilt ear toward shoulder on one side. Return to center. 3. Repeat slowly and gently, avoiding pain.
Safety Cue: The movement should be slow and gentle. Never push into pain or full range of motion.

Goals: Improve Posture and Balance, Stability
Contraindications: Shoulder impingement, neck fusion surgery
Steps to Perform: 1. Sit on floor or a bench, press a light dumbbell straight overhead. 2. Maintain a perfectly vertical arm and actively press the weight to the ceiling. 3. Hold and resist any movement in the torso or arm.
Safety Cue: Focus on keeping the core braced and the ribcage pulled down to avoid arching the low back.

Goals: Rehabilitation & Injury prevention, Increase overall strength
Contraindications: Acute rib fracture, unhealed shoulder injury
Steps to Perform: 1. Lie on your side, forearm on floor, elbow directly under shoulder. 2. Keep knees bent, stack hips, and lift hips off the floor, forming a straight line from head to knees. 3. Hold, then slowly lower.
Safety Cue: Ensure your elbow is directly under your shoulder to protect the joint. Squeeze the bottom oblique muscle.

Goals: Improve Flexibility & Mobility, Reduce Stress
Contraindications: Acute sacroiliac joint pain, late-stage pregnancy (avoid)
Steps to Perform: 1. Lie on back, knees bent, feet flat near hips. 2. Press into feet, squeeze glutes, and lift hips toward the ceiling. 3. Clasp hands underneath or keep arms flat. Hold the peak of the pose.
Safety Cue: Keep your knees tracking over your ankles. Avoid letting the knees splay out wide.

Goals: Rehabilitation & Injury prevention, Increase overall strength
Contraindications: Acute groin strain, hip joint impingement
Steps to Perform: 1. Lie on back, knees bent, feet flat. Place a small ball or foam roller between your knees. 2. Gently squeeze the object between your knees for a few seconds. 3. Slowly release the squeeze. Focus on the inner thigh muscles.
Safety Cue: Keep your back relaxed and neutral on the floor. Focus only on the inner thigh contraction.

Goals: Improve cardiovascular fitness
Contraindications: Acute knee/hip pain, severe unmanaged balance issues
Steps to Perform: 1. Use a sturdy handrail for balance. 2. Climb stairs at a steady, rhythmic pace, focusing on pushing off the entire foot. 3. Maintain an upright posture and control your breathing.
Safety Cue: Use handrails for safety and take one step at a time if balance is a concern.

Goals: Improve Flexibility & Mobility, Improve Posture and Balance
Contraindications: Recent hip replacement (check angle), severe knee pain
Health Benefit: Relieve Hip Tightness & Low Back Stress
Steps to Perform: 1. Sit near the edge of a chair. Slide one hip forward until the thigh is off the seat and the knee is pointing toward the floor. 2. Keep the chest lifted and gently tuck the tailbone under (pelvic tilt). 3. Hold the stretch in the front of the hip.
Safety Cue: Sit on the very edge of the chair to allow the hip flexor of the back leg to lengthen.

Goals: Increase overall strength
Contraindications: Acute shoulder instability, severe lower back pain
Steps to Perform: 1. Lie on your back, knees bent, feet flat. Hold dumbbells above your chest. 2. Slowly lower weights until your triceps lightly touch the floor. 3. Powerfully press the weights back up to the start.
Safety Cue: Keep your upper arms close to your sides. Press your low back flat into the floor to maintain core stability.

Goals: Increase overall strength
Contraindications: Acute shoulder instability, chronic sternum/rib pain
Steps to Perform: 1. Sit in machine, adjust seat so shoulders are level with handles/pads. 2. Press handles/pads together in front of your chest, squeezing chest muscles. 3. Slowly return the arms to the open position with control.
Safety Cue: Do not let the weight stack touch between reps. Maintain tension and a slight bend in the elbows.

Goals: Increase overall strength, Improve Posture and Balance
Contraindications: Acute back pain, unhealed abdominal separation
Steps to Perform: 1. Lie on back, lift knees to 90 degrees (shins parallel to floor). 2. Press your hands against your thighs and simultaneously push your thighs back against your hands. 3. Hold this isometric contraction, focusing on deep core engagement.
Safety Cue: Ensure your back remains pressed flat against the mat. Do not let your hands or knees win the push-pull.

Goals: Improve Posture and Balance, Rehabilitation & Injury prevention
Contraindications: Acute ankle sprain, severe vertigo
Steps to Perform: 1. Stand near a support. Place one foot on a folded towel, cushion, or balance disc. 2. Slowly lift the other foot and maintain balance on the unstable surface. 3. Hold for time, then switch legs.
Safety Cue: Gaze at a fixed point in front of you. Focus on tiny, continuous muscle adjustments to stay upright.

Goals: Reduce Stress, Improve Oxygen Efficiency
Contraindications: Unmanaged anxiety or panic attacks (consult physician)
Steps to Perform: 1. Sit tall in a chair, feet flat on the floor, hands resting in your lap. 2. Close eyes or soften gaze. Inhale deeply through the nose, filling the belly and chest. 3. Exhale slowly and completely through the mouth, emptying the lungs fully.
Safety Cue: Relax your shoulders. Let your breath be audible and smooth, focusing on making the exhale slightly longer than the inhale.

Goals: Reduce Stress, Improve Focus
Contraindications: Unmanaged high blood pressure, pregnancy, hernia, recent abdominal surgery
Steps to Perform: 1. Sit tall. Take a deep inhale. 2. Exhale forcefully through the nose, drawing the belly sharply inward (like an abdominal pump). 3. The inhale is passive. Continue the sharp, active exhales for 20-30 cycles, then rest.
Safety Cue: Keep your face and shoulders relaxed; the action comes solely from the lower abdomen. Stop if you feel dizzy.

Goals: Increase overall strength, Improve Flexibility & Mobility
Contraindications: Acute shoulder injury, unhealed neck injury
Steps to Perform: 1. Start on hands and knees. Lower onto forearms, clasp hands or keep them parallel. 2. Tuck toes, lift hips high and walk feet in (like Downward Dog on forearms). 3. Press forearms down, lift shoulders away from ears, and hold, pulling the core inward.
Safety Cue: Keep your neck long and your head lifted slightly off the floor; do not let your head hang or rest on the mat.

Goals: Increase overall strength, Improve Posture and Balance
Contraindications: Acute back pain, neck strain (support head)
Steps to Perform: 1. Lie on back, bring legs straight up. 2. Lift head, neck, and shoulders off the mat. Lower straight legs to about 30 degrees (without back arching). 3. Extend arms forward or overhead and hold the position.
Safety Cue: Press the entire lower back firmly into the floor. If it lifts, raise your legs higher until the back flattens.

Goals: Improve Flexibility & Mobility, Reduce Stress
Contraindications: Acute SI joint pain, unhealed hip injury
Steps to Perform: 1. Lie on back, knees bent, feet wide (to edges of mat), arms out to sides. 2. Slowly drop both knees together to one side (like a car's wiper). 3. Return to center and slowly drop them to the other side.
Safety Cue: Keep your upper back and shoulders relaxed on the mat. Move slowly within a comfortable range.

Goals: Improve Flexibility & Mobility, Improve Posture and Balance
Contraindications: Acute knee injury, low blood pressure
Steps to Perform: 1. Stand with feet wide, turn one foot out 90 degrees. Hinge hips over the front leg. 2. Lower hand to shin, ankle, or a block. Extend the top arm straight up to the ceiling. 3. Look up at the top hand, creating a straight line from the heel of the back foot to the top hand.
Safety Cue: Focus on length, not depth. The body should be flat against an imaginary wall; avoid collapsing forward.

Goals: Rehabilitation & Injury prevention, Improve Focus
Contraindications: Recent abdominal/pelvic floor surgery (check protocol)
Steps to Perform: 1. Lie on back, knees bent. Place one hand on belly. 2. Inhale: breathe into the belly/ribs (360 degrees expansion). 3. Exhale: gently contract pelvic floor and deep abdominals (zipper from pubic bone to navel).
Safety Cue: Keep the chest still; the primary movement should be in the lower ribs, belly, and sides.

Goals: Increase overall strength, Improve Flexibility & Mobility
Contraindications: Acute back injury, severe shoulder/wrist pain
Steps to Perform: 1. Start in a forearm plank position. 2. Keeping the core tight, slowly dip the right hip toward the floor (without touching). 3. Return to center and slowly dip the left hip. Continue alternating.
Safety Cue: Control the twist; avoid letting your hips rise up too high. Keep shoulders stable over elbows.

Goals: Improve Flexibility & Mobility, Reduce Stress
Contraindications: Acute lumbar disc injury, severe sciatica
Steps to Perform: 1. Sit with legs extended, feet flexed. Inhale and lengthen the spine. 2. Exhale and hinge forward from the hips, reaching for shins, ankles, or feet (use a strap if needed). 3. Relax the neck and breathe deeply into the back of the body.
Safety Cue: Keep the spine long; avoid rounding the upper back aggressively. Focus on the hip hinge.

Goals: Rehabilitation & Injury prevention, Increase overall strength
Contraindications: Acute SI joint pain, severe hip arthritis
Steps to Perform: 1. Start on hands and knees (tabletop). 2. Keeping the knee bent, slowly lift one knee out to the side (like a dog lifting its leg). 3. Lower the knee slowly and repeat. Ensure hips remain level.
Safety Cue: Avoid leaning into the opposite hip to lift the leg higher; keep the hips square to the floor.

Goals: Improve Flexibility & Mobility, Reduce Stress
Contraindications: Recent abdominal surgery, unhealed rib fracture
Health Benefit: Gentle Low Back Release & Hip Stretch
Steps to Perform: 1. Lie on back, knees bent, feet flat. 2. Gently draw one knee in toward the chest, clasping hands around the shin or behind the thigh. 3. Hold and breathe deeply, allowing the lower back to fully relax into the mat.
Safety Cue: Keep the opposite leg either bent or straight, whichever feels most comfortable for your low back.

Goals: Improve Posture and Balance, Increase overall strength
Contraindications: Acute knee/ankle injury, severe vertigo
Steps to Perform: 1. Start in a high lunge. Shift weight to the front foot. 2. Press through the standing foot, lifting the back leg until the torso and leg are parallel to the floor (forming a 'T'). 3. Extend arms forward and hold the balance.
Safety Cue: Keep the lifted hip facing down (square to the floor). Look at a fixed point to maintain balance.

Goals: Improve Flexibility & Mobility, Rehabilitation & Injury prevention
Contraindications: Acute wrist pain (use fists or modify), unhealed spinal fracture
Steps to Perform: 1. Start on hands and knees. Inhale: drop the belly, lift the chest and tailbone (Cow). 2. Exhale: round the spine toward the ceiling, tucking the chin and tailbone (Cat). 3. Flow smoothly between the two poses, linking movement to breath.
Safety Cue: Move slowly and deliberately. Synchronize the full inhale with Cow and the full exhale with Cat.

Goals: Reduce Stress, Improve Focus
Contraindications: Severe congestion (modify), acute asthma attack
Steps to Perform: 1. Sit comfortably. Place right thumb on right nostril, right ring finger on left nostril. 2. Close right, inhale left. Close left, exhale right. 3. Inhale right. Close right, exhale left. Continue alternating.
Safety Cue: The breath should be slow, quiet, and effortless. Do not force the breath or hold too long.

Goals: Rehabilitation & Injury prevention, Increase overall strength
Contraindications: Acute back pain, hip flexor tendonitis
Steps to Perform: 1. Lie on back, knees bent 90 degrees (shins parallel to floor). Back pressed flat. 2. Slowly lower one heel to tap the floor, maintaining the 90-degree knee bend. 3. Pull the leg back up using the core. Alternate sides.
Safety Cue: Do not let your lower back arch as the foot lowers. If it arches, stop the tap higher up.

Exercise Name: Yoga: Reclined Bound Angle Pose (Supta Baddha Konasana)
Goals: Reduce Stress, Improve Flexibility & Mobility
Contraindications: Acute groin tear, low back pain (use support)
Steps to Perform: 1. Lie on back. Bring the soles of your feet together, letting knees fall open wide. 2. Place blocks or pillows under each knee for support. 3. Rest arms out to the sides, palms up, and breathe deeply.
Safety Cue: Ensure there is no strain in the hips or groin; use enough support under the knees.

Goals: Increase overall strength, Improve cardiovascular fitness
Contraindications: Acute shoulder injury, unstable neck
Health Benefit: Explosive Core Power & Arm Balance Prep
Steps to Perform: 1. Start in Dolphin Pose (forearms down, hips up). 2. Gaze slightly forward. Gently and repeatedly kick one leg up and back toward the ceiling. 3. Maintain core control and switch legs.
Safety Cue: Keep forearms pressing down and avoid letting the shoulders collapse toward the floor.

Goals: Improve Posture and Balance, Rehabilitation & Injury prevention
Contraindications: Acute wrist pain, shoulder surgery history
Steps to Perform: 1. Sit tall in a chair, scoot forward slightly. Place hands on the sides of the seat. 2. Gently push through your hands, slightly lifting your chest and arching your upper back. 3. Squeeze shoulder blades together. Do not lift hips off the seat.
Safety Cue: Maintain control and keep the movement focused on opening the chest and activating the upper back.

Goals: Increase overall strength, Improve Focus
Contraindications: Acute wrist injury, unstable high blood pressure
Steps to Perform: 1. Start in a squat. Place hands flat, shoulder-width apart. 2. Place knees high on the back of the upper arms/triceps. 3. Shift weight forward, gazing slightly ahead. Gently lift one foot, then the other, balancing on the hands.
Safety Cue: Protect the wrists by pressing strongly into the fingertips and engaging the core. Use a cushion in front of your face!

Goals: Improve Flexibility & Mobility, Reduce Stress
Contraindications: Acute shoulder impingement, recent knee surgery
Steps to Perform: 1. Start on hands and knees (tabletop). 2. Slide one arm underneath the opposite armpit, palm facing up. 3. Rest the shoulder and head on the floor, gently pressing the working arm into the floor for a deeper twist.
Safety Cue: Keep your hips lifted and stacked over the knees. Avoid shifting the weight drastically backward.

Goals: Reduce Stress, Improve Focus
Contraindications: Any discomfort (use props for support)
Steps to Perform: 1. Lie flat on your back, arms slightly away from the body, palms up. Legs fall open naturally. 2. Close eyes. Take a deep sigh. Allow the body to be completely still and heavy. 3. Focus on letting go of control of the breath and simply observing.
Safety Cue: Use a pillow under your knees or a blanket over your eyes for maximum comfort and relaxation.

Goals: Improve Posture and Balance, Increase overall strength
Contraindications: Acute shoulder pain, rotator cuff tear
Steps to Perform: 1. Stand, hold light dumbbells, hinge at hips with flat back. Arms hang under chest. 2. Keeping a slight bend in elbows, raise arms out to the sides (like a reverse fly). 3. Squeeze shoulder blades together at the top. Slowly lower back down.
Safety Cue: Keep your back flat and avoid rounding. Use light weight, focusing on the squeeze in the upper back.

Goals: Rehabilitation & Injury prevention, Increase overall strength
Contraindications: Acute back flare-up, unhealed rib fracture
Steps to Perform: 1. Lie face down, arms extended overhead, legs straight. 2. Simultaneously lift arms, chest, and legs a few inches off the floor. 3. Hold briefly, squeezing the glutes and lower back. Slowly lower back down.
Safety Cue: Keep your neck neutral (gaze down). The lift should be small and controlled to avoid hyperextending the low back.

Goals: Improve cardiovascular fitness, Increase overall strength
Contraindications: Acute wrist pain, unhealed abdominal hernia
Steps to Perform: 1. Start in a high plank position (hands under shoulders). 2. Slowly bring one knee toward the chest, maintaining a flat back. 3. Return the foot to the plank position and switch legs, moving with control.
Safety Cue: Keep your hips low and avoid letting the hips jump up and down. Maintain a rigid plank torso.

Goals: Increase overall strength
Contraindications: Acute wrist or elbow pain, tennis elbow
Steps to Perform: 1. Sit facing the cable machine (high pulley), grip the bar/rope, elbows tucked at sides. 2. Press the bar/rope down toward the floor, fully straightening the arms and squeezing the triceps. 3. Slowly let the bar/rope return to the start, controlling the weight.
Safety Cue: Keep elbows pinned to your sides. Avoid leaning your body weight into the movement; isolate the triceps.

Goals: Improve Flexibility & Mobility, Posture
Contraindications: Acute knee pain, recent hip/knee surgery
Steps to Perform: 1. Kneel facing a wall (or couch). Place the top of one foot high up the wall. 2. Step the opposite foot forward into a deep lunge position. 3. Gently push your hips forward and tuck your tailbone until a deep stretch is felt in the front of the back thigh/hip.
Safety Cue: Use a thick pad under the kneeling knee. Avoid arching your lower back; focus on tucking the pelvis.

Goals: Increase overall strength
Contraindications: Acute neck pain, cervical spine injury
Steps to Perform: 1. Stand tall, holding heavy dumbbells at your sides. 2. Shrug your shoulders straight up toward your ears as high as possible. 3. Hold the squeeze briefly, then slowly lower the weights back to the start.
Safety Cue: Roll your shoulders up and down (not forward or backward) in a straight line for maximum benefit and safety.

Goals: Improve Flexibility & Mobility, Increase overall strength
Contraindications: Acute neck injury, pregnancy (modify)
Steps to Perform: 1. Lie on your back, knees bent, feet flat, arms at sides. 2. Press through your feet and arms, lifting the hips off the floor. 3. Clasp hands underneath the back or keep arms flat. Press chest toward chin.
Safety Cue: Keep your neck long and avoid turning your head while in the pose. Press through all four corners of your feet.

Goals: Improve Posture and Balance, Rehabilitation & Injury prevention
Contraindications: Acute shoulder pain, biceps tendonitis
Steps to Perform: 1. Attach a band to a sturdy anchor at face height. Grip the ends, palms facing down or neutral. 2. Pull the band toward your face, driving the elbows back and squeezing the shoulder blades together. 3. Finish with hands near ears and forearms pointing up. Slowly extend arms.
Safety Cue: Pull with your upper back and rear shoulders, not your biceps. Try to externally rotate your shoulders as you pull.

Goals: Increase overall strength, Rehabilitation & Injury prevention
Contraindications: Acute wrist pain, severe dizziness/balance issues
Steps to Perform: 1. Stand facing a wall, place hands slightly wider than shoulders on the wall. 2. Step feet back until body is in a slight incline (the steeper the angle, the harder it is). 3. Lower chest toward the wall by bending elbows, then push back strongly.
Safety Cue: Keep your body straight from head to heels. The angle determines the intensity—start shallow if needed.

Goals: Improve Flexibility & Mobility, Rehabilitation & Injury prevention
Contraindications: Acute low back pain, unhealed spinal fracture
Steps to Perform: 1. Sit on the edge of a chair, feet flat and wide. Place hands on your hips or across your chest. 2. Maintain a flat back. Gently hinge forward at the hips, leading with the chest. 3. Use your glutes/low back muscles to return to an upright seated position.
Safety Cue: Only hinge as far as comfortable while maintaining a flat, neutral spine. The movement is small.

Goals: Improve cardiovascular fitness, Increase overall strength
Contraindications: Acute shoulder/elbow injury, severe unmanaged heart condition
Steps to Perform: 1. Stand in a quarter-squat, holding ropes, facing the anchor point. 2. Quickly alternate moving each arm up and down to create continuous waves traveling down the rope. 3. Maintain continuous, powerful motion, driving power from the core and hips.
Safety Cue: Keep your chest up and stay in the athletic (quarter-squat) stance throughout the set.

Goals: Improve Flexibility & Mobility, Improve Posture and Balance
Contraindications: Acute knee pain, severe ankle instability
Steps to Perform: 1. Start in a lunge (front knee stacked over ankle). 2. Ensure the back leg is straight and heel is lifted. Raise arms overhead. 3. Sink hips low, maintaining core engagement and a long spine.
Safety Cue: Squeeze the glute of the back leg to deepen the hip flexor stretch and stabilize the pelvis.

Goals: Increase overall strength, Stability
Contraindications: Acute spinal disc injury, unhealed hernia
Steps to Perform: 1. Sit on the mat, knees bent, feet slightly off the floor (or resting lightly). Hold a dumbbell at your chest. 2. Keeping the core braced, slowly rotate the torso and touch the dumbbell to the floor beside your hip. 3. Rotate back to the center and switch sides, maintaining a controlled speed.
Safety Cue: Keep your back straight (avoid rounding). The rotation should come from the torso, not just swinging the arms.

Goals: Increase overall strength, Rehabilitation & Injury prevention
Contraindications: Acute shoulder pain, low back pain
Steps to Perform: 1. Sit on a bench/chair. Lean forward, supporting with one hand on the knee. Hold a dumbbell in the opposite hand. 2. Pull the weight to the chest, squeezing the shoulder blade toward the spine. 3. Slowly lower the weight back down with control.
Safety Cue: Maintain a flat back throughout the movement. Focus on pulling the elbow, not just the wrist.

Goals: Rehabilitation & Injury prevention, Improve Posture and Balance
Contraindications: Acute wrist pain (use fists), severe shoulder instability
Steps to Perform: 1. Start on hands and knees (tabletop). 2. Slowly extend one arm straight forward to ear height, keeping hips and torso perfectly still. 3. Lower the arm back down with control. Alternate arms.
Safety Cue: Avoid letting your torso shift or rotate as you lift the arm. Keep your gaze down to protect the neck.

Goals: Improve Flexibility & Mobility, Rehabilitation & Injury prevention
Contraindications: Acute hip joint pain, severe balance issues (use support)
Health Benefit: Hip Capsule Lubrication & Range of Motion
Steps to Perform: 1. Stand near a wall for support, balancing on one leg. 2. Lift the opposite knee up and draw a large, slow circle with the knee, moving the hip. 3. Complete all reps in one direction, then reverse the direction, and switch legs.
Safety Cue: Keep the standing knee slightly soft. Focus on slow, controlled, full circles in the hip joint.

Goals: Increase overall strength, Improve cardiovascular fitness
Contraindications: Acute knee pain, unmanaged high blood pressure
Steps to Perform: 1. Adjust the resistance to a challenging level that forces you to push with effort on each stroke. 2. Maintain a seated position. Pedal at a slower, forceful pace (e.g., 60-80 RPM). 3. Focus on pushing through the heels and engaging the glutes/hamstrings.
Safety Cue: Ensure seat height is correct (slight knee bend at bottom). Keep your core engaged to prevent rocking.

Goals: Increase overall strength
Contraindications: Acute shoulder or wrist pain, unhealed chest injury
Steps to Perform: 1. Loop a long resistance band across your upper back, gripping the ends under your hands. 2. Get into a standard plank position (band adds resistance against gravity). 3. Perform a standard push-up, fighting against the band tension on the way up.
Safety Cue: Keep your body in a straight line (rigid plank). Ensure the band is secure and won't snap up at the end of the movement.

Goals: Improve Flexibility & Mobility, Posture
Contraindications: Acute spinal disc injury, severe shoulder impingement
Steps to Perform: 1. Stand with feet wide, turn one foot out 90 degrees. Extend arms out wide (like a T). 2. Hinge at the hip, sliding the hand down the inside of the front leg (or reach for a toe/block). 3. Extend the opposite arm toward the ceiling, keeping a flat back and looking toward the top hand.
Safety Cue: Keep the spine long and straight (flat back); the movement is a side-body hinge, not a rounding forward.

Goals: Improve Focus, Reduce Stress
Contraindications: Severe congestion, unmanaged respiratory condition
Steps to Perform: 1. Choose a low-to-moderate intensity cardio activity (e.g., walking, slow jog, bike). 2. Maintain the activity for 10-20 minutes, only breathing through the nose (both inhale and exhale). 3. If you must open your mouth, reduce the intensity immediately.
Safety Cue: Keep the intensity low enough that you can comfortably sustain nasal breathing without gasping for air.

Goals: Increase overall strength, Improve Flexibility & Mobility
Contraindications: Acute knee pain, severe ankle instability
Steps to Perform: 1. Place the top of one foot on a bench behind you. Hold dumbbells at sides. 2. Lower into a lunge, dropping the back knee toward the floor. Maintain upright torso. 3. Drive through the front heel to return to the starting position.
Safety Cue: Ensure the front knee tracks over the ankle. The majority of the load should be on the front leg.

Goals: Increase overall strength, Rehabilitation & Injury prevention
Contraindications: Acute knee pain, recent hip replacement
Steps to Perform: 1. Stand holding the handles, step back so the straps are taut. 2. Squat down deeply, keeping chest up and leaning back slightly to use the straps for support. 3. Press through the heels to stand, pulling on the straps as needed.
Safety Cue: Maintain control of the descent and ascent. Use the straps only to assist balance, not to pull yourself up.

Goals: Rehabilitation & Injury prevention, Improve Posture and Balance
Contraindications: Acute wrist pain (use fists), severe SI joint pain
Steps to Perform: 1. Start in a tabletop position (hands and knees). 2. Simultaneously lift and extend the opposite arm and leg straight out (like Bird Dog). 3. Draw the elbow and knee back in to gently tap underneath the torso. Extend and repeat.
Safety Cue: Move slowly and with precision. Avoid letting the torso rock or shift as the limbs move.

Goals: Improve Posture and Balance, Increase overall strength
Contraindications: Acute shoulder impingement, unhealed sternum fracture
Steps to Perform: 1. Lie face down on an incline bench, chest supported. Hold dumbbells underneath. 2. Pull the weights up toward the chest, squeezing the shoulder blades together. 3. Slowly lower the weights back to the start.
Safety Cue: Keep your head neutral and focus entirely on pulling with the back muscles, not shrugging with the neck.

Goals: Improve Flexibility & Mobility, Reduce Stress
Contraindications: Acute knee pain, recent hip replacement (consult doc)
Steps to Perform: 1. Sit with one knee bent forward, the other leg extended straight back. 2. Place a cushion or folded blanket under the bent hip for support. 3. Rest forearms down or stay upright. Breathe into the outer hip/glute stretch.
Safety Cue: The bent knee must feel comfortable. If there is any sharp knee pain, stop the stretch immediately.

Goals: Increase overall strength, Improve cardiovascular fitness
Contraindications: Acute knee/ankle pain, severe balance issues
Steps to Perform: 1. Stand on one leg. Lower slightly into a quarter-squat. 2. Explode sideways, jumping as far as possible, landing softly on the opposite leg. 3. Immediately stabilize the landing before repeating the jump back in the opposite direction.
Safety Cue: Land softly and absorb the impact through the hip and knee. Maintain control; stability is key.

Goals: Increase overall strength
Contraindications: Acute knee/ankle pain, unmanaged heart condition
Steps to Perform: 1. Sit on a sturdy box/bench (start height: below knee level). Feet flat. 2. Explosively jump forward onto a low target box, landing softly and standing up tall. 3. Step back down to the starting seated position.
Safety Cue: Do not pause or rock at the bottom; explode immediately from the seated position. Ensure boxes are stable.

Goals: Increase overall strength, Rehabilitation & Injury prevention
Contraindications: Acute shoulder pain, recent hip surgery
Steps to Perform: 1. Start in a forearm side plank (body in a straight line). 2. Keeping the core tight and hips lifted, slowly raise the top leg toward the ceiling. 3. Slowly lower the top leg back down without letting the hips sag.
Safety Cue: Keep your hips pressed forward and stacked. Avoid letting your torso twist or lean backward.

Goals: Increase overall strength, Improve Posture and Balance
Contraindications: Acute elbow or wrist pain, severe low back instability
Steps to Perform: 1. Sit at the end of a bench, hold dumbbells with palms facing each other (neutral grip). 2. Hinge forward slightly. Pull the weights to your chest, squeezing shoulder blades together. 3. Slowly lower the weights back to the start.
Safety Cue: Keep your chest tall and back flat. The neutral grip can be easier on the shoulder capsule.

Goals: Improve Posture and Balance, Improve Flexibility & Mobility
Contraindications: Acute knee/ankle injury, severe dizziness
Steps to Perform: 1. Stand tall. Wrap one leg tightly over the other, hooking the foot around the opposite calf. 2. Wrap the arms (opposite arm on top) and bring palms together or grab shoulders. 3. Squat down slightly and hold, keeping the core engaged.
Safety Cue: Find a fixed point to gaze at. Gently squat low to deepen the hip and shoulder stretch.

Goals: Improve Flexibility & Mobility, Rehabilitation & Injury prevention
Contraindications: Acute hamstring tear, knee ligament injury
Steps to Perform: 1. Lie on back, legs extended. Loop a strap/towel around the ball of one foot. 2. Gently pull the strap, drawing the leg toward your head until a deep stretch is felt in the hamstring. 3. Keep the opposite leg straight and grounded.
Safety Cue: Keep your lower back flat on the mat and breathe deeply into the stretch. A slight bend in the knee is okay.

Goals: Increase overall strength
Contraindications: Acute spinal disc injury, unhealed hernia
Steps to Perform: 1. Kneel facing the high pulley, gripping the rope attachment by your ears/neck. 2. Curl your torso down toward your thighs, squeezing the abs tightly. 3. Slowly uncurl the torso back to the starting kneeling position, resisting the weight.
Safety Cue: The movement is only a spinal curl, not a hip hinge. Keep the hips stationary and focus the effort on the abs.

Goals: Improve cardiovascular fitness, Rehabilitation & Injury prevention
Contraindications: Acute hip/knee pain, severe balance issues
Steps to Perform: 1. Sit upright near the edge of a chair, feet flat on the floor. 2. Alternately lift one knee toward the chest, simulating a slow marching motion. 3. Maintain a consistent, steady pace.
Safety Cue: Keep your back straight and avoid rocking side-to-side. Use your hands on the chair arms for support if needed.

Goals: Increase overall strength
Contraindications: Acute shoulder instability, severe grip weakness
Steps to Perform: 1. Hang from a pull-up bar with an overhand grip. 2. Keeping core tight, lift both knees straight up toward the chest/ribcage. 3. Slowly lower the legs back down, maintaining control and avoiding swinging.
Safety Cue: Avoid swinging your body (kipping). The movement should be controlled by the core through the entire range.

Goals: Improve Flexibility & Mobility, Reduce Stress
Contraindications: Acute spinal disc injury, severe scoliosis
Steps to Perform: 1. Sit cross-legged (or on a chair) with a tall spine. 2. Raise one arm overhead. Gently lean the torso straight over to the opposite side. 3. Breathe into the ribs and side of the torso, reaching the arm long. Slowly return and switch.
Safety Cue: Ground both sit bones evenly. The movement is a gentle lift and lean, not a rounding forward.

Exercise Name: Wall Sit with Alternating Heel Raise
Goals: Increase overall strength, Rehabilitation & Injury prevention
Contraindications: Acute knee pain, recent Achilles tendon repair
Steps to Perform: 1. Get into a standard Wall Sit position (90-degree knees). 2. While holding the squat, slowly lift one heel off the floor (calf raise). 3. Lower the heel and switch sides, maintaining the squat depth throughout.
Safety Cue: Keep your back flat against the wall and avoid letting your hips shift side-to-side during the heel lift.

Goals: Increase overall strength, Improve Flexibility & Mobility
Contraindications: Acute shoulder impingement, lower back pain
Steps to Perform: 1. Lie perpendicular across a bench, supporting shoulders and head, feet flat. Hold one dumbbell with both hands over your chest. 2. Slowly lower the dumbbell in an arc behind your head, stretching the chest and lats. 3. Pull the dumbbell back over your chest, finishing with lats/chest tension.
Safety Cue: Keep a slight bend in the elbows throughout the movement. Brace your core to prevent excessive arching of the low back.

Goals: Increase overall strength, Rehabilitation & Injury prevention
Contraindications: Acute knee swelling, unhealed hamstring tear
Steps to Perform: 1. Sit tall in a chair. Loop a resistance band around one ankle and a sturdy chair leg/anchor. 2. Slowly bend the knee, pulling the ankle backward, squeezing the hamstring against the band resistance. 3. Slowly release and allow the leg to return to the start.
Safety Cue: Sit completely upright and avoid leaning forward or using your hands to pull the leg. Focus on the back of the thigh.

Goals: Improve cardiovascular fitness, Balance
Contraindications: Acute hip flexor pain, severe sciatica
Steps to Perform: 1. Stand tall. Shift weight to one foot. 2. Swing the opposite leg forward, performing a controlled, low-to-mid-level kick. 3. Bring the foot back down and immediately switch legs, maintaining a rhythmic pace.
Safety Cue: Keep your core tight and minimize upper body sway. The kick height should be comfortable and controlled.

Exercise Name: Yoga: Downward Dog Split (Tri Pada Adho Mukha Svanasana)
Goals: Improve Flexibility & Mobility, Increase overall strength
Contraindications: Acute shoulder injury, unhealed hamstring tear
Steps to Perform: 1. Start in Downward Facing Dog. 2. Lift one leg straight up and back toward the ceiling, keeping the foot flexed. 3. Keep the hips level (or open slightly for stretch), pressing through both hands equally. Hold and switch.
Safety Cue: Press firmly through your hands, keeping the shoulders engaged. Do not collapse into the shoulders to lift the leg higher.

Goals: Improve Flexibility & Mobility, Posture
Contraindications: Acute shoulder pain, spinal fusion (check with doctor)
Steps to Perform: 1. Start on hands and knees. Place one hand behind your head. 2. Draw the elbow down toward the floor near the opposite wrist. 3. Rotate and open the elbow up toward the ceiling, looking up slightly. Slowly return and repeat.
Safety Cue: Keep your hips steady and centered over your knees. The rotation should come from the upper/mid-back.

Goals: Increase overall strength, Rehabilitation & Injury prevention
Contraindications: Acute knee pain, recent hip surgery
Steps to Perform: 1. Hold one dumbbell vertically against your chest (goblet style). Stand in front of a chair/box. 2. Squat down slowly, reaching the hips back until you lightly tap the chair. 3. Drive through the heels and squeeze the glutes to stand back up.
Safety Cue: Maintain an upright chest and keep the dumbbell pressed firmly against your body. Tap the chair gently; don't rest.

Goals: Improve Posture and Balance, Rehabilitation & Injury prevention
Contraindications: Acute shoulder impingement, shoulder instability
Steps to Perform: 1. Hold a band with both hands, arms extended straight out in front of the chest, palms facing each other. 2. Pull the band apart, driving the hands outward until they reach the sides of the chest. 3. Squeeze the shoulder blades together briefly. Slowly return to the start.
Safety Cue: Keep your arms straight (no bend in the elbows) and avoid shrugging your shoulders toward your ears.

Goals: Improve Posture and Balance, Rehabilitation & Injury prevention
Contraindications: Severe dizziness, acute ankle sprain
Steps to Perform: 1. Stand near a sturdy object (wall or chair) for light support. 2. Lift one foot slightly off the ground (only a few inches). 3. Maintain balance, using minimal contact with the support object.
Safety Cue: Keep your standing knee soft (not locked). Focus your gaze on a non-moving point in front of you.

Goals: Increase overall strength, Rehabilitation & Injury prevention
Contraindications: Acute Achilles pain, recent ankle surgery
Steps to Perform: 1. Sit on a bench, feet flat, balls of feet resting on a step/block. Place a dumbbell on each knee. 2. Slowly push up onto the balls of your feet, raising the heels as high as possible. 3. Slowly lower the heels back down to stretch the calf muscles.
Safety Cue: Ensure the step is secure and cannot tip. Control the lowering phase completely.

Goals: Increase overall strength, Improve Posture and Balance
Contraindications: Acute wrist pain (use fists), severe shoulder instability
