Steps to Perform: 1. Sit with knees bent, feet flat, hands shoulder-width apart behind hips, fingers pointing forward. 2. Press through hands and feet, lifting hips off the floor until torso and thighs form a straight line. 3. Hold, squeezing glutes and engaging the core.
Safety Cue: Keep your neck neutral (gaze slightly up or straight ahead). Focus on driving the hips high.

Goals: Increase overall strength, Rehabilitation & Injury prevention
Contraindications: Acute shoulder instability, unhealed sternum fracture
Steps to Perform: 1. Loop a band around an anchor behind you (at chest height). Face away from the anchor. 2. Hold the band handle in one hand, starting with elbow bent. Stand in a slight athletic stance. 3. Press the hand straight forward, fighting the band trying to pull you into rotation. Slowly resist back.
Safety Cue: Brace your core and hips to remain perfectly square to the front. Avoid letting your torso twist.

Goals: Rehabilitation & Injury prevention, Increase overall strength
Contraindications: Acute knee pain, severe sciatica
Steps to Perform: 1. Sit upright near the edge of a chair, feet flat. 2. Straighten one knee, lifting the foot a few inches off the floor. Contract the thigh muscles. 3. Hold for 1 second, then slowly lower the foot back down. Repeat on the same side.
Safety Cue: Sit completely upright and avoid leaning back to assist the leg lift. Keep the movement small and controlled.

Goals: Increase overall strength
Contraindications: Acute low back pain, unhealed spinal disc injury
Steps to Perform: 1. Stand holding dumbbells in front of thighs. Keep knees slightly soft (not locked). 2. Hinge at the hips, pushing the glutes back, allowing the weights to slide down the legs. 3. Stop when you feel a stretch in the hamstrings (mid-shin height). Squeeze glutes to stand up.
Safety Cue: Maintain a flat, neutral spine throughout the movement. Focus on the hip hinge, not rounding the back.

Goals: Improve Flexibility & Mobility, Reduce Stress
Contraindications: Acute knee pain, recent hip surgery
Steps to Perform: 1. Start in a half-kneeling position (one foot forward). Use a pad under the back knee. 2. Tuck the tailbone strongly forward and squeeze the glute of the back leg. 3. Gently lean back the torso slightly. Hold the intense stretch in the front of the back hip.
Safety Cue: Avoid excessive arching of the lower back; the tuck of the pelvis is crucial to target the deep psoas muscle.

Goals: Rehabilitation & Injury prevention, Stability
Contraindications: Acute spinal disc injury, unhealed abdominal separation
Steps to Perform: 1. Lie on back, knees bent 90 degrees over hips, arms straight up. Press low back flat. 2. Slowly extend one arm back overhead and the opposite leg straight forward, just above the floor. 3. Slowly return to the start and switch sides, maintaining constant low back contact.
Safety Cue: Do not let your lower back arch. If the arch lifts, reduce the range of motion of the arm and/or leg.

Goals: Increase overall strength
Contraindications: Acute shoulder instability, acute low back pain
Steps to Perform: 1. Sit upright on a bench with back support. Hold dumbbells racked at shoulder height. 2. Press the dumbbells straight overhead until arms are fully extended. 3. Slowly lower the weights back to the start.
Safety Cue: Keep your core braced and back pressed against the support to prevent excessive arching of the spine.

Goals: Rehabilitation & Injury prevention, Improve Flexibility & Mobility
Contraindications: Acute knee pain, recent hip/knee surgery (check protocol)
Health Benefit: Gentle Knee & Hip Range of Motion
Steps to Perform: 1. Lie on your back, legs straight. 2. Keeping the heel on the floor, slowly slide one heel toward the glute, bending the knee. 3. Slowly slide the heel back out until the leg is straight. Repeat on the same side.
Safety Cue: Move slowly and only within a pain-free range of motion. Keep the opposite leg still and grounded.

Goals: Rehabilitation & Injury prevention, Improve Posture and Balance
Contraindications: Acute shoulder instability, biceps tendonitis
Steps to Perform: 1. Lie on your side, elbow bent 90 degrees, upper arm resting on torso. Loop a mini-band around forearms/wrists. 2. Keeping the elbow glued to your side, slowly rotate the top forearm upward against the band. 3. Slowly control the forearm back to the starting position.
Safety Cue: Keep your upper arm still and glued to your side. The movement should be small and isolated to the shoulder.

Goals: Increase overall strength
Contraindications: Acute shoulder impingement, acute neck pain
Steps to Perform: 1. Sit on a bench, holding dumbbells at sides. Keep torso upright. 2. Raise the weights out to the sides until they reach shoulder height (like a 'T'). 3. Slowly lower the weights back to the start with control.
Safety Cue: Do not swing or use momentum; use a light weight and focus on the side of the shoulder.

Goals: Reduce Stress, Improve Flexibility & Mobility
Contraindications: Acute knee injury, severe diarrhea
Steps to Perform: 1. Kneel on the floor, bring big toes to touch, and open knees wide (or keep them close). 2. Fold torso forward, letting the forehead rest on the mat (or a block). 3. Extend arms out, or let them rest by your sides, palms up. Breathe deeply and relax.
Safety Cue: If knees feel uncomfortable, place a rolled towel behind the knee joint or sit on a low block.

Goals: Increase overall strength, Improve Posture and Balance
Contraindications: Unmanaged hernia, acute wrist/elbow pain
Steps to Perform: 1. Stand tall, holding a heavy dumbbell/kettlebell in only one hand. 2. Walk slowly and deliberately for the prescribed time/distance. 3. Resist the urge to lean away from the weight; maintain a perfectly straight, upright torso.
Safety Cue: Maintain perfect vertical posture. The goal is to keep the shoulders level and avoid leaning side-to-side.

Goals: Improve Posture and Balance, Improve Flexibility & Mobility
Contraindications: Acute shoulder instability, recent sternum surgery
Steps to Perform: 1. Sit tall in a chair or stand. Interlace hands behind your back. 2. Straighten your arms (or keep them slightly bent) and gently lift the interlaced hands away from your back. 3. Hold the stretch, allowing your chest to open and shoulder blades to draw together.
Safety Cue: Keep your neck relaxed and avoid pushing the stretch so hard that your shoulders rise to your ears.

Goals: Rehabilitation & Injury prevention, Increase overall strength
Contraindications: Acute knee pain, recent hip surgery
Steps to Perform: 1. Place a mini-band around your ankles (or knees). Get into a slight athletic quarter-squat stance. 2. Step sideways (laterally) against the band's tension. Keep feet shoulder-width apart (never let them touch). 3. Complete all steps in one direction, then return in the opposite direction.
Safety Cue: Stay low in the quarter-squat position the entire time. Do not let the band pull your knees inward.

Goals: Improve Flexibility & Mobility, Posture
Contraindications: Acute spinal disc injury, severe osteoporosis
Steps to Perform: 1. Lie on your back, roller perpendicular across your upper/mid-back. Hands behind head for support. 2. Lift hips slightly. Slowly roll the foam roller along the thoracic spine (avoiding the low back). 3. Pause briefly on tight spots and lift hips higher for more pressure.
Safety Cue: Keep your breathing slow and deep. Roll slowly and stop immediately if you feel sharp or shooting pain.

Goals: Increase overall strength, Rehabilitation & Injury prevention
Contraindications: Acute wrist pain, severe shoulder impingement
Steps to Perform: 1. Place hands slightly wider than shoulders on an elevated surface (bench or wall). 2. Step feet back so your body forms a straight line. 3. Lower your chest toward the bench by bending your elbows. 4. Push back up forcefully, maintaining the straight body line.
Safety Cue: Keep your core tight to prevent your hips from sagging or lifting. The higher the incline, the easier the movement.

Goals: Increase overall strength, Rehabilitation & Injury prevention
Contraindications: Acute low back pain, unhealed abdominal hernia
Steps to Perform: 1. Loop a band around your neck/upper back and anchor the bottom ends under your feet. 2. Stand with feet hip-width apart, knees slightly soft. Maintain a flat back. 3. Hinge forward at the hips, pushing glutes back until a hamstring stretch is felt. 4. Drive hips forward, squeezing glutes to return to standing.
Safety Cue: Do not let your back round. Keep a slight arch in your lower back throughout the hinge movement.

Goals: Increase overall strength, Rehabilitation & Injury prevention
Contraindications: Acute hamstring strain, severe low back pain
Steps to Perform: 1. Lie on your back, place heels on top of the ball, arms out to sides for balance. 2. Lift hips off the floor into a straight line (glute bridge). 3. Slowly curl heels toward your glutes, rolling the ball toward you. 4. Slowly push the ball back out until legs are straight, maintaining hip height.
Safety Cue: Keep your hips lifted the entire time; do not let them drop or sag toward the floor.

Goals: Increase overall strength, Improve Posture and Balance
Contraindications: Acute elbow pain, severe thoracic kyphosis
Steps to Perform: 1. Sit upright, feet braced, holding a neutral grip attachment (palms facing each other). 2. Pull the handle toward your lower abdomen, initiating the pull by squeezing shoulder blades together. 3. Extend arms fully back to the start, controlling the weight stretch.
Safety Cue: Keep your torso stable and avoid excessive rocking backward to use momentum.

Goals: Increase overall strength, Rehabilitation & Injury prevention
Contraindications: Acute knee pain, recent hip surgery
Steps to Perform: 1. Stand in front of a chair/box. Feet hip-width apart. 2. Squat down slowly and deliberately, reaching hips back to lightly touch the seat. 3. Immediately stand back up without resting or pushing off the chair.
Safety Cue: Keep your chest up and ensure your knees track over your feet. Control the descent fully.

Goals: Rehabilitation & Injury prevention, Improve Posture and Balance
Contraindications: Acute wrist pain (use fists), pregnancy (avoid later stages)
Steps to Perform: 1. Start on hands and knees (tabletop). 2. Slowly extend one arm straight forward and the opposite leg straight back, maintaining a neutral spine. 3. Hold briefly, then slowly return the arm and leg to the floor.
Safety Cue: Keep your spine neutral (flat) and avoid letting your hips or torso rotate as the limbs extend.

Goals: Increase overall strength
Contraindications: Acute elbow or wrist pain, biceps tendonitis
Steps to Perform: 1. Stand tall, holding dumbbells at sides, palms facing forward (supinated grip). 2. Curl the weights up toward the shoulders, flexing the biceps strongly at the top. 3. Slowly lower the weights back to the starting position with full control.
Safety Cue: Keep your elbows pinned to your sides throughout the movement. Avoid leaning back or using momentum to lift the weights.

Goals: Improve Flexibility & Mobility, Posture
Contraindications: Acute knee pain, recent hip/knee surgery
Steps to Perform: 1. Stand near a wall or chair for support. Bend one knee and grab the ankle or foot with the same-side hand. 2. Gently pull the heel toward the glute, feeling the stretch in the front of the thigh. 3. Tuck the pelvis slightly forward to enhance the stretch.
Safety Cue: Keep your knee pointed straight toward the floor. Do not allow your knee to wing out to the side.

Goals: Improve Posture and Balance, Rehabilitation & Injury prevention
Contraindications: Acute shoulder impingement, shoulder adhesive capsulitis
Steps to Perform: 1. Stand against a wall. Press your entire back, head, and elbows/forearms flat against the wall. 2. Slowly slide your arms up the wall, keeping forearms and hands in contact, until arms are fully extended overhead (like a 'Y'). 3. Slowly slide them back down to the start.
Safety Cue: Ensure your lower back stays flat against the wall. Only move as high as you can without the elbows or wrists lifting off.

Goals: Rehabilitation & Injury prevention, Increase overall strength
Contraindications: Acute low back pain, unhealed tailbone injury
Steps to Perform: 1. Lie on your back, knees bent, feet flat. Place a mini-band just above your knees. 2. Press out slightly against the band and maintain that tension. 3. Lift hips off the floor, squeezing glutes tightly at the top. 4. Slowly lower hips back down.
Safety Cue: Keep the band tension constant to ensure the knees do not collapse inward during the lift.

Goals: Improve Flexibility & Mobility, Posture
Contraindications: Acute shoulder impingement, lower back pain
Steps to Perform: 1. Lie perpendicular across a bench, supporting shoulders and head, feet flat. Hold one light dumbbell over your chest with straight arms. 2. Slowly lower the dumbbell in an arc behind your head, maintaining straight arms and a slight stretch. 3. Pull the dumbbell back over your chest, squeezing the lats.
Safety Cue: Keep your core tight and avoid excessive arching of the low back as the weight moves overhead.

Goals: Increase overall strength, Improve Flexibility & Mobility
Contraindications: Acute knee pain, unhealed groin strain
Steps to Perform: 1. Stand tall. Step wide to the side with one foot, keeping the toes pointing straight ahead. 2. Bend the knee of the stepping leg, sinking the hips back as you keep the opposite leg straight. 3. Push off the bent leg to return to the standing position.
Safety Cue: Keep the heel grounded on the bent leg. Hinge at the hip, ensuring your back remains flat.

Goals: Increase overall strength
Contraindications: Acute shoulder instability, elbow joint pain
Steps to Perform: 1. Sit upright with back support. Hold one dumbbell with both hands extended overhead. 2. Slowly bend the elbows, lowering the dumbbell behind your head/neck. 3. Extend the arms forcefully back overhead, engaging the triceps.
Safety Cue: Keep your elbows narrow and pointing straight forward. Avoid letting them flare out excessively.

Goals: Improve Flexibility & Mobility, Rehabilitation & Injury prevention
Contraindications: Acute hip joint pain, groin strain
Steps to Perform: 1. Stand near a wall or chair for support. Balance on one leg. 2. Swing the opposite leg forward and backward in a smooth, controlled motion. 3. Maintain an upright torso and only swing as high as comfortable.
Safety Cue: Keep your torso stable and minimize rocking. The speed should be controlled and not jarring.

Goals: Increase overall strength
Contraindications: Acute spinal disc injury, unhealed hernia
Steps to Perform: 1. Lie on your back, knees bent, feet flat. Place hands flat on your thighs. 2. Curl your head and shoulders up, sliding your hands up toward your knees. 3. Contract the abs at the top of the curl. Slowly lower back down.
Safety Cue: Keep the lower back glued to the floor. Avoid yanking your neck; the power comes from the core contraction.

Goals: Increase overall strength
Contraindications: Acute low back pain, unhealed hernia
Steps to Perform: 1. Set the barbell inside a rack so the bar sits just below or above the knee (reduced range). 2. Stand with feet under the bar, hands outside shins. Hinge and grip the bar. 3. Drive through the heels and stand up tall, locking out the hips and back. 4. Slowly lower the bar back to the rack pins.
Safety Cue: Maintain a flat, rigid back throughout the lift. The focus is on the hip drive, not pulling with the arms.

Goals: Improve Posture and Balance, Reduce Stress
Contraindications: Acute shoulder instability, shoulder labral tear
Steps to Perform: 1. Stand in a doorway. Place one forearm flat against the frame (or hand on the frame). 2. Step one foot forward, gently leaning your body forward until a stretch is felt in the chest/front of the shoulder. 3. Breathe deeply and hold the stretch.
Safety Cue: Avoid shrugging your shoulder up toward your ear. The stretch should be felt in the pec, not the joint.

Goals: Increase overall strength
Contraindications: Acute low back pain, inner thigh strain
Steps to Perform: 1. Stand with a wide stance, toes pointed slightly out. Place the KB on the floor between your feet. 2. Squat down and grip the handle. Keep your chest up and back flat. 3. Drive through the heels and stand up, squeezing the glutes. 4. Lower the KB back to the floor with control.
Safety Cue: Keep your chest up and the KB close to your body. Allow your hips to drop low; this is a more upright, quad-friendly hinge.

Goals: Increase overall strength, Improve Posture and Balance
Contraindications: Acute knee pain (use cushion), shoulder instability
Steps to Perform: 1. Kneel with one foot forward (half-kneeling). Hold a dumbbell racked at the shoulder of the same side. 2. Dip the hips slightly (small bounce), then explosively drive the dumbbell overhead. 3. Control the weight back down to the shoulder and reset.
Safety Cue: Keep your core rigid and your glute of the back leg squeezed tight to prevent rocking or arching your low back.

Goals: Rehabilitation & Injury prevention, Improve Flexibility & Mobility
Contraindications: Acute whiplash, severe vertigo
Health Benefit: Gentle Cervical Spine Range of Motion
Steps to Perform: 1. Sit upright with good posture, gazing straight ahead. 2. Slowly turn your head to look over one shoulder, only as far as comfortable (no pain). 3. Slowly return to the center and then turn to the opposite shoulder.
Safety Cue: Move slowly and deliberately. Do not let your shoulders move or elevate as your head turns.

Goals: Increase overall strength, Improve Posture and Balance
Contraindications: Acute wrist pain (use fists), severe shoulder pain
Steps to Perform: 1. Start in a Reverse Tabletop (hips lifted, hands and feet on floor). 2. Maintain a straight torso line. Slowly lift one foot off the floor (a 'march'). 3. Place the foot down and immediately lift the opposite foot. Keep hips stable.
Safety Cue: Keep your hips high and perfectly level throughout the marching motion; avoid letting them drop or tilt.

Goals: Increase overall strength, Rehabilitation & Injury prevention
Contraindications: Acute shoulder instability, recent rotator cuff surgery
Steps to Perform: 1. Lie on the floor, knees bent, feet flat. Hold dumbbells in a neutral grip (palms facing each other). 2. Press the dumbbells straight up to the ceiling until arms are straight. 3. Slowly lower the dumbbells until your upper arms lightly touch the floor. Press and repeat.
Safety Cue: Keep your wrists straight and the back of your arms on the floor at the bottom of the movement to protect the shoulders.

Goals: Improve Posture and Balance, Rehabilitation & Injury prevention
Contraindications: Acute knee pain, severe vertigo
Steps to Perform: 1. Stand on one leg, near a support. Hinge at the hip, letting the torso drop forward. 2. Reach the opposite hand down to tap the toe or floor, keeping the standing knee soft. 3. Squeeze the glute and drive up to the standing position, maintaining balance.
Safety Cue: Move slowly and maintain a flat back. Use the support only for fingertip assistance, if needed.

Goals: Improve Flexibility & Mobility, Posture
Contraindications: Acute shoulder pain, recent neck injury
Steps to Perform: 1. Start on hands and knees. Reach one arm under the torso and across the mat, palm up. 2. Lower the shoulder and side of the head to the floor, twisting the upper back. 3. Hold the passive twist, breathing deeply. Unwind and switch sides.
Safety Cue: Keep your hips high and squared over your knees. Relax into the stretch without forcing the twist.

Goals: Increase overall strength
Contraindications: Acute wrist pain, severe tennis elbow
Steps to Perform: 1. Sit upright, holding dumbbells at sides with palms facing each other (hammer grip). 2. Curl the weights up toward the shoulders, keeping the hammer grip constant. 3. Slowly lower the weights back to the start with control.
Safety Cue: Maintain an upright posture and keep your elbows pinned to your sides. Avoid leaning back or rocking.

Goals: Increase overall strength, Balance
Contraindications: Acute knee pain, ankle instability
Steps to Perform: 1. Stand in front of a sturdy step/box (low height). Step up with one foot, planting the whole foot firmly. 2. Drive through the heel to stand up on the box. 3. Slowly lower the trailing foot back to the floor with control. Complete all reps on one side.
Safety Cue: Avoid pushing off with the back foot. The entire lift should be driven by the foot planted on the step.

Goals: Increase overall strength, Improve Posture and Balance
Contraindications: Acute shoulder pain, rotator cuff tear
Steps to Perform: 1. Kneel facing an anchor point overhead (door anchor or rack). Grip the band/rope. 2. Pull the band down toward your shoulders/chest, depressing your shoulder blades and squeezing your lats. 3. Slowly let the band stretch your arms back overhead.
Safety Cue: Keep your torso stable and upright throughout. Focus on pulling the elbows down and back using the lats.

Goals: Rehabilitation & Injury prevention, Increase overall strength
Contraindications: Acute knee pain, recent hip surgery
Rest Intervals: Maximal Glute Medius Isolation & Hip Stability
Health Benefit: 1. Lie on your side, knees bent, mini-band around knees. Lift your hips off the floor slightly (side-plank prep). 2. Keeping feet together, push the top knee open against the band tension. 3. Slowly control the knee back down. Maintain the lifted hip position.
Steps to Perform: Keep your feet together and avoid letting your hips rock backward as you open the knee.

Goals: Improve Flexibility & Mobility, Reduce Stress
Contraindications: Acute knee pain, recent hip replacement (check doc)
Steps to Perform: 1. Lie on your back. Cross one ankle over the opposite knee (forming a '4' shape). 2. Reach through the opening and gently pull the knee toward your chest. 3. Relax your shoulders and breathe into the stretch in the glute/hip area.
Safety Cue: Avoid lifting your lower back aggressively off the floor. Keep the movement gentle and steady.

Goals: Increase overall strength, Improve Posture and Balance
Contraindications: Acute low back pain, severe balance issues
Health Benefit: 1. Stand on one leg, holding a light dumbbell in the opposite hand (e.g., stand on left leg, dumbbell in right hand). 2. Hinge at the hip, lowering the dumbbell toward the floor, letting the back leg float behind you. 3. Squeeze the standing glute to drive back up to the starting position.
Steps to Perform: Maintain a flat back and a soft knee on the standing leg. Focus on controlled hip movement, not speed.

Goals: Improve Flexibility & Mobility, Reduce Stress
Contraindications: Acute spinal disc injury, severe wrist pain (use fists)
Steps to Perform: 1. Start on hands and knees (tabletop). 2. Cow: Drop the belly, lift the tailbone, and look up gently (inhale). 3. Cat: Arch the spine toward the ceiling (like a Halloween cat), tuck the chin and tailbone (exhale). Move slowly between poses.
Safety Cue: Coordinate the movement with your breath (inhale for cow, exhale for cat). Keep the movement fluid and gentle.

Goals: Increase overall strength, Improve Posture and Balance
Contraindications: Acute shoulder impingement, unhealed rib fracture
Steps to Perform: 1. Lie face down on an incline bench, chest supported. Hold dumbbells underneath, palms facing each other. 2. Pull the weights up toward the chest, driving elbows high and squeezing the shoulder blades. 3. Slowly lower the weights back down.
Safety Cue: Keep your head neutral and the chest pressed firmly into the bench. Avoid pulling with the neck or shoulders.

Goals: Increase overall strength, Rehabilitation & Injury prevention
Contraindications: Acute spinal disc injury, unhealed abdominal hernia
Steps to Perform: 1. Sit tall in a chair, feet flat. Hold a light medicine ball/dumbbell at your chest. 2. Keeping your back straight, slowly twist your torso to one side. 3. Slowly return to the center and twist to the opposite side.
Safety Cue: Maintain an upright spine and control the rotation. The movement is small and driven by the core, not swinging the arms.

Goals: Rehabilitation & Injury prevention, Increase overall strength
Contraindications: Acute hip joint pain, unhealed groin strain
Steps to Perform: 1. Lie on your side, body straight, supporting your head with your hand. 2. Keeping the top leg perfectly straight, slowly lift it up toward the ceiling. 3. Slowly lower the leg back down with control.
Safety Cue: Keep your hips stacked (perpendicular to the floor) and avoid rolling backward to lift the leg higher.

Goals: Increase overall strength
Contraindications: Acute knee pain, high blood pressure (avoid straining)
Steps to Perform: 1. Get into a standard Wall Sit position (90-degree knees). 2. Hold a dumbbell or kettlebell vertically against your chest (goblet style). 3. Brace your core and hold the position for the duration.
Safety Cue: Ensure your knees are stacked over your ankles (90 degrees). Keep your back flat against the wall and your core tight.

Goals: Improve cardiovascular fitness, Balance
Contraindications: Acute knee pain, severe ankle stiffness
Steps to Perform: 1. Sit upright on a chair, feet flat. 2. Alternately tap the toe of one foot and then the heel of the same foot quickly, followed by the opposite foot. 3. Maintain a continuous, rhythmic "tap-tap" motion.
Safety Cue: Maintain an upright back. Keep the movement small and controlled from the ankle and hip.

Goals: Increase overall strength
Contraindications: Acute elbow pain, severe wrist pain
Steps to Perform: 1. Stand facing the anchor, holding the handles, body straight. Walk feet forward to increase the lean/intensity. 2. Curl your body up toward your hands, bending the elbows and keeping them high. 3. Slowly lower back to the starting lean position with control.
Safety Cue: Keep your body rigid and straight as a plank. Avoid letting your hips drop or lag behind the shoulders.

Exercise Name: Forward Fold (Uttanasana) with Hands on Blocks
Goals: Improve Flexibility & Mobility, Reduce Stress
Contraindications: Acute hamstring tear, uncontrolled high blood pressure
Steps to Perform: 1. Stand with feet hip-width apart. Place blocks or a low stool in front of your feet. 2. Hinge at the hips, keeping a flat back initially, reaching hands to the blocks. 3. Allow your neck to relax and gently deepen the bend as comfortable.
Safety Cue: Do not force the stretch. Keep knees slightly bent if hamstrings are tight, and use the blocks to keep the spine long.

Goals: Increase overall strength, Rehabilitation & Injury prevention
Contraindications: Acute spinal disc injury, acute knee pain (use cushion)
Steps to Perform: 1. Kneel in a half-kneeling position (one knee up, one down) perpendicular to the cable/band anchor (chest height). 2. Grip the handle with both hands at your chest. 3. Slowly press your arms straight forward and hold the position, fighting the rotational pull. Slowly return and repeat.
Safety Cue: Keep your hips square and brace your core completely. The goal is to prevent the cable/band from rotating your torso.

Goals: Rehabilitation & Injury prevention, Improve Flexibility & Mobility
Contraindications: Acute plantar fasciitis, recent ankle surgery
Steps to Perform: 1. Sit upright. Alternately press your heel down and lift your toes high, then press your toes down and lift your heel high. 2. Perform the movement slowly and deliberately, focusing on full range of motion in the ankle. 3. Repeat for the prescribed reps.
Safety Cue: Keep your knee stationary and focus the movement entirely at the ankle joint.

Goals: Rehabilitation & Injury prevention, Increase overall strength
Contraindications: Acute knee pain, inability to stand independently
Steps to Perform: 1. Sit tall in a sturdy chair, feet flat and wide. Cross arms over chest. 2. Lean forward slightly and press through your feet to stand up completely. 3. Slowly lower back down to lightly tap the chair before standing again.
Safety Cue: Keep your back straight and avoid rocking forward excessively. Choose a chair height that allows for controlled standing.

Goals: Increase overall strength, Improve Posture and Balance
Contraindications: Unmanaged hernia, severe vertigo
Steps to Perform: 1. Stand tall, holding very heavy dumbbells (or kettlebells) in each hand. 2. Maintain perfect vertical posture, bracing the core and pulling shoulders back. 3. Walk slowly and deliberately for the prescribed distance or time.
Safety Cue: Resist the urge to lean or sway. Shoulders must remain level, and the grip should be secure.

Goals: Increase overall strength
Contraindications: Acute wrist pain, severe shoulder impingement
Steps to Perform: 1. Place feet on a bench, hands on the floor. Hips are pushed high (inverted 'V' shape). 2. Lower the top of your head toward the floor by bending the elbows. 3. Push back up forcefully, extending the arms.
Safety Cue: Keep your hands and head forming a triangle throughout the movement. Focus on the push, not letting the head touch the floor.

Goals: Rehabilitation & Injury prevention, Improve Posture and Balance
Contraindications: Acute shoulder pain, unhealed rib fracture
Steps to Perform: 1. Lie on your side, knees bent 90 degrees. Prop up on your forearm (elbow under shoulder). 2. Press through the forearm and hips to lift the hips off the floor, forming a straight line from head to knees. 3. Hold the position rigidly.
Safety Cue: Keep your elbow directly under your shoulder. Press the bottom hip forward to prevent rolling backward.

Goals: Increase overall strength, Improve Posture and Balance
Contraindications: Acute shoulder instability, severe low back pain
Steps to Perform: 1. Sit upright on a bench (no back support). Hold one dumbbell racked at shoulder height. 2. Press the dumbbell straight overhead until the arm is fully extended. 3. Slowly lower the weight back to the shoulder, resisting lateral shift.
Safety Cue: Brace your core tightly to prevent your torso from bending or tilting away from the weight.

Goals: Improve Posture and Balance, Rehabilitation & Injury prevention
Contraindications: Acute shoulder pain, biceps tendonitis
Steps to Perform: 1. Attach band high. Grip ends. Pull band toward your face, driving elbows back. 2. Squeeze shoulder blades together, finishing with hands near ears. 3. Control the hands forward slowly. Focus on high reps and maintaining form.
Safety Cue: Do not let your shoulders creep up to your ears. Focus the squeeze in the rear shoulders and upper back.

Goals: Improve Flexibility & Mobility, Rehabilitation & Injury prevention
Contraindications: Acute hamstring strain, severe sciatica
Steps to Perform: 1. Stand tall. Step one heel forward, keeping the leg straight (or slightly bent). 2. Hinge at the hips and "scoop" your hands toward your heel/toe. 3. Stand back up and bring the leg back. Repeat smoothly on the same side.
Safety Cue: Maintain a straight back throughout the hinge. The movement is fluid, not a static hold.

Goals: Increase overall strength, Balance
Contraindications: Acute knee pain, recent hip surgery
Steps to Perform: 1. Stand on one leg in front of a box/bench. The other foot is slightly off the ground. 2. Slowly lower down until you lightly tap the box. 3. Drive through the heel of the standing foot to stand back up without using the other leg.
Safety Cue: Start with a higher box and keep your knee tracking over your foot. Control the descent fully.

Goals: Improve cardiovascular fitness, Rehabilitation & Injury prevention
Contraindications: Severe dizziness, acute joint pain
Steps to Perform: 1. Stand near a wall or sturdy furniture for light support. 2. Slowly march in place, lifting knees to hip height if comfortable. 3. Maintain a consistent, steady rhythm. Use support only for balance.
Safety Cue: Keep your head up and focus forward. Gradually reduce your reliance on the support object.

Goals: Increase overall strength
Contraindications: Acute low back pain, unhealed hernia
Steps to Perform: 1. Lie on your back, knees bent. Place a barbell or heavy dumbbell across your lower abdomen/hips. 2. Drive through the heels to lift the hips toward the ceiling until the torso and thighs are in a straight line. 3. Squeeze the glutes hard at the top. Slowly lower back down.
Safety Cue: Ensure padding (towel/pad) is used under the weight. Avoid over-arching the low back; the lift should come from the glutes.

Exercise Name: Forearm Plank to Hands Plank (Up-Down Plank)
Goals: Increase overall strength, Stability
Contraindications: Acute wrist pain, shoulder instability
Steps to Perform: 1. Start in a forearm plank (elbows under shoulders). 2. Push up onto one hand, then the other, transitioning to a high plank. 3. Immediately lower back down onto the first forearm, then the second. Repeat, alternating the lead arm.
Safety Cue: Minimize hip movement (rocking/tilting) as you transition between the forearm and high plank positions.

Goals: Increase overall strength, Rehabilitation & Injury prevention
Contraindications: Acute wrist pain, shoulder instability
Steps to Perform: 1. Start on hands and knees. Walk hands forward until the body is in a straight line from head to knees. 2. Keep elbows tucked close to your body. Lower chest toward the floor by bending the elbows backward. 3. Push forcefully back up to the start.
Safety Cue: Keep your core tight and maintain the straight line from head to knees. Elbows should graze the ribs.

Goals: Increase overall strength, Improve Posture and Balance
Contraindications: Acute knee pain (use cushion), shoulder pain
Steps to Perform: 1. Place one knee and the opposite hand on a flat bench. Keep the back flat and parallel to the floor. 2. Hold a dumbbell in the hanging hand. Pull the weight to the chest, squeezing the shoulder blade. 3. Slowly lower the weight back down with control.
Safety Cue: Avoid letting your torso rotate toward the ceiling as you pull. Focus on pulling the elbow, not just the wrist.

Goals: Improve Posture and Balance, Rehabilitation & Injury prevention
Contraindications: Acute shoulder pain, severe neck tension
Steps to Perform: 1. Stand with your back flat against the wall. Place elbows and wrists against the wall (like a goalpost). 2. Slowly slide the arms up the wall, keeping the lower back, elbows, and wrists in contact. 3. Slide the arms back down. Only go as high as you can maintain contact.
Safety Cue: Do not let your lower back arch. Focus on depressing the shoulder blades (pulling them down) as you slide.

Goals: Improve Flexibility & Mobility, Rehabilitation & Injury prevention
Contraindications: Acute hamstring strain, low back pain
Steps to Perform: 1. Lie on your back, one leg bent, foot flat. Loop a strap around the arch of the straight leg. 2. Use your hands to pull the strap, gently guiding the leg up toward the ceiling. 3. Hold briefly at the peak stretch, then slowly lower the leg back down with control.
Safety Cue: Keep your low back flat on the mat. The movement is a controlled leg raise, not a jerky pull.

Goals: Increase overall strength, Rehabilitation & Injury prevention
Contraindications: Acute knee pain, severe ankle instability
Steps to Perform: 1. Place a long band under your feet, holding the ends at shoulder height (like holding straps). 2. Squat down, keeping your chest up and back straight, using the band to increase resistance on the way up. 3. Drive through the heels to stand.
Safety Cue: Ensure your knees track over your feet. The band provides an upward pull, making the top of the squat harder.

Goals: Increase overall strength, Improve cardiovascular fitness
Contraindications: Acute shoulder pain, spinal disc injury (use light weight)
Steps to Perform: 1. Stand in an athletic stance, holding a light medicine ball. 2. Lift the ball up and over to one side (like drawing a rainbow arc). 3. Forcefully slam the ball down just outside the opposite foot, hinging the hips. Catch and repeat smoothly.
Safety Cue: Protect your lower back by bracing your core strongly during the slam. Use a light ball and focus on rotation/speed.

Goals: Rehabilitation & Injury prevention, Reduce Stress
Contraindications: Acute low back flare-up, unhealed tailbone injury
Steps to Perform: 1. Lie on your back, knees bent, feet flat. 2. Gently flatten your lower back into the floor by tilting your pelvis upward (tucking your tailbone). 3. Gently release the tilt, allowing a small arch to return. The movement is very subtle.
Safety Cue: The movement is small and controlled. Avoid pressing hard enough to lift your hips completely off the floor.

Goals: Improve Posture and Balance, Rehabilitation & Injury prevention
Contraindications: Acute ankle sprain, severe dizziness
Steps to Perform: 1. Stand facing a wall, hands on the wall for balance. Lift one foot slightly off the floor. 2. Slowly rock forward onto the ball of the standing foot, lifting the heel slightly (push-off). 3. Slowly lower the heel back down, maintaining balance on the single leg.
Safety Cue: Keep your standing knee soft (not locked). Use the wall only for very light fingertip support.

Goals: Increase overall strength, Improve Posture and Balance
Contraindications: Acute knee pain (use cushion), spinal disc injury
Steps to Perform: 1. Kneel in a half-kneeling position facing the anchor (high pulley). Grip the handle with both hands. 2. Pull the handle diagonally across your body (chopping motion) toward the knee that is up. 3. Slowly return the handle to the start, resisting the pull back up.
Safety Cue: Keep your torso upright and avoid leaning or letting the torso rotate excessively toward the anchor point.

Goals: Increase overall strength, Stability
Contraindications: Acute low back pain, severe balance issues
Steps to Perform: 1. Stand tall, hands behind your head, feet shoulder-width apart. 2. Lift one knee up and crunch your elbow down toward that knee. 3. Squeeze the side of your torso (obliques). Return to standing and alternate sides.
Safety Cue: Avoid pulling on your neck. The movement should be a controlled side bend and crunch from the core.

Goals: Increase overall strength, Rehabilitation & Injury prevention
Contraindications: Acute knee pain, ankle instability
Steps to Perform: 1. Stand in a staggered stance (one foot forward), holding a light dumbbell in the opposite hand. 2. Place the free hand on a wall or chair for light support. 3. Lower into a lunge, dropping the back knee toward the floor. 4. Drive through the front heel to stand up.
Safety Cue: Use the support lightly for balance only. Ensure the front knee tracks safely over the ankle.

Goals: Increase overall strength, Improve Posture and Balance
Contraindications: Acute shoulder pain, unhealed sternum fracture
Steps to Perform: 1. Sit upright, facing away from the low-pulley cable. Grip the handle in one hand at the shoulder. 2. Press the handle straight forward, fully extending the arm. 3. Slowly resist the weight as it pulls the arm back to the chest. Brace the core.
Safety Cue: Keep your torso completely still and square; fight the machine's attempt to pull you into rotation.

Goals: Improve Flexibility & Mobility, Reduce Stress
Contraindications: Acute knee pain, recent hip/knee surgery (consult doc)
Steps to Perform: 1. From hands and knees, bring one knee forward toward the outside of the hand. Slide the opposite leg straight back. 2. Place support (pillow/block) under the bent hip. 3. Fold the torso forward over the front knee, resting on forearms or stacked hands.
Safety Cue: Protect your knee. If you feel any sharp pain, come out of the pose immediately and use more support under the hip.

Goals: Rehabilitation & Injury prevention, Improve Posture and Balance
Contraindications: Acute wrist pain (use fists), severe SI joint pain
Steps to Perform: 1. Start on hands and knees (tabletop). 2. Simultaneously lift and extend the opposite arm and leg straight out (arm to ear height, leg to hip height). 3. Hold briefly, then slowly return to the floor.
Safety Cue: Keep your gaze down to maintain a neutral neck. Avoid letting your lower back arch or your torso rotate.

Goals: Increase overall strength, Improve Posture and Balance
Contraindications: Acute shoulder instability, severe neck pain
Steps to Perform: 1. Stand tall. Press one dumbbell overhead until the arm is fully straight (locked). 2. Walk slowly and deliberately, maintaining the arm straight and vertical. 3. Resist the tendency to lean away from the weight.
Safety Cue: Keep your core strongly braced. Do not let the arm drift forward or backward; it must stay directly overhead.

Goals: Increase overall strength, Rehabilitation & Injury prevention
Contraindications: Acute knee pain, unhealed hamstring tear
Steps to Perform: 1. Lie on back, knees bent, feet flat. Extend one leg straight up or forward. 2. Drive through the heel of the planted foot, lifting hips toward the ceiling. 3. Squeeze the glute of the planted leg. Slowly lower hips back down.
Safety Cue: Ensure your hips stay level throughout the lift. Avoid pushing up so high that your low back takes over from your glutes.

Goals: Rehabilitation & Injury prevention, Increase overall strength
Contraindications: Acute knee pain, Achilles tendonitis
Steps to Perform: 1. Place a mini-band around your ankles. Get into a slight quarter-squat stance. 2. Step sideways (laterally), leading the step by digging the heel into the floor first. 3. Maintain band tension and complete all reps, then reverse direction.
Safety Cue: Stay low in the quarter-squat position. Focus the pressure through the heel as you step to engage the glutes more.

Goals: Improve cardiovascular fitness, Increase overall strength
Contraindications: Acute knee pain, severe weakness
Steps to Perform: 1. Choose a chair/bench height that is easy to stand from. 2. Stand up and sit down continuously at a steady, rhythmic pace for the duration. 3. Maintain good form (chest up, knees over feet).
Safety Cue: Do not fully rest at the bottom; treat it as a light touch-and-go. Keep the pace consistent.

Goals: Increase overall strength
Contraindications: Acute shoulder pain, wrist pain
Steps to Perform: 1. Sit on a bench edge, hands by hips, fingers pointing forward. Walk feet out so knees are bent 90 degrees. 2. Lower your hips toward the floor by bending the elbows (should go backward, not out). 3. Push back up forcefully, extending the arms completely.
Safety Cue: Keep your elbows tracking backward and close to your body. Avoid letting your shoulders roll forward at the bottom.

Goals: Improve Flexibility & Mobility, Reduce Stress
Contraindications: Acute hamstring strain, severe low back pain
Steps to Perform: 1. Sit on the floor, one leg straight, the other leg bent (foot to inner thigh). 2. Keep the back straight. Hinge forward at the hips, reaching hands toward the straight foot. 3. Relax and hold the stretch in the back of the leg.
Safety Cue: Focus on hinging from the hips (chest toward thigh), not rounding the lower back (nose toward knee).

Goals: Increase overall strength, Improve Posture and Balance
Contraindications: Acute shoulder instability, elbow joint pain
Steps to Perform: 1. Stand tall, holding one dumbbell with both hands extended overhead. 2. Slowly bend the elbows, lowering the dumbbell behind your head/neck. 3. Extend the arms forcefully back overhead, engaging the triceps.
Safety Cue: Keep your core tight and avoid arching your lower back as the weight moves behind your head.

Goals: Rehabilitation & Injury prevention, Improve Flexibility & Mobility
Contraindications: Acute hip joint pain, recent hip surgery (check protocol)
Health Benefit: Hip Capsule Mobility & Range of Motion
Steps to Perform: 1. Lie on your back, knees bent, feet flat and wide (wider than hip-width). 2. Keeping the feet planted, slowly let both knees drop inward toward each other. 3. Return the knees to the starting position. Repeat slowly.
Safety Cue: Control the inward movement and avoid letting your feet slide. The movement should be slow and fluid.

Goals: Increase overall strength
Contraindications: Acute shoulder pain, unhealed sternum fracture
Steps to Perform: 1. Lie on a bench, feet flat. Grip the bar slightly wider than shoulder-width. 2. Lower the bar to the mid-chest with control. 3. Press the bar straight up, locking out the elbows.
Safety Cue: Maintain 5 points of contact (feet, glutes, back, head). Use a spotter and focus on controlled descent.

Goals: Increase overall strength, Rehabilitation & Injury prevention
Contraindications: Acute wrist pain, carpal tunnel flare-up
Steps to Perform: 1. Sit and rest your forearm on your thigh/bench, wrist hanging off the edge. Hold a light dumbbell. 2. Extension: Slowly curl the wrist up toward the ceiling. Flexion: Slowly curl the wrist down toward the floor.
Safety Cue: Keep the forearm pinned to the support; only the wrist should be moving. Use very light weight.

Goals: Improve Posture and Balance, Rehabilitation & Injury prevention
Contraindications: Severe dizziness, acute ankle sprain
Steps to Perform: 1. Stand on one leg. Lift the opposite foot slightly off the ground. 2. Once stable, close your eyes and hold the position. 3. Have a wall or support nearby to reach out to if you lose balance.
Safety Cue: Use a spotter or be near a wall. Focus on maintaining a very still, locked-in standing knee and ankle.

Goals: Increase overall strength
Contraindications: Acute elbow joint pain, wrist pain
Steps to Perform: 1. Sit on a bench, legs open wide. Brace the back of the upper arm against the inside of the thigh. 2. Curl the dumbbell up toward the shoulder, squeezing the bicep hard. 3. Slowly lower the weight with extreme control. Complete all reps on one side.
Safety Cue: Keep the upper arm locked against the thigh for stability. Use a slower tempo (3-4 seconds down).

Goals: Increase overall strength
Contraindications: Acute spinal disc injury, severe scoliosis
Steps to Perform: 1. Sit upright on a bench. Hold a light dumbbell in one hand, the other hand behind the head. 2. Slowly lean the torso over to the side holding the weight (side bend). 3. Use the opposite oblique muscle to slowly pull the torso back to the upright center.
Safety Cue: Maintain an upright chest and avoid leaning forward or backward during the bend. Keep the movement slow.

Goals: Improve Flexibility & Mobility, Rehabilitation & Injury prevention
Contraindications: Acute hamstring tear, severe sciatica
Steps to Perform: 1. Sit on the foam roller, placing it under one hamstring. Use hands for support. 2. Slowly roll back and forth along the entire hamstring (from glute to knee). 3. Pause on any tender spots for 10-15 seconds. Switch legs.
Safety Cue: Keep your spine neutral (avoid rounding). Use the non-rolling leg and arms to control the pressure.

Goals: Rehabilitation & Injury prevention, Improve Posture and Balance
Contraindications: Acute spinal disc injury, severe knee pain (use cushion)
Steps to Perform: 1. Kneel perpendicular to the cable anchor (chest height). Grip the handle with both hands at your chest. 2. Press your arms straight out in front of you and hold them stationary. 3. Fight the pull of the cable trying to rotate your body toward the anchor point.
Safety Cue: Brace your core and glutes to maintain a perfect, motionless box shape (no rotation or leaning allowed).

Goals: Increase overall strength, Rehabilitation & Injury prevention
Contraindications: Acute Achilles pain, severe dizziness
Steps to Perform: 1. Stand facing a wall, hands lightly on the wall for balance. 2. Slowly lift both heels off the floor, pushing up onto the balls of your feet. 3. Hold briefly at the top, then slowly lower the heels back down.
Safety Cue: Keep your body straight and use the wall only for light fingertip support. Focus on smooth, controlled movement.

Goals: Increase overall strength, Rehabilitation & Injury prevention
Contraindications: Acute shoulder instability, recent rotator cuff surgery
Steps to Perform: 1. Lie on the floor, knees bent, feet flat. Hold dumbbells with palms facing feet (standard grip). 2. Press the dumbbells straight up until arms are straight. 3. Slowly lower until upper arms lightly touch the floor, protecting the shoulder joint.
Safety Cue: Keep your low back flat and avoid arching. The floor acts as a natural range limiter for shoulder safety.

Goals: Increase overall strength, Improve Posture and Balance
Contraindications: Acute low back pain, shoulder impingement
Steps to Perform: 1. Stand on the middle of the band, holding the ends. Hinge at the hips with a flat back (bent-over position). 2. Pull the band ends up toward your chest, driving elbows high and squeezing shoulder blades. 3. Slowly lower the hands back down, resisting the band tension.
Safety Cue: Maintain the flat back and the hip-hinged position throughout. Avoid rounding the shoulders forward.

Goals: Rehabilitation & Injury prevention, Increase overall strength
Contraindications: Acute knee pain, recent hip surgery
Steps to Perform: 1. Stand tall, mini-band around ankles. Use a wall for light support if needed. 2. Slowly lift one leg straight out to the side (abduction) against the band tension. 3. Slowly lower the leg back down, without letting it rest completely. Repeat on the same side.
Safety Cue: Keep your torso completely still and upright. The movement should be small and controlled from the hip.

Goals: Improve Flexibility & Mobility, Reduce Stress
Contraindications: Acute spinal disc injury, shoulder impingement
Steps to Perform: 1. Lie on your side, knees bent 90 degrees and stacked. Arms extended straight out in front of you. 2. Slowly "open" the top arm and shoulder, rotating the upper body until the shoulder blade/back of the hand touches the floor on the opposite side. 3. Hold the stretch, allowing the chest to open.
Safety Cue: Keep the knees stacked and firmly on the floor throughout the rotation.

Goals: Increase overall strength, Improve cardiovascular fitness
Contraindications: Acute low back pain, inner thigh strain
Steps to Perform: 1. Stand wide, feet out, KB on floor. Squat down and grip the handle. 2. Drive through the heels and stand up tall, squeezing glutes. 3. Immediately lower back down to the floor, maintaining a quick, controlled pace.
Safety Cue: Maintain your chest up and a flat back, especially as fatigue sets in. Do not let the form break down.

Goals: Improve Posture and Balance, Rehabilitation & Injury prevention
Contraindications: Severe dizziness, acute ankle sprain
Steps to Perform: 1. Stand on one leg. Lift the opposite foot slightly. 2. Slowly perform large circles with both arms simultaneously in the same direction. 3. After 10 circles, reverse the direction. Switch legs and repeat.
Safety Cue: Keep the standing knee soft and the core braced. The eyes should follow the hands if possible for added challenge.

Goals: Increase overall strength, Rehabilitation & Injury prevention
Contraindications: Acute hamstring strain, severe low back pain
Steps to Perform: 1. Lie on your back, place heels in the foot cradles of the TRX, starting with knees bent. 2. Lift hips into a bridge. Slowly extend legs straight out (avoiding hip drop). 3. Slowly curl heels back in toward the glutes, lifting hips higher at the end.
Safety Cue: Keep your hips lifted and level throughout the entire range of motion. Control the eccentric phase (leg extension).

Goals: Increase overall strength
Contraindications: Acute knee pain, unmanaged high blood pressure
Steps to Perform: 1. Place back against the wall. Walk feet out and slide down until your hips are below your knees. 2. Ensure your thighs are slightly below parallel to the floor (deep squat position). 3. Hold the position rigidly.
Safety Cue: Maintain constant tension in the quads and keep your back flat against the wall.

Goals: Improve Posture and Balance, Rehabilitation & Injury prevention
Contraindications: Acute shoulder impingement, lower back pain
Steps to Perform: 1. Lie perpendicular across a bench. Lower a dumbbell behind your head (arms slightly bent). 2. After pulling the dumbbell back over the chest, perform a final slight "punch" to the ceiling (protraction). 3. This small extra reach engages the serratus anterior.
Safety Cue: Keep the arms slightly bent and focus on the small forward reach (protraction) at the top of the movement.

Goals: Increase overall strength, Rehabilitation & Injury prevention
Contraindications: Acute elbow or wrist pain, shoulder instability
Steps to Perform: 1. Sit in a chair with back support. Hold a dumbbell in one hand, palm up. 2. Keep the elbow tight to your side and the upper arm resting against the torso. 3. Curl the weight up toward the shoulder and slowly lower.
Safety Cue: Use the backrest and torso for support to eliminate momentum (cheating). Focus on the contraction.

Goals: Rehabilitation & Injury prevention, Improve Flexibility & Mobility
Contraindications: Acute ankle sprain, severe arthritis
Health Benefit: Ankle Joint Health & Range of Motion
Steps to Perform: 1. Sit tall in a chair. Lift one foot slightly off the floor. 2. Slowly trace a large circle with the ankle/foot, moving through the full range of motion. 3. Complete all circles in one direction, then reverse. Switch feet.
Safety Cue: Keep the shin and knee still. The movement should be concentrated only at the ankle joint.

Goals: Improve Posture and Balance, Reduce Stress
Contraindications: Acute low back pain, pregnancy (modify)
Steps to Perform: 1. Lie face down, hands under shoulders, elbows tucked in. 2. Press through hands and feet, lifting the chest gently off the floor (using mostly back muscles). 3. Keep the neck long and shoulders away from ears. Keep hips on the floor.
Safety Cue: Lift with your back muscles, not your arms. The lift should be low and comfortable for the low back.

Goals: Increase overall strength, Stability
Contraindications: Acute spinal disc injury, severe knee pain (use cushion)
Steps to Perform: 1. Kneel perpendicular to the cable anchor (chest height). Grip handle with both hands. 2. Press arms straight out from your chest and hold the arms extended. 3. Fight the rotational pull rigidly. Maintain tension and no movement in the torso.
Safety Cue: Ensure your body forms a straight line from head to kneeling knee. Do not let the arms move once extended.

Goals: Increase overall strength, Balance
Contraindications: Acute knee pain, severe hamstring tightness
Steps to Perform: 1. Stand on one leg. Hinge at the hip, letting your torso drop toward the floor. 2. Extend the non-standing leg straight out behind you, maintaining a flat back. 3. Drive through the standing heel and squeeze the glute to return to standing.
Safety Cue: Focus on keeping your hips level (not twisting). Only hinge as far as you can maintain a flat back.

Goals: Increase overall strength, Improve Posture and Balance
Contraindications: Acute shoulder instability, severe low back pain
Steps to Perform: 1. Sit on a bench with back support. Hold one dumbbell racked at shoulder height. 2. Press the dumbbell straight overhead. 3. Slowly lower the weight, controlling the lateral forces. Use the free hand to brace the core if needed.
Safety Cue: Keep your core tight and back pressed against the support. Avoid leaning away from the pressing side.

Goals: Rehabilitation & Injury prevention, Increase overall strength
Contraindications: Acute knee pain, groin strain
Steps to Perform: 1. Lie on your side. Cross the top leg over the bottom leg, planting the top foot on the floor in front of the bottom knee. 2. Keep the bottom leg straight. Slowly lift the bottom leg up toward the ceiling. 3. Slowly lower the bottom leg back down without letting it rest.
Safety Cue: Keep the bottom leg straight and rotate the hip slightly inward to engage the adductors effectively.

Goals: Increase overall strength, Rehabilitation & Injury prevention
Contraindications: Acute knee pain, severe dizziness
Steps to Perform: 1. Stand on a low box or step. Step one foot to the edge. 2. Slowly lower yourself down, controlling the descent fully until the foot lightly touches the floor. 3. Step back up to the box and repeat with the same leg.
Safety Cue: Make the descent as slow as possible (3-5 seconds down). Avoid letting the knee cave inward during the lowering phase.

Goals: Increase overall strength
Contraindications: Acute shoulder instability, acute low back pain
Steps to Perform: 1. Sit upright with back support. Hold dumbbells racked, palms facing each other (neutral grip). 2. Press the dumbbells straight overhead. 3. Slowly lower the weights back to the start.
Safety Cue: Ensure your core is braced. The neutral grip can be gentler on the shoulders than the standard grip.

Goals: Increase overall strength
Contraindications: Acute elbow pain, wrist pain
Steps to Perform: 1. Lie on a bench, holding dumbbells straight up over your chest. 2. Keeping upper arms vertical (or angled slightly back), slowly bend elbows to lower the dumbbells toward your ears/head. 3. Forcefully extend the arms, squeezing the triceps.
Safety Cue: Tuck the elbows in slightly and keep them pointing forward. Use a spotter or lighter weight for safety over the face.

Goals: Improve Flexibility & Mobility, Rehabilitation & Injury prevention
Contraindications: Acute hip joint pain, knee instability
Steps to Perform: 1. Stand on one leg (use support if needed). Lift the opposite knee up to 90 degrees. 2. Keeping the knee bent, slowly rotate the lower leg inward (foot moves out) and outward (foot moves in). 3. Only move within a pain-free range.
Safety Cue: Keep your pelvis level and your torso stable. The movement should be concentrated at the hip joint.

Goals: Increase overall strength, Improve Posture and Balance
Contraindications: Acute knee pain (use cushion), shoulder pain
Steps to Perform: 1. Kneel in a half-kneeling position, facing away from the band anchor (chest height). 2. Hold the band handle in the hand corresponding to the front knee. Press the arm straight forward. 3. Slowly resist the band as it pulls the arm back to the chest.
Safety Cue: Squeeze the glute of the back leg to stabilize the pelvis and prevent rotational movement.

Goals: Rehabilitation & Injury prevention, Improve Posture and Balance
Contraindications: Severe dizziness, acute knee/hip pain
Steps to Perform: 1. Stand on one leg next to a wall/chair for support. Keep a slight bend in the standing knee. 2. Hinge forward at the hip, extending the free leg straight back. Use light fingertip support. 3. Return to standing. Keep the hinge small and controlled.
Safety Cue: Maintain a flat back. Use the support for stability and focus on the hinge motion in the hip.

Goals: Increase overall strength
Contraindications: Acute low back pain, unhealed spinal disc injury
Steps to Perform: 1. Stand, holding one dumbbell vertically with both hands in front of your thighs. 2. Hinge at the hips, pushing glutes back, allowing the dumbbell to track down the legs. 3. Stop at mid-shin or when stretch is felt. Squeeze glutes to stand up.
Safety Cue: Maintain a flat, neutral spine. The dumbbell helps ensure the load is centered and managed.

Goals: Improve Flexibility & Mobility, Posture
Contraindications: Acute knee pain, recent hip surgery
Steps to Perform: 1. Start in a deep half-kneeling lunge position (front knee over ankle). 2. Gently rock the hips straight forward until a stretch is felt, then rock the hips back over the rear knee. 3. Move back and forth smoothly for reps.
Safety Cue: Keep your torso upright and avoid arching the low back. The movement should be a gentle rock.

Goals: Increase overall strength
Contraindications: Acute spinal disc injury, unhealed hernia
Steps to Perform: 1. Lie on your back, legs straight up (perpendicular to the floor). Hands flat on the floor or behind your head. 2. Gently curl the pelvis up, lifting the tailbone and lower back slightly off the floor. 3. Slowly lower the hips back down with control.
Safety Cue: Keep the legs vertical and focus on the small, upward pelvic curl, not swinging the legs.

Goals: Improve Posture and Balance, Increase overall strength
Contraindications: Acute shoulder pain, rotator cuff tear
Steps to Perform: 1. Lie face down on an incline bench, chest supported. Hold light dumbbells underneath. 2. Raise arms out to the sides in an arc, squeezing the shoulder blades together. 3. Slowly lower back down.
Safety Cue: Keep your head neutral and press your chest into the bench. Avoid using momentum.

Goals: Increase overall strength, Rehabilitation & Injury prevention
Contraindications: Acute shoulder pain, low back pain
Steps to Perform: 1. Sit on a chair. Lean forward, supporting the non-working arm on the knee. Hold a dumbbell in the opposite hand. 2. Pull the weight to the chest, squeezing the shoulder blade toward the spine. 3. Slowly lower the weight back down with control.
Safety Cue: Maintain a flat back and keep the torso stable. Use the support arm to help stabilize the core.

Goals: Improve Flexibility & Mobility, Rehabilitation & Injury prevention
Contraindications: Acute hip joint pain, groin strain
Steps to Perform: 1. Stand near a support. Balance on one leg. 2. Swing the opposite leg out to the side and then across the body in a controlled arc. 3. Maintain an upright torso and only swing as high as comfortable.
Safety Cue: Keep your torso stable and avoid tilting or leaning excessively with the movement.

Goals: Increase overall strength, Rehabilitation & Injury prevention
Contraindications: Acute wrist pain, unhealed chest injury
Steps to Perform: 1. Stand facing a wall. Place hands much wider than shoulder-width on the wall. 2. Step feet back until the body is in a slight incline. 3. Lower the chest toward the wall, letting the elbows flare out slightly. Push back strongly.
Safety Cue: Keep your body straight from head to heels. The wide grip targets the chest more than a standard wall push-up.

Goals: Increase overall strength, Improve Posture and Balance
Contraindications: Acute low back pain, severe scoliosis
Steps to Perform: 1. Stand tall, feet shoulder-width apart. Place one hand behind your head. 2. Slowly bend your torso directly to the side, lowering the hand down the opposite thigh. 3. Use the opposite oblique to pull your torso back up to center.
Safety Cue: Avoid leaning forward or backward. Keep the movement purely side-to-side and controlled.

Goals: Increase overall strength, Improve Posture and Balance
Contraindications: Unmanaged hernia, severe vertigo
Steps to Perform: 1. Stand tall, holding one very heavy dumbbell/KB in only one hand. 2. Walk slowly and deliberately, focusing on keeping your shoulders and hips perfectly level. 3. Resist the tendency for the torso to lean toward the opposite side.
Safety Cue: Maintain perfect vertical posture. Use the heaviest weight you can control without side-bending.

Goals: Increase overall strength
Contraindications: Acute wrist pain, severe shoulder impingement
Steps to Perform: 1. Place hands on elevated blocks or dumbbells. Hips are pushed high (inverted 'V' shape). 2. Lower the top of your head toward the floor between your hands, maintaining the pike. 3. Push back up forcefully, extending the arms.
Safety Cue: Control the descent. Elevating the hands increases the depth and range of motion for the shoulders.

Goals: Rehabilitation & Injury prevention, Increase overall strength
Contraindications: Acute knee pain (use cushion), severe low back pain
Steps to Perform: 1. Start on hands and knees. Loop a mini-band around one foot and the opposite knee. 2. Push the banded foot straight back and slightly up toward the ceiling, contracting the glute. 3. Slowly lower the foot back to the start. Keep the foot flexed.
Safety Cue: Keep your back flat and avoid excessive arching of the low back as you kick back.

Goals: Increase overall strength, Improve Posture and Balance
Contraindications: Acute knee pain, recent hip replacement
Steps to Perform: 1. Stand tall, feet together or hip-width apart. Raise arms overhead (or hands to chest). 2. Sit back as if sitting in a chair, keeping the chest lifted and core engaged. 3. Hold the deep squat position.
Safety Cue: Keep the weight in your heels. Try to see your toes past your knees to ensure good squat depth.

Goals: Increase overall strength, Rehabilitation & Injury prevention
Contraindications: Acute knee pain, ankle instability
Steps to Perform: 1. Stand on one leg. Hold TRX handles or resistance band ends for support. 2. Slowly squat down on the standing leg, using the handles only as needed for balance/stability. 3. Drive through the heel to stand back up.
Safety Cue: The straps/band should only be used for minimal assistance; the standing leg does the majority of the work.

Goals: Rehabilitation & Injury prevention, Increase overall strength
Contraindications: Acute knee pain, severe sciatica
Steps to Perform: 1. Sit upright near the edge of a chair. 2. Straighten one knee, lifting the foot a few inches off the floor. Contract the thigh muscles and hold for 3 seconds. 3. Slowly lower the foot back down.
Safety Cue: Sit completely upright and avoid leaning back. Focus on the squeeze in the front of the thigh.

Goals: Increase overall strength
Contraindications: Acute neck pain, shoulder impingement
Steps to Perform: 1. Stand tall, holding heavy dumbbells at your sides (palms facing in). 2. Elevate your shoulders straight up toward your ears as high as possible. 3. Hold the squeeze briefly, then slowly lower the weights back down.
Safety Cue: Keep your head neutral and your arms straight. Do not roll your shoulders forward or backward.

Exercise Name: Side Plank (Straight Leg, Foot on Step)
Goals: Increase overall strength, Stability
Contraindications: Acute shoulder pain, recent hip surgery
Steps to Perform: 1. Lie on your side. Prop up on your forearm. Place the top foot on an elevated step or bench. 2. Lift hips high until the body forms a straight line from head to heels. 3. Hold the position rigidly.
Safety Cue: Maintain the straight line. Press the top hip forward to keep the core engaged and hips stacked.

Goals: Improve Flexibility & Mobility, Reduce Stress
Contraindications: Acute shoulder pain, unhealed sternum fracture
Steps to Perform: 1. Lie on your back on the floor. Bring one arm out at a 90-degree angle (like a goalpost). 2. Use the opposite hand to gently press the bent elbow toward the floor. 3. Feel the stretch deep in the front of the shoulder/chest. Hold and breathe.
Safety Cue: Avoid pressing hard enough to cause shoulder joint pain. The stretch should be gentle and passive.

Goals: Increase overall strength, Rehabilitation & Injury prevention
Contraindications: Acute elbow pain, severe shoulder instability
Steps to Perform: 1. Sit on a bench. Hinge forward with a flat back. Hold a dumbbell in one hand. 2. Pin the upper arm parallel to the floor. Extend the elbow, straightening the arm backward. 3. Squeeze the tricep hard. Slowly bend the elbow back to the start (90 degrees).
Safety Cue: Keep the upper arm stationary throughout. The movement should occur only at the elbow joint.

Goals: Rehabilitation & Injury prevention, Increase overall strength
Contraindications: Acute knee pain, severe ankle stiffness
Steps to Perform: 1. Place a mini-band around your ankles (or knees). Get into a slight athletic stance. 2. Walk forward, maintaining constant tension on the band by driving your knees slightly outward. 3. Take small, controlled steps, focusing on smooth gait mechanics.
Safety Cue: Do not let the band pull your knees inward. Focus on pushing the knees out against the tension.

Goals: Increase overall strength, Improve Posture and Balance
Contraindications: Acute elbow pain, severe thoracic kyphosis
Steps to Perform: 1. Sit on a bench placed on the cable row machine, facing the machine. Back is supported. 2. Grip the handle in one hand. Pull the handle back toward your side/ribcage, squeezing the back muscle. 3. Slowly let the weight pull the arm forward to full stretch.
Safety Cue: Use the back support to eliminate torso rotation. Focus entirely on the back muscle pulling the elbow.

Goals: Rehabilitation & Injury prevention, Increase overall strength
Contraindications: Acute low back pain, knee ligament injury
Steps to Perform: 1. Lie on your back, knees bent, feet elevated on a bench or chair. 2. Drive through the heels to lift the hips off the floor into a bridge. 3. Squeeze the glutes and hamstrings at the top. Slowly lower back down.
Safety Cue: Keep the low back flat at the start. The feet being elevated places more emphasis on the hamstrings.

Goals: Rehabilitation & Injury prevention, Stability
Contraindications: Acute spinal disc injury, unhealed abdominal separation
Steps to Perform: 1. Lie on back, knees bent 90 degrees, arms straight up. Place a folded towel under the low back. 2. Simultaneously extend opposite arm/leg. 3. Focus on crushing the towel into the floor with the low back to prevent arching.
Safety Cue: If the towel lifts or you feel strain, reduce the range of motion of the arm or leg immediately.

Goals: Improve Flexibility & Mobility, Improve Posture and Balance
Contraindications: Acute hip pain, severe knee ligament issues
Steps to Perform: 1. Stand with feet wide apart. Turn front foot out 90 degrees. 2. Hinge at the front hip, reaching the front hand down the leg (or to a block). 3. Extend the back arm straight up, opening the chest to the side wall. Look up if comfortable.
Safety Cue: Keep your front leg strong (not locked). The reach should maintain the length of both sides of the torso.

Goals: Increase overall strength, Improve Posture and Balance
Contraindications: Acute shoulder instability, severe low back pain
Steps to Perform: 1. Stand tall, feet hip-width apart. Grip the bar slightly outside shoulders, resting at the front of the shoulders. 2. Brace the core and glutes. Press the bar straight overhead, pushing the head slightly forward at the top. 3. Slowly lower the bar back to the starting rack position.
Safety Cue: Brace your entire body (glutes, core). Avoid leaning backward (arching the low back) to complete the lift.

Goals: Rehabilitation & Injury prevention, Balance
Contraindications: Acute knee/ankle pain, severe osteoporosis
Steps to Perform: 1. Stand on one leg. Perform a small, controlled jump sideways onto the opposite foot. 2. Land softly and stabilize immediately before repeating the jump back in the opposite direction. 3. Keep the jump height and distance minimal.
Safety Cue: Focus on the soft landing and quick stabilization. This is about control, not distance or height.

Goals: Increase overall strength
Contraindications: Acute wrist pain, severe tennis elbow
Steps to Perform: 1. Sit upright, holding dumbbells at sides, palms facing each other (hammer grip). 2. Curl the weights up toward the shoulders, maintaining the hammer grip. 3. Slowly lower the weights back to the start.
Safety Cue: Keep your upper arms stationary and close to your body. Avoid leaning back or rocking.

Goals: Improve Flexibility & Mobility, Posture
Contraindications: Acute knee pain, recent hip surgery
Steps to Perform: 1. Step into a low lunge position (one knee bent, one leg straight back). 2. Tuck the pelvis strongly forward (posterior tilt) and squeeze the glute of the back leg. 3. Feel the stretch high in the front of the back hip/thigh. Hold and breathe.
Safety Cue: The pelvic tuck is essential to isolate the hip flexor. Avoid arching the low back.

Goals: Rehabilitation & Injury prevention, Stability
Contraindications: Acute spinal disc injury, unhealed hernia
Steps to Perform: 1. Lie on your back, knees bent, feet flat. Hands flat on the floor. 2. Gently perform a slow pelvic tilt (tucking the tailbone under) to flatten the low back. 3. Hold for 1 second, then slowly release. The hips barely lift off the floor.
Safety Cue: The movement is minimal. Focus on the deep abdominal contraction causing the pelvic tilt.

Goals: Increase overall strength, Improve Posture and Balance
Contraindications: Acute shoulder pain, elbow pain
Steps to Perform: 1. Stand facing the anchor, holding the handles. Walk feet back so your body is slightly leaning back (high angle). 2. Pull your chest toward the handles, driving the elbows back. Squeeze shoulder blades. 3. Slowly extend the arms back to the starting lean.
Safety Cue: Keep your body straight (plank) throughout the movement. The more vertical the body, the easier the row.

Goals: Increase overall strength, Flexibility & Mobility
Contraindications: Acute low back pain, severe hamstring tightness
Steps to Perform: 1. Stand with feet slightly elevated on blocks or plates, holding dumbbells. 2. Hinge at the hips, lowering the weights below the level of your feet for increased stretch. 3. Drive through the heels and squeeze glutes to stand.
Safety Cue: Maintain a perfectly flat back. The deficit requires excellent hamstring flexibility and control.

Goals: Rehabilitation & Injury prevention, Increase overall strength
Contraindications: Acute hip joint pain, recent hip surgery
Steps to Perform: 1. Lie on your side, body straight. Place the bottom arm under the head for support. 2. Slowly lift the top leg a few inches toward the ceiling. 3. Slowly lower the leg back down with control. Keep the leg straight.
Safety Cue: Ensure your hips are stacked and do not roll backward. The movement is small and focused on the side of the hip.

Exercise Name: Yoga: Half Lord of the Fishes Pose (Ardha Matsyendrasana)
Goals: Improve Flexibility & Mobility, Reduce Stress
Contraindications: Acute spinal disc injury, pregnancy (modify/avoid)
Steps to Perform: 1. Sit with legs extended. Bend one knee, stepping the foot over the opposite thigh. 2. Place the bent elbow on the outside of the raised knee. Place the opposite hand behind the tailbone. 3. Gently twist the torso to look over the back shoulder.
Safety Cue: Sit tall and lengthen the spine before twisting. Avoid rounding the lower back during the twist.

Goals: Increase overall strength
Contraindications: Acute shoulder impingement, severe neck pain
Steps to Perform: 1. Stand tall, holding a dumbbell in one hand. 2. Slowly lift the dumbbell straight up in front of you until it reaches shoulder height. 3. Slowly lower the weight back down with control. Avoid leaning backward.
Safety Cue: Use a light weight. Keep the movement controlled and avoid swinging your body to lift the weight.

Goals: Increase overall strength, Improve Posture and Balance
Contraindications: Acute shoulder instability, elbow pain
Steps to Perform: 1. Sit with back support. Hold one dumbbell racked at shoulder height, palm facing in (hammer grip). 2. Press the dumbbell straight overhead. 3. Slowly lower, controlling the weight.
Safety Cue: The hammer grip can be more comfortable for individuals with shoulder impingement issues. Maintain core stability.

Goals: Rehabilitation & Injury prevention, Improve Posture and Balance
Contraindications: Acute shoulder instability, biceps tendonitis
Steps to Perform: 1. Stand, holding a mini-band taut between hands, elbows bent 90 degrees, forearms facing each other. 2. Keeping the upper arms pinned to the side, slowly pull the hands apart against the band tension. 3. Slowly return to the start.
Safety Cue: Keep your upper arms locked at your sides. The movement should be small and isolated to external rotation.

Goals: Rehabilitation & Injury prevention, Improve Flexibility & Mobility
Contraindications: Acute plantar fasciitis, severe ankle stiffness
Steps to Perform: 1. Stand tall. Slowly rock forward onto the balls of your feet (heels up). 2. Slowly rock backward onto your heels, lifting your toes up. 3. Maintain a continuous, gentle rocking motion. Use a wall for support if needed.
Safety Cue: Keep the movement slow and controlled. Focus on mobilizing the ankle joint through the full range.

Goals: Increase overall strength
Contraindications: Acute elbow pain, shoulder pain
Steps to Perform: 1. Kneel facing the cable machine (or band anchor) with a rope/bar attachment. 2. Pull the handle down until arms are straight, squeezing the triceps at the bottom. 3. Slowly let the handle rise back up to the start, controlling the elbow flexion.
Safety Cue: Keep your elbows pinned to your sides throughout the movement. Focus on the final lockout with the triceps.

Goals: Improve Flexibility & Mobility, Reduce Stress
Contraindications: Acute spinal disc injury, unhealed hamstring tear
Steps to Perform: 1. Sit on the floor, legs extended straight out in front of you. 2. Sit tall, then hinge forward at the hips, reaching toward your feet or shins. 3. Allow a slight rounding in the upper back to deepen the stretch, and relax.
Safety Cue: Use a strap around your feet if you cannot reach them. Focus on the stretch in the back of the legs.

Exercise Name: Wall Sit with Alternating Toe Lift
Goals: Increase overall strength, Rehabilitation & Injury prevention
Contraindications: Acute knee pain, recent Achilles tendon repair
Steps to Perform: 1. Get into a standard Wall Sit position (90-degree knees). 2. While holding the squat, slowly lift the toes of one foot off the floor (shin contraction). 3. Lower the toes and switch sides, maintaining the squat depth.
Safety Cue: Keep your back flat against the wall and maintain the knee angle. Avoid letting the heels lift excessively.

Goals: Rehabilitation & Injury prevention, Improve Flexibility & Mobility
Contraindications: Acute whiplash, severe vertigo
Health Benefit: Gentle Cervical Spine Range of Motion
Steps to Perform: 1. Stand tall (use support if needed). Gaze straight ahead. 2. Slowly turn your head to look over one shoulder, only as far as comfortable. 3. Slowly return to the center and then turn to the opposite shoulder.
Safety Cue: Move slowly and deliberately. Do not let your shoulders or torso move during the head turn.

Goals: Increase overall strength
Contraindications: Acute spinal disc injury, unhealed hernia
Steps to Perform: 1. Sit on the floor, knees bent, feet slightly off the floor (or planted for easier version). Lean back slightly, maintaining a straight back. 2. Hold a light medicine ball/dumbbell. Twist your torso quickly from side to side, tapping the ball on the floor next to your hips.
Safety Cue: Maintain the angle of your torso. The twist comes from the core, not just swinging the arms.

Goals: Increase overall strength, Improve Flexibility & Mobility
Contraindications: Acute knee pain, unhealed groin strain
Steps to Perform: 1. Stand holding one dumbbell vertically (goblet style) or at your sides. 2. Step wide to the side. Sink the hips back and down, loading the bent leg, keeping the opposite leg straight. 3. Drive hard through the heel of the bent leg to return to standing.
Safety Cue: Keep your chest up and hinge strongly at the hip. Ensure the bent knee tracks safely over the foot.

Goals: Reduce Stress, Improve Flexibility & Mobility
Contraindications: Acute knee injury, severe diarrhea
Steps to Perform: 1. Kneel on the floor, sit back on heels, open knees wide. 2. Fold torso forward, letting the forehead rest on the mat. 3. Extend arms straight out in front of you, stretching the shoulders and back.
Safety Cue: Breathe deeply and sink the hips back onto the heels. Use a block under the forehead if the floor is too far away.

Goals: Increase overall strength, Improve Posture and Balance
Contraindications: Acute shoulder pain, elbow pain
