Steps to Perform: 1. Loop a band around an anchor (chest height). Stand perpendicular to the anchor. 2. Grip the band in the outside hand. Pull the hand straight back toward the ribcage, squeezing the shoulder blade. 3. Slowly resist the band forward.
Safety Cue: Brace your core to prevent the band from rotating or pulling your torso toward the anchor.

Goals: Improve Posture and Balance, Rehabilitation & Injury prevention
Contraindications: Severe dizziness, acute ankle sprain
Steps to Perform: 1. Stand on one leg. Lift the opposite foot slightly. 2. Slowly turn your head from side to side (looking left, then right) while maintaining balance. 3. Have a spotter or wall ready.
Safety Cue: Maintain controlled head movement. The head turns challenge the inner ear and increase the difficulty of the balance.

Goals: Increase overall strength, Rehabilitation & Injury prevention
Contraindications: Acute wrist pain, carpal tunnel flare-up
Steps to Perform: 1. Sit and rest your forearm on your thigh/bench, wrist hanging off the edge. Hold a light dumbbell with a neutral grip. 2. Supination: Slowly rotate the palm up toward the ceiling. Pronation: Slowly rotate the palm down toward the floor.
Safety Cue: Keep the forearm completely still. The rotation should occur only at the wrist/forearm joint. Use very light weight.

Goals: Increase overall strength
Contraindications: Acute low back pain, unhealed abdominal separation
Steps to Perform: 1. Lie on your back, knees bent, feet flat near your glutes. Lift head/shoulders slightly off the floor. 2. Reach one hand down to tap the heel of the same-side foot. 3. Immediately curl across to tap the opposite heel. Maintain the slight crunch throughout.
Safety Cue: Keep the low back pressed into the floor. The movement is lateral (side-to-side curl), not forward.

Goals: Increase overall strength
Contraindications: Acute knee pain, high blood pressure (avoid straining)
Steps to Perform: 1. Get into a Wall Sit (90-degree knees). Place a small rolled-up mat or block between the thighs. 2. Hold a dumbbell/KB (goblet style). 3. Squeeze the mat/block between your thighs as hard as possible while holding the Wall Sit.
Safety Cue: Maintain the perfect knee angle. The internal squeeze activates the adductor muscles (inner thighs).

Goals: Improve Posture and Balance, Increase overall strength
Contraindications: Acute shoulder pain, elbow pain
Steps to Perform: 1. Lie chest-down on an incline bench, supporting your chest. Hold light dumbbells. 2. With a slight bend in the elbows, raise arms out to the sides (reverse fly), squeezing shoulder blades. 3. Slowly lower back down.
Safety Cue: Keep your head neutral. The incline bench supports the spine and isolates the rear deltoids.

Goals: Rehabilitation & Injury prevention, Improve Flexibility & Mobility
Contraindications: Acute ankle sprain, severe stiffness
Steps to Perform: 1. Sit on floor, legs straight. Loop a light band around one foot and anchor the other end to a fixed object. 2. Eversion: Slowly pull the foot outward against the band. Inversion: Anchor the band opposite and pull the foot inward. 3. Complete all reps slowly in one direction.
Safety Cue: The movement must be controlled and isolated to the ankle joint (no knee movement).

Goals: Increase overall strength, Rehabilitation & Injury prevention
Contraindications: Acute Achilles pain, severe dizziness
Steps to Perform: 1. Stand near a wall, balancing on one foot. Use light support if needed. 2. Slowly lift the heel off the floor, pushing up onto the ball of the foot. 3. Hold briefly at the top, then slowly lower the heel back down.
Safety Cue: Maintain control throughout the movement. Focus on pushing straight up, not letting the ankle roll inward or outward.

Goals: Increase overall strength, Power and Speed
Contraindications: Acute low back pain, shoulder instability
Steps to Perform: 1. Stand over a dumbbell. Hinge down and grip it. 2. Explode up, pulling the dumbbell vertically close to your body. 3. Punch the weight overhead in one fluid motion, finishing with the arm locked out overhead.
Safety Cue: Focus on the hip drive to initiate the lift. Keep the dumbbell close to the body, and maintain a braced core.

Goals: Increase overall strength, Stability
Contraindications: Acute wrist pain, shoulder instability
Steps to Perform: 1. Place feet in the cradles, hands on the floor (High Plank position). 2. Perform a standard push-up. The instability of the straps increases the core demand.
Safety Cue: Maintain a rigid plank position; do not let your hips sag or pike. Control the movement slowly.

Goals: Rehabilitation & Injury prevention, Increase overall strength
Contraindications: Acute knee pain, recent hip surgery
Steps to Perform: 1. Loop a band around one ankle and anchor the other end to a fixed object (low). 2. Step away to create tension. Slowly pull the banded leg straight out to the side. 3. Slowly resist the band as the leg returns to the center.
Safety Cue: Keep your standing leg straight and your torso perfectly upright. Do not lean away from the anchor point.

Exercise Name: Yoga: Half-Kneeling Hip Flexor Stretch (Extended Arm)
Goals: Improve Flexibility & Mobility, Posture
Contraindications: Acute knee pain (use cushion), recent hip surgery
Steps to Perform: 1. Start in a half-kneeling position (lunge). Tuck the pelvis strongly forward. 2. Raise the arm corresponding to the back leg straight overhead. 3. Gently lean the upper body away from the stretched side to deepen the stretch.
Safety Cue: The pelvic tuck is crucial for isolating the hip flexor. Breathe deeply and maintain the core brace.

Exercise Name: Seated Single-Arm Dumbbell Row (Supported on Knee)
Goals: Increase overall strength, Rehabilitation & Injury prevention
Contraindications: Acute shoulder pain, low back pain
Steps to Perform: 1. Sit at the end of a stool, lean forward with a flat back. Support the non-working arm on the inner thigh/knee. 2. Pull the dumbbell to the chest, squeezing the shoulder blade. 3. Slowly lower the weight back down.
Safety Cue: Keep the head neutral and the back flat. Use the support arm to stabilize the torso.

Goals: Increase overall strength, Balance
Contraindications: Acute knee pain, ankle instability
Steps to Perform: 1. Stand on one leg in front of a box. Place hands on hips. 2. Slowly lower down until you lightly tap the box. 3. Drive through the heel of the standing foot to stand back up, keeping hands on hips.
Safety Cue: Choose a box height that challenges you without compromising knee safety or low back posture.

Goals: Increase overall strength
Contraindications: Acute elbow joint pain, shoulder instability
Steps to Perform: 1. Lie on a flat bench, holding one dumbbell with both hands extended over your chest. 2. Slowly lower the dumbbell behind your head by bending the elbows. 3. Extend the arms forcefully, squeezing the triceps.
Safety Cue: Keep your upper arms stationary and pointed towards the ceiling; only the forearms should move.

Goals: Improve Flexibility & Mobility, Rehabilitation & Injury prevention
Contraindications: Acute hamstring strain, sciatica
Reps: 3 cycles (10 sec hold / 5 sec push) / side
Steps to Perform: 1. Lie on back, strap around one foot. Pull leg toward chest for initial stretch (10 sec). 2. Contract: Push heel into the air/strap against your hand resistance (5 sec). 3. Release: Pull the leg farther into the stretch (10 sec). Repeat cycle.
Safety Cue: Breathe deeply during the static holds. The push phase should be a strong contraction (70% effort).

Goals: Increase overall strength, Stability
Contraindications: Acute shoulder pain, recent hip surgery
Steps to Perform: 1. Get into a full side plank (straight legs, prop on forearm). 2. While maintaining the plank, slowly lift the top leg toward the ceiling (abduction). 3. Slowly lower the leg, avoiding touching the bottom leg.
Safety Cue: Keep your hips pressed high and perfectly stable; the only movement should be the top leg lifting.

Goals: Rehabilitation & Injury prevention, Balance
Contraindications: Acute shoulder instability, severe neck pain
Steps to Perform: 1. Sit tall in a chair with back support. Press one light dumbbell straight overhead. 2. Lock the arm out and hold the position, maintaining perfect vertical posture. 3. Resist any tendency for the torso to slump or lean.
Safety Cue: Sit completely upright. This is a safe way to build isometric shoulder endurance and core stability.

Goals: Improve Posture and Balance, Rehabilitation & Injury prevention
Contraindications: Acute shoulder pain, rotator cuff issue
Steps to Perform: 1. Anchor band high. Pull the band toward your face, driving elbows back. 2. Pause and squeeze your shoulder blades together hard for 1-2 seconds at the peak of the pull. 3. Slowly release and repeat.
Safety Cue: Focus on the squeeze. The movement is slow and deliberate, designed for muscle quality, not speed.

Goals: Increase overall strength
Contraindications: Acute knee pain, ankle stiffness
Steps to Perform: 1. Stand with heels elevated on small plates/wedges. Hold one dumbbell vertically at your chest (goblet style). 2. Squat down deep, keeping your chest up and back straight. 3. Drive through the entire foot to stand up.
Safety Cue: The heel elevation allows for a deeper, more upright squat, heavily targeting the quads.

Exercise Name: Wall Sit with Alternating Heel Lift
Goals: Increase overall strength, Rehabilitation & Injury prevention
Contraindications: Acute knee pain, recent Achilles tendon repair
Steps to Perform: 1. Get into a standard Wall Sit position (90-degree knees). 2. While holding the squat, slowly lift the heel of one foot off the floor (calf contraction). 3. Lower the heel and switch sides, maintaining the squat depth.
Safety Cue: Keep your back flat against the wall. The lift should be controlled, not jerky.

Goals: Increase overall strength, Rehabilitation & Injury prevention
Contraindications: Acute wrist pain, carpal tunnel flare-up
Steps to Perform: 1. Sit and rest forearms on your thighs/bench, wrists hanging off the edge. Hold a light barbell or dowel. 2. Slowly curl the wrists up toward the ceiling (extension). 3. Slowly lower the weight back down.
Safety Cue: Only the wrists should move. Use the dowel rod for higher volume/less weight to focus on endurance.

Goals: Increase overall strength, Rehabilitation & Injury prevention
Contraindications: Acute low back pain, unhealed hamstring tear
Steps to Perform: 1. Lie on back, knees bent. Lift one leg straight up (perpendicular to floor). 2. Drive through the heel of the planted foot, lifting hips high and holding for 2 seconds. 3. Slowly lower back down.
Safety Cue: Keep your hips level. Avoid letting the hip of the lifted leg drop or tilt during the hold.

Goals: Improve Flexibility & Mobility, Rehabilitation & Injury prevention
Contraindications: Acute knee pain, severe hip stiffness
Health Benefit: Hip Capsule Lubrication & Range of Motion
Steps to Perform: 1. Start on hands and knees. Lift one bent knee off the floor. 2. Slowly rotate the knee in a large circle (forward, out, back, down). 3. Reverse the circle direction after 10 reps. Switch legs.
Safety Cue: Keep your torso stable and avoid rocking. Control the movement from the hip joint.

Exercise Name: Dumbbell Bench Press (Standard Grip, High Rep)
Goals: Increase overall strength, Endurance
Contraindications: Acute shoulder pain, wrist pain
Steps to Perform: 1. Lie on a flat bench. Hold moderate dumbbells with palms facing feet. 2. Press the weights up quickly but under control. 3. Lower the weights slowly to the chest. Focus on sustained effort.
Safety Cue: Use a weight that allows you to hit the 15-20 rep range without compromising shoulder safety.

Goals: Increase overall strength, Improve Posture and Balance
Contraindications: Acute elbow pain, shoulder pain
Steps to Perform: 1. Sit at the cable row, gripping a D-handle with a neutral grip (palm facing in). 2. Pull the handle back toward your side/ribcage, squeezing the shoulder blade. 3. Slowly let the weight pull the arm forward to full stretch, resisting rotation.
Safety Cue: Keep your torso stable. The neutral grip is often more comfortable for the shoulder joint.

Goals: Improve Flexibility & Mobility, Rehabilitation & Injury prevention
Contraindications: Acute low back pain, uncontrolled blood pressure
Health Benefit: Gentle Low Back Stretch & Core Prep
Steps to Perform: 1. Lie on your back, arms at sides. Slowly lift legs straight up until they are perpendicular to the floor. 2. Gently push the hands into the floor and draw the chin slightly toward the chest. 3. Breathe and hold.
Safety Cue: Keep the legs vertical and focus on lengthening the low back. Do not attempt a full plow pose.

Goals: Increase overall strength, Power and Speed
Contraindications: Acute knee pain, ankle instability
Steps to Perform: 1. Stand in front of a high box/bench. Hold one heavy dumbbell at the side of the same-side leg. 2. Step up with that foot, driving through the heel to stand up on the box. 3. Slowly step back down. Complete all reps on one side.
Safety Cue: Choose a box height that makes the rep challenging. Maintain a vertical torso and strong core brace.

Goals: Increase overall strength, Improve Posture and Balance
Contraindications: Acute shoulder pain, rotator cuff tear
Steps to Perform: 1. Kneel facing the anchor (high pulley). Grip a rope or neutral grip attachment. 2. Pull the handle down toward your thighs, squeezing the lats and depressing the shoulders. 3. Slowly let the weight pull your arms back overhead.
Safety Cue: Keep your core tight and minimize backward lean. The neutral grip is generally safer for the shoulder joint.

Goals: Increase overall strength, Balance
Contraindications: Acute low back pain, severe balance issues
Steps to Perform: 1. Stand on one leg, holding a weight in the opposite hand. Use the free hand lightly on a wall for support. 2. Hinge at the hip, lowering the weight toward the floor, keeping the back flat. 3. Squeeze the glute to drive back up.
Safety Cue: Use the support minimally. Focus on the hip hinge and maintaining a flat, neutral spine.

Goals: Increase overall strength
Contraindications: Acute elbow pain, shoulder pain
Steps to Perform: 1. Sit on an incline bench (about 45 degrees). Let arms hang straight down, palms forward. 2. Curl the weights toward the shoulders. The incline maximizes the bicep stretch at the bottom. 3. Slowly lower the weights back down.
Safety Cue: Keep your back flat against the bench. Do not use momentum; the shoulders should remain stationary.

Goals: Rehabilitation & Injury prevention, Improve Flexibility & Mobility
Contraindications: Acute hip joint pain, recent hip surgery (check doc)
Steps to Perform: 1. Lie on your back, knees bent, feet flat and wide. 2. Slowly drop both knees inward toward each other until your feet are "pigeon-toed." 3. Return the knees to the starting position. Keep the movement slow and controlled.
Safety Cue: Ensure the feet stay planted. The movement should be gentle and pain-free.

Goals: Increase overall strength, Stability
Contraindications: Acute shoulder pain, severe wrist pain
Steps to Perform: 1. Start in a high plank (hands on floor) with shins or tops of feet resting on a stability ball. 2. Maintain a rigid plank position, resisting the instability of the ball.
Safety Cue: Keep the hips low and avoid letting the lower back arch. The shoulders must work hard to stabilize.

Goals: Improve Flexibility & Mobility, Posture
Contraindications: Acute shoulder impingement, lower back pain
Steps to Perform: 1. Lie perpendicular across a bench. Hold one dumbbell over your chest with slightly bent arms. 2. Slowly lower the dumbbell in an arc behind your head, feeling the lat stretch. 3. Pull the dumbbell back over your chest, maintaining the slight elbow bend.
Safety Cue: Keep the bend in your elbows constant throughout the movement. Brace your core to protect the low back.

Goals: Increase overall strength, Power and Speed
Contraindications: Acute knee/ankle pain, severe osteoporosis
Steps to Perform: 1. Stand in front of a low box. Load the hips (small dip). 2. Explode up onto the box, landing softly and simultaneously on both feet. 3. Step back down and reset.
Safety Cue: The landing must be soft and quiet. This is an advanced movement requiring full joint health and control.

Goals: Improve Posture and Balance, Rehabilitation & Injury prevention
Contraindications: Acute shoulder impingement, shoulder adhesive capsulitis
Steps to Perform: 1. Stand against a wall, pressing back/head flat. Hold very light dumbbells in your hands. 2. Slide arms up and down the wall, trying to maintain contact with forearms and hands (and weights).
Safety Cue: The weights increase the difficulty and emphasize the effort to keep the forearms pinned against the wall.

Goals: Increase overall strength
Contraindications: Acute elbow or wrist pain, biceps tendonitis
Steps to Perform: 1. Stand on the middle of the band, holding the ends, palms facing forward. 2. Curl the band up toward the shoulders. The tension increases at the top of the movement. 3. Slowly lower the hands back down, resisting the band.
Safety Cue: Keep your elbows pinned to your sides. The band offers accommodating resistance, maximizing tension at the peak contraction.

Goals: Improve Flexibility & Mobility, Posture
Contraindications: Acute shoulder pain, severe shoulder instability
Steps to Perform: 1. Lie lengthwise along a foam roller, supporting head and tailbone. Knees bent, feet flat. 2. Let arms fall out to the sides with palms up, allowing gravity to open the chest. 3. Relax the shoulders and breathe deeply.
Safety Cue: The roller supports the spine and allows for a passive, deep stretch across the chest and front of the shoulders.

Goals: Increase overall strength
Contraindications: Acute elbow pain, shoulder pain
Steps to Perform: 1. Sit on an incline bench (about 60-70 degrees). Hold dumbbells at your sides, palms forward. 2. Curl the weights up, trying to keep the upper arm stationary. 3. Slowly lower the weights.
Safety Cue: The incline angle prevents swinging and uses the bench to stabilize the upper arm.

Goals: Rehabilitation & Injury prevention, Improve Flexibility & Mobility
Contraindications: Acute hip joint pain, knee instability
Steps to Perform: 1. Loop a band around one ankle and anchor it to a fixed object on the same side. 2. Stand tall. Slowly pull the banded leg inward against the band tension (internal rotation). 3. Slowly release and repeat.
Safety Cue: Keep your knee slightly bent and your torso stable. The movement is small and isolated to the hip capsule.

Goals: Rehabilitation & Injury prevention, Balance
Contraindications: Acute low back pain, severe balance issues
Steps to Perform: 1. Stand on one leg, holding a light dumbbell in the opposite hand. Use the free hand lightly on a wall for support. 2. Perform a small, controlled hip hinge. 3. Return to standing. Keep the hinge minimal for safety and balance.
Safety Cue: Use the wall for balance. Focus on the hip movement and maintaining a flat back.

Goals: Increase overall strength, Improve Posture and Balance
Contraindications: Acute wrist pain (use fists), severe shoulder pain
Steps to Perform: 1. Sit on the floor, legs straight, hands behind your hips, fingers facing feet. 2. Press through hands and heels to lift hips off the floor, forming a straight line from head to heels. 3. Keep the glutes squeezed and core tight.
Safety Cue: Keep your hips high and avoid letting them sag. Gaze towards your toes or ceiling.

Goals: Increase overall strength
Contraindications: Acute spinal disc injury, unhealed hernia
Steps to Perform: 1. Lie on your back, knees bent. Extend arms straight back over your head. 2. Curl head and shoulders up, reaching hands toward the ceiling/wall behind you. 3. Slowly lower back down.
Safety Cue: The extended arms increase the lever length, making the crunch more difficult. Focus on controlling the movement.

Goals: Increase overall strength, Rehabilitation & Injury prevention
Contraindications: Acute spinal disc injury, unhealed hernia
Steps to Perform: 1. Sit on the floor, knees bent, feet flat on the ground. Lean back slightly, maintaining a straight back. 2. Hold a light weight. Slowly twist the torso from side to side, tapping the weight next to your hips.
Safety Cue: Planting the feet provides stability, making this a safer, lower-level core rotation exercise.

Goals: Improve Posture and Balance, Rehabilitation & Injury prevention
Contraindications: Severe dizziness, acute ankle sprain
Steps to Perform: 1. Stand on one leg. Slowly cross both arms over the chest, then quickly open them wide. 2. Maintain balance throughout the crossing and opening movement.
Safety Cue: Focus on a stable base. The arm movement creates a shifting balance challenge.

Goals: Increase overall strength, Stability
Contraindications: Acute knee pain, ankle instability
Steps to Perform: 1. Stand holding a KB vertically at your chest (goblet style). 2. Step one foot straight back and lower into a lunge. 3. Drive through the front heel to return to standing.
Safety Cue: Maintain an upright torso by bracing the core against the weight. Focus on a controlled descent.

Goals: Rehabilitation & Injury prevention, Improve Posture and Balance
Contraindications: Acute wrist pain, shoulder instability
Steps to Perform: 1. Start in a high plank (hands under shoulders). Keep arms straight. 2. Protraction: Push your upper back toward the ceiling, rounding the shoulders slightly. 3. Retraction: Let your shoulder blades pinch together, dropping the chest slightly. Move only the shoulder blades.
Safety Cue: Keep your core tight and your elbows locked. The movement is small and focused entirely on the shoulder blades.

Exercise Name: Wall Sit with Alternating Knee March
Goals: Rehabilitation & Injury prevention, Balance
Contraindications: Acute knee pain, severe weakness
Steps to Perform: 1. Get into a comfortable Wall Sit position (e.g., 45-degree knee bend). 2. Slowly lift one foot off the floor and bring the knee up (march). 3. Place the foot down and immediately switch to the other side.
Safety Cue: Maintain contact with the wall and keep the hips as level as possible during the marching.

Goals: Increase overall strength
Contraindications: Acute elbow pain, wrist pain
Steps to Perform: 1. Lie on a bench. Hold one dumbbell straight up over your chest. 2. Keeping the upper arm vertical, slowly bend the elbow to lower the dumbbell toward the ear. 3. Extend the arm, squeezing the tricep.
Safety Cue: Use the free hand to touch the working tricep to ensure muscle activation. Control the weight carefully.

Goals: Increase overall strength, Improve Posture and Balance
Contraindications: Acute low back pain, shoulder impingement
Steps to Perform: 1. Sit on the floor, legs straight. Loop the band around the soles of your feet. 2. Grip the ends. Sit tall with a straight back. Pull the band toward your lower abdomen. 3. Squeeze shoulder blades, then slowly release.
Safety Cue: Maintain the upright, rigid back throughout the pull. Avoid rounding forward excessively on the release.

Goals: Rehabilitation & Injury prevention, Increase overall strength
Contraindications: Acute knee pain, groin strain
Steps to Perform: 1. Lie on your side. Loop a mini-band around the ankles. Place the top foot on the floor in front of the bottom knee. 2. Slowly lift the bottom leg up toward the ceiling against the band tension. 3. Slowly lower the leg back down.
Safety Cue: Keep the bottom leg straight and focus on the inner thigh (adductor) contraction.

Goals: Improve Flexibility & Mobility, Rehabilitation & Injury prevention
Contraindications: Acute knee pain, severe balance issues
Steps to Perform: 1. Stand near a wall/chair for support. Bend one knee and gently pull the heel back toward the glute (like a standing quad stretch). 2. Tuck the pelvis slightly to feel the stretch higher in the hip flexor area.
Safety Cue: Use the support fully for balance. Focus on the subtle pelvic tuck to intensify the stretch.

Goals: Increase overall strength
Contraindications: Acute low back pain, unhealed hernia
Steps to Perform: 1. Sit with upper back against a bench, barbell across hips (use pad). 2. Drive through the feet to lift hips high, finishing with the body in a straight line from shoulders to knees. 3. Squeeze glutes hard at the top. Slowly lower down.
Safety Cue: Ensure a strong, rigid core and minimal knee flare-out. The goal is maximum glute contraction.

Goals: Increase overall strength, Improve Posture and Balance
Contraindications: Acute low back pain, severe neck pain
Steps to Perform: 1. Lie face down on the mat, arms extended forward. 2. Slowly lift the opposite arm and leg simultaneously a few inches off the floor. 3. Hold briefly, then slowly lower and switch sides.
Safety Cue: Keep the head neutral (looking down). Focus on slow, controlled lifting and lowering, avoiding jerky movements.

Goals: Increase overall strength, Power and Speed
Contraindications: Acute spinal disc injury, severe knee pain
Steps to Perform: 1. Kneel beside a high cable pulley. Grip the handle with both hands. 2. Pull the handle diagonally down and across your body toward the opposite hip (the knee that is up). 3. Control the handle back up slowly.
Safety Cue: Keep the movement powerful but controlled. The core must brace strongly to decelerate the weight.

Goals: Increase overall strength
Contraindications: Acute elbow pain, shoulder pain
Steps to Perform: 1. Stand tall, holding dumbbells at your sides, palms facing forward. 2. Curl one dumbbell up and across your body toward the opposite shoulder. 3. Squeeze the bicep hard at the top. Slowly lower and repeat on the same side.
Safety Cue: This variation changes the angle of the resistance, increasing the isolation on the bicep peak.

Goals: Rehabilitation & Injury prevention, Balance
Contraindications: Acute knee pain, severe weakness
Steps to Perform: 1. Step into a lunge position (front knee over ankle, back knee low). 2. Use a wall or chair for light fingertip support. 3. Hold the lowest comfortable position rigidly for time.
Safety Cue: Ensure the front knee is properly aligned. Use the support only to maintain balance, not to hold the body weight.

Goals: Rehabilitation & Injury prevention, Increase overall strength
Contraindications: Acute hip joint pain, unhealed groin strain
Steps to Perform: 1. Lie on your side, knees bent 90 degrees (like a clamshell start). 2. Keep the feet together. Lift the top knee up. 3. Now, keeping the knee bent, lift the entire top leg up a few inches (Abduction). Slowly lower.
Safety Cue: This small, controlled lift isolates the glute medius without much joint stress.

Goals: Increase overall strength
Contraindications: Acute knee pain, low back pain
Steps to Perform: 1. Stand in front of a box. Squat down very slowly (e.g., counting to 4) until you lightly tap the box. 2. Stand back up at a normal pace.
Safety Cue: The slow descent maximizes muscle fiber recruitment and control, improving joint stability.

Exercise Name: Seated Dumbbell Shoulder Press (No Back Support)
Goals: Increase overall strength, Stability
Contraindications: Acute shoulder instability, severe low back pain
Steps to Perform: 1. Sit upright on a bench with no back support. Hold dumbbells racked at shoulder height. 2. Press the dumbbells straight overhead. 3. Slowly lower. The core must work extremely hard to prevent the spine from collapsing.
Safety Cue: Use lighter weights than you would typically use with back support. Maintain a neutral, rigid spine.

Goals: Increase overall strength, Rehabilitation & Injury prevention
Contraindications: Acute spinal disc injury, unhealed hernia
Steps to Perform: 1. Lie on your back, legs straight up. 2. Slowly lower the legs toward the floor, counting to 5 (or more), stopping before the low back arches. 3. Return to the top (or bend knees to reset).
Safety Cue: The focus is on the slow, controlled lowering. Keep the low back pressed into the floor at all times.

Goals: Increase overall strength, Rehabilitation & Injury prevention
Contraindications: Acute wrist pain, carpal tunnel flare-up
Steps to Perform: 1. Sit and rest forearms on your thighs/bench, wrists hanging off the edge, palms up. Hold a light barbell or dowel. 2. Slowly curl the wrists up toward the ceiling (flexion). 3. Slowly lower the weight back down.
Safety Cue: Only the wrists should move. The dowel rod allows for high-volume, isolated work for endurance.

Goals: Improve Flexibility & Mobility, Reduce Stress
Contraindications: Acute spinal disc injury, severe wrist pain
Steps to Perform: 1. Start on hands and knees. 2. Focus on the Cow Pose (dropping the belly, lifting the tailbone, gentle extension) for the majority of the movement. The Cat Pose transition is brief.
Safety Cue: Prioritize the gentle arch and opening of the chest, maintaining a fluid, breath-led rhythm.

Goals: Increase overall strength, Improve Posture and Balance
Contraindications: Acute shoulder impingement, unhealed rib fracture
Health Benefit: Mid-Back Isolation with No Spinal Load
Steps to Perform: 1. Lie chest down on an incline bench. Hold one dumbbell. 2. Pull the weight up toward the chest, driving the elbow high and squeezing the shoulder blade. 3. Slowly lower the weight back down.
Safety Cue: The bench eliminates core strain, allowing for complete isolation of the upper back musculature.

Goals: Improve Posture and Balance, Rehabilitation & Injury prevention
Contraindications: Acute shoulder pain, biceps tendonitis
Steps to Perform: 1. Hold the band taut in front of your chest with straight arms (or slight bend). 2. Pull your arms apart in an arc until they are extended out to the sides. 3. Squeeze the shoulder blades hard. Slowly bring the arms back to the front.
Safety Cue: Maintain straight arms and focus on pinching the shoulder blades together, not just moving the hands.

Goals: Improve cardiovascular fitness, Coordination
Contraindications: Acute knee pain, severe ankle stiffness
Steps to Perform: 1. Sit upright. Alternately tap the toe of one foot and then the heel of the same foot quickly, followed by the opposite foot. 2. Maintain a very quick, continuous, rhythmic "tap-tap" motion for the duration.
Safety Cue: Keep the rhythm fast to elevate the heart rate. Focus on minimal movement in the rest of the body.

Goals: Improve Flexibility & Mobility, Rehabilitation & Injury prevention
Contraindications: Acute knee pain (use cushion), recent hip surgery
Steps to Perform: 1. Start in a half-kneeling lunge. Tuck the pelvis forward. 2. Slowly rock the hips forward one inch to deepen the stretch, then rock back one inch. 3. Maintain the pelvic tuck and continuously "pulse" forward and back in a small range.
Safety Cue: The pulsing motion allows the tissue to actively lengthen and is safer than a static, forced hold.

Goals: Increase overall strength
Contraindications: Acute knee pain, low back pain
Steps to Perform: 1. Use a lower box (challenging depth). Squat down very slowly (4-5 second descent) until you lightly tap the box. 2. Stand back up explosively.
Safety Cue: This variation combines maximal safe depth with heavy eccentric (lowering) control.

Goals: Increase overall strength, Power and Speed
Contraindications: Acute low back/shoulder pain, high blood pressure
Steps to Perform: 1. Hold a dumbbell racked at the shoulder. Squat down deep. 2. Explode up from the squat, driving the dumbbell straight overhead in one fluid motion. 3. Catch the weight at the shoulder as you descend into the next squat.
Safety Cue: The power comes from the legs/hips. The arm acts as a guide to punch the weight overhead.

Goals: Increase overall strength, Flexibility & Mobility
Contraindications: Acute spinal disc injury, severe low back pain
Steps to Perform: 1. Lie on your back, knees bent 90 degrees (shins parallel to floor). Arms spread wide. 2. Slowly lower both knees to one side, only as far as you can without letting the opposite shoulder lift. 3. Pull the knees back to the center using your core. Alternate sides.
Safety Cue: Keep both shoulders pinned to the floor. The movement is slow and highly controlled by the core.

Goals: Increase overall strength, Rehabilitation & Injury prevention
Contraindications: Acute wrist pain, recent chest surgery
Steps to Perform: 1. Stand in a wide stance, facing a wall. Place hands flat on the wall at chest height (like a push-up start). 2. Lean forward and push into the wall as hard as you can (or at a comfortable intensity). 3. Hold the maximal contraction.
Safety Cue: The resistance is your own effort. Focus on bracing the core and contracting the chest and shoulders strongly.

Goals: Rehabilitation & Injury prevention, Increase overall strength
Contraindications: Acute knee pain, severe sciatica
Steps to Perform: 1. Sit upright near the edge of a chair. Extend one leg straight out in front of you, heel on the floor. 2. Lift the heel a few inches off the floor, contracting the quad. 3. Tap the heel gently back down. Repeat continuously on one leg.
Safety Cue: Keep your back straight and avoid leaning back. Focus on the squeeze in the front of the thigh.

Goals: Increase overall strength, Power and Speed
Contraindications: Acute low back pain, shoulder instability
Steps to Perform: 1. Stand over a dumbbell. Hinge down and grip it. 2. Explode up (hip drive), quickly flipping the dumbbell to the shoulder (the clean). 3. Immediately press the dumbbell overhead (the press). Lower with control.
Safety Cue: The clean and the press are two distinct, powerful movements. Maintain a tight core brace throughout.

Goals: Increase overall strength, Stability
Contraindications: Acute wrist pain, shoulder impingement
Steps to Perform: 1. Place feet on a box/bench. Hands on the floor. Push hips high, forming a rigid inverted 'V' position. 2. Hold the position perfectly still.
Safety Cue: Ensure the legs and back are straight. Focus on maintaining the high hip angle and pushing the head through the shoulders.

Goals: Improve Posture and Balance, Rehabilitation & Injury prevention
Contraindications: Acute low back pain, shoulder impingement
Steps to Perform: 1. Stand on the middle of the band. Hinge at the hips with a flat back (bent-over position). 2. With arms mostly straight, raise them out to the sides (reverse fly motion) against band tension. 3. Slowly lower the hands back down.
Safety Cue: Keep the back flat and the hinge constant. Focus the movement on the rear of the shoulders.

Goals: Improve Flexibility & Mobility, Reduce Stress
Contraindications: Acute knee pain, severe hip stiffness
Health Benefit: Lateral Spinal Stretch & Inner Thigh Opening
Steps to Perform: 1. Kneel. Extend one leg straight out to the side, foot flat. 2. Lean the torso to the side of the extended leg, letting the hand rest on the leg. 3. Extend the opposite arm over the head, reaching for the foot.
Safety Cue: Maintain the knee/foot alignment of the extended leg. Avoid crunching the torso forward.

Goals: Increase overall strength
Contraindications: Acute shoulder impingement, neck tension
Steps to Perform: 1. Sit on a bench (no back support), holding dumbbells at your sides. 2. Raise arms out to the sides until they reach shoulder height (no higher). 3. Slowly lower the weights back down, controlling the descent.
Safety Cue: Sit tall and avoid using momentum or leaning back. Focus the lift purely on the side of the shoulder.

Goals: Rehabilitation & Injury prevention, Increase overall strength
Contraindications: Acute wrist pain (use fists), severe low back pain
Steps to Perform: 1. Start in a reverse plank position (hips lifted, body straight). 2. While maintaining the plank, slowly lift one heel off the floor (calf raise). 3. Lower the heel and switch.
Safety Cue: Keep your hips lifted high and level throughout the alternating heel raise movement.

Goals: Increase overall strength
Contraindications: Acute shoulder pain, severe low back pain
Steps to Perform: 1. Lie on your side, holding a light dumbbell. Extend the arm holding the dumbbell straight up. 2. Slowly lift the dumbbell and the torso/upper body off the floor (side crunch motion). 3. Slowly lower back down. This is a weighted side-lying crunch.
Safety Cue: Keep the body straight and the movement slow. Focus the contraction on the side of the torso.

Goals: Improve Posture and Balance, Rehabilitation & Injury prevention
Contraindications: Severe dizziness, acute ankle sprain
Steps to Perform: 1. Stand on one leg. Lift the opposite foot slightly. 2. Slowly nod your head "yes" (up and down) 10 times, then nod "no" (side to side) 10 times, while maintaining balance.
Safety Cue: Keep the standing knee soft and the core braced. Go slowly to avoid dizziness.

Goals: Increase overall strength
Contraindications: Acute shoulder pain, wrist pain
Steps to Perform: 1. Sit on a bench edge, hands by hips. Walk feet out so legs are straight and heels are on the floor. 2. Lower hips toward the floor by bending the elbows (tracking backward). 3. Push forcefully back up to the start.
Safety Cue: The straight legs significantly increase the load on the triceps and shoulders. Keep the back close to the bench.

Goals: Increase overall strength, Rehabilitation & Injury prevention
Contraindications: Acute elbow or wrist pain, shoulder instability
Steps to Perform: 1. Sit in a chair with back support. Hold a dumbbell with palm facing up (supinated grip). 2. Keep the elbow pinned to the side. Curl the weight toward the shoulder. 3. Slowly lower the weight back down.
Safety Cue: Use the backrest to prevent leaning or swinging, ensuring the bicep does the work.

Goals: Improve Flexibility & Mobility, Rehabilitation & Injury prevention
Contraindications: Acute hip joint pain, severe stiffness
Steps to Perform: 1. Stand holding onto a wall/chair for full support. 2. Slowly swing one leg out to the side and then gently cross it in front of the standing leg. 3. Maintain a continuous, gentle arc.
Safety Cue: Use the support fully. The movement should be controlled, pain-free, and focus on lubrication of the hip joint.

Goals: Increase overall strength, Stability
Contraindications: Acute wrist pain, shoulder instability
Steps to Perform: 1. Start in a high reverse plank position (hands and heels on floor, hips lifted). 2. While maintaining the plank, slowly tuck one knee toward your chest. 3. Extend the leg back to the plank position and alternate sides.
Safety Cue: Keep your hips lifted high and level; avoid letting the hips drop or tilt during the tuck.

Goals: Increase overall strength
Contraindications: Acute shoulder pain, wrist pain
Steps to Perform: 1. Lie on a flat bench. Hold dumbbells close together over your chest (palms facing in, neutral grip). 2. Lower the weights slowly toward the lower chest/ribs. 3. Press the weights straight up, squeezing the triceps.
Safety Cue: The close, neutral grip places maximum emphasis on the triceps and inner chest fibers.

Goals: Rehabilitation & Injury prevention, Improve Posture and Balance
Contraindications: Acute shoulder instability, biceps tendonitis
Steps to Perform: 1. Lie on your side, elbow bent 90 degrees, upper arm resting on your torso. Loop a mini-band around your wrists/forearms. 2. Slowly rotate the top forearm up toward the ceiling against the band tension. 3. Slowly return to the starting position.
Safety Cue: Keep the upper arm pinned to your side. The movement is small and focused on the deep shoulder muscles.

Goals: Increase overall strength
Contraindications: Acute knee pain, ankle stiffness
Steps to Perform: 1. Hold weight goblet style. Slowly squat down, taking 4 seconds to reach the bottom. 2. Pause briefly. Drive up quickly.
Safety Cue: The slow descent improves muscle endurance and joint stability by maximizing time under tension.

Goals: Increase overall strength, Balance
Contraindications: Acute knee pain, severe weakness
Steps to Perform: 1. Step into a low lunge position (front knee over ankle, back knee low). 2. Maintain the lowest comfortable position rigidly for time, hands on hips or overhead.
Safety Cue: Keep the torso vertical and the core braced. The longer hold increases muscle fatigue.

Goals: Increase overall strength, Power and Speed
Contraindications: Acute spinal disc injury, severe knee pain
Steps to Perform: 1. Kneel beside a low cable pulley. Grip the handle with both hands. 2. Pull the handle diagonally up and across your body toward the opposite shoulder. 3. Control the handle back down slowly.
Safety Cue: Initiate the movement from the hips and core. Maintain a rigid, stable torso; don't let the weight pull you down.

Goals: Increase overall strength, Rehabilitation & Injury prevention
Contraindications: Acute shoulder impingement, neck tension
Steps to Perform: 1. Sit with back support. Hold a light dumbbell. 2. Slowly lift the dumbbell straight up in front of you to shoulder height. 3. Slowly lower the weight back down.
Safety Cue: Use the back support to eliminate leaning and isolate the front deltoid muscle.

Exercise Name: Lying Tricep Extension (Dumbbell, Single Arm, Neutral Grip)
Goals: Increase overall strength
Contraindications: Acute elbow pain, wrist pain
Steps to Perform: 1. Lie on a bench. Hold one dumbbell straight up over your chest with a neutral grip (palm facing in). 2. Keeping the upper arm vertical, bend the elbow to lower the dumbbell toward the ear. 3. Extend the arm, squeezing the tricep.
Safety Cue: The neutral grip often reduces stress on the elbow joint compared to the standard pronated grip.

Goals: Rehabilitation & Injury prevention, Stability
Contraindications: Acute wrist pain, low back pain
Steps to Perform: 1. Start on hands and knees. Simultaneously lift opposite arm/leg. 2. Focus intently on squeezing the glute of the extended leg at the top, ensuring the foot lifts no higher than the hip. 3. Control the return.
Safety Cue: Avoid arching the low back. The lift should stop at hip level, driven by the glute, not the back.

Goals: Increase overall strength, Power and Speed
Contraindications: Acute knee/ankle pain, severe osteoporosis
Steps to Perform: 1. Stand on one leg. Perform a large, forceful jump sideways onto the opposite foot. 2. Land softly, absorb the force, and immediately jump back to the starting side.
Safety Cue: Focus on maximizing distance and vertical height. Requires excellent joint health and control.

Goals: Rehabilitation & Injury prevention, Increase overall strength
Contraindications: Acute knee pain, post-op recovery
Steps to Perform: 1. Sit on floor/bed, leg straight. Place a small rolled towel under the knee. 2. Press the back of the knee down into the towel, simultaneously tightening the thigh muscle as hard as possible. 3. Hold the maximal tension for 5 seconds. Relax and repeat.
Safety Cue: This is an isometric exercise. Focus solely on the intensity of the muscle contraction, not on lifting the leg.

Goals: Increase overall strength, Rehabilitation & Injury prevention
Contraindications: Acute shoulder instability, wrist pain
Health Benefit: Chest Strength with Neutral Shoulder Position
Steps to Perform: 1. Lie on the floor. Hold dumbbells with palms facing each other (neutral grip). 2. Press the dumbbells straight up. 3. Slowly lower until upper arms lightly touch the floor.
Safety Cue: The neutral grip often places the shoulder in a more stable, comfortable position than the standard grip.

Goals: Rehabilitation & Injury prevention, Improve Flexibility & Mobility
Contraindications: Acute ankle sprain, severe stiffness
Reps: Write 1 set of the alphabet / foot
Steps to Perform: 1. Sit tall in a chair. Lift one foot slightly off the floor. 2. Use the ankle/foot to slowly "write" the letters of the alphabet in the air. 3. Focus on large, distinct letters.
Safety Cue: Keep the knee and shin still. The movement should be concentrated only at the ankle joint for mobility.

Exercise Name: Lying Tricep Extension (Single Dumbbell, Two Hands)
Goals: Increase overall strength
Contraindications: Acute elbow pain, shoulder pain
Steps to Perform: 1. Lie on a bench. Hold one dumbbell with both hands (palms under the weight) extended over your chest. 2. Slowly lower the dumbbell behind your head by bending both elbows. 3. Extend the arms forcefully back overhead.
Safety Cue: Using two hands on one dumbbell is great for heavier loads with a single weight, increasing tricep focus.

Goals: Rehabilitation & Injury prevention, Increase overall strength
Contraindications: Acute knee pain, severe ankle stiffness
Steps to Perform: 1. Place a mini-band around your knees. Get into a slight quarter-squat stance. 2. Step sideways (laterally), pushing the leading knee out to maintain band tension. 3. Complete all reps in one direction, then reverse.
Safety Cue: The band placement at the knees increases the leverage and demand on the glutes compared to the ankles.

Goals: Improve Posture and Balance, Rehabilitation & Injury prevention
Contraindications: Severe dizziness, acute ankle sprain
Steps to Perform: 1. Stand on one leg. Lift the opposite foot slightly. 2. Place both hands behind your head (like a crunch starting position). 3. Hold the balance rigidly.
Safety Cue: Shifting the hands overhead significantly raises the center of gravity, increasing the difficulty of the balance.

Goals: Increase overall strength, Improve Posture and Balance
Contraindications: Acute shoulder pain, elbow pain
Steps to Perform: 1. Sit at the cable row. Grip the wide straight bar. 2. Pull the bar toward the upper abdomen/chest, flaring the elbows out wide. 3. Focus on squeezing the middle of the upper back. Slowly extend arms.
Safety Cue: The wide grip emphasizes the outer lats and middle trapezius muscles. Control the forward stretch.

Goals: Rehabilitation & Injury prevention, Stability
Contraindications: Acute spinal disc injury, unhealed abdominal separation
Steps to Perform: 1. Lie on back, knees bent 90. Arms straight up. Towel under low back. 2. Keep arms straight up. Slowly extend only one leg toward the floor. 3. Focus on crushing the towel with the low back. Return the leg and alternate.
Safety Cue: The arms stay static and the tension is maintained by resisting the lever of the moving leg.

Goals: Increase overall strength, Balance
Contraindications: Acute low back pain, severe hamstring tightness
Steps to Perform: 1. Stand on one leg, holding a dumbbell in the hand on the same side as the standing leg. 2. Hinge at the hip, keeping the back flat. 3. Drive through the heel to stand up.
Safety Cue: Loading the same side significantly increases the core's anti-rotation challenge and standing glute demand.

Goals: Increase overall strength, Improve Posture and Balance
Contraindications: Acute shoulder pain, elbow pain
Steps to Perform: 1. Stand facing the anchor (mid-chest height). Grip the opposite cable handle. 2. Pull the handle across and back, aiming to pull the arm straight out to the side (reverse fly motion). 3. Slowly resist the cable back to the start.
Safety Cue: Keep the arm mostly straight and focus the squeeze on the rear of the shoulder blade.

Goals: Increase overall strength
Contraindications: Acute Achilles pain, severe foot pain
Steps to Perform: 1. Sit on a bench, balls of feet elevated on a plate. Place a heavy dumbbell across your lower thighs near the knee. 2. Lower the heels deep. Slowly push up onto the balls of your feet. 3. Squeeze the calves at the top.
Safety Cue: Keep the back straight. The seated position isolates the Soleus muscle, which is key for endurance.

Goals: Increase overall strength, Power and Speed
Contraindications: Acute knee/ankle pain, severe osteoporosis
Steps to Perform: 1. Stand beside a low box/step. Jump laterally (sideways) up onto the box, landing softly on both feet. 2. Step or jump back down to the start and immediately jump up to the opposite side.
Safety Cue: Focus on a stable, centered landing on the box. Control the lateral push-off.

Goals: Increase overall strength, Improve cardiovascular fitness
Contraindications: Acute knee pain, severe weakness
Steps to Perform: 1. Stand tall. Step one foot straight back and lower into a lunge. 2. Drive through the front heel to return to standing. 3. Maintain a quick, continuous pace with strict form.
Safety Cue: Focus on keeping the torso vertical and the front knee tracking over the foot.

Goals: Rehabilitation & Injury prevention, Improve Flexibility & Mobility
Contraindications: Acute shoulder instability, severe impingement
Steps to Perform: 1. Stand holding a mini-band anchored at elbow height. Elbow bent 90 degrees, upper arm pinned to side. 2. Slowly pull the forearm across your stomach against the band tension (internal rotation). 3. Slowly return to the starting position.
Safety Cue: Keep the upper arm stationary. The movement is small and focused only on the internal rotation of the shoulder.

Exercise Name: Lying Straight Leg Raise (Assisted, Eccentric Focus)
Goals: Rehabilitation & Injury prevention, Increase overall strength
Contraindications: Acute spinal disc injury, unhealed hernia
Steps to Perform: 1. Lie on back. Use a strap to assist in raising one leg straight up. 2. Once at the top, remove strap and slowly lower the leg to the floor, taking 5 seconds. 3. Do not let the low back arch.
Safety Cue: The focus is on the slow, controlled lowering without spinal movement, maximizing lower ab control.

Goals: Increase overall strength, Stability
Contraindications: Acute shoulder instability, low back pain
Steps to Perform: 1. Sit with back support. Hold dumbbells racked at shoulder height. 2. Press one dumbbell overhead. As it descends, press the opposite dumbbell up. 3. Maintain a continuous, controlled alternation.
Safety Cue: The alternating load increases the core's demand for trunk stability throughout the set.

Goals: Improve Posture and Balance, Rehabilitation & Injury prevention
Contraindications: Severe dizziness, acute ankle sprain
Health Benefit: Dynamic Balance & Center of Mass Shift
Steps to Perform: 1. Stand on one leg. Lift the opposite foot slightly. 2. Extend the opposite arm straight up and slowly perform a small circle or reach as far as possible in a continuous motion.
Safety Cue: The arm reach shifts the center of gravity, challenging the standing ankle and core.

Goals: Increase overall strength, Rehabilitation & Injury prevention
Contraindications: Acute wrist pain, carpal tunnel flare-up
Steps to Perform: 1. Sit and rest forearm on thigh/bench, palm up, wrist hanging off. Loop mini-band around hand/fingers and under foot. 2. Slowly curl the wrist up against band tension. 3. Slowly lower.
Safety Cue: The band provides accommodating resistance, maximizing tension at the top of the wrist curl.

Goals: Increase overall strength, Stability
Contraindications: Acute shoulder pain, spinal disc injury
Steps to Perform: 1. Kneel facing the anchor. Hold handles at chest height. 2. Lean forward, letting arms extend overhead (like a kneeling plank). 3. Slowly pull handles back to the chest, resisting the urge to arch the low back.
Safety Cue: Maintain a perfect plank (straight line from shoulder to knee) throughout the entire movement.

Goals: Increase overall strength, Improve Posture and Balance
Contraindications: Acute shoulder pain, elbow pain
Steps to Perform: 1. Lie chest down on an incline bench. Hold one dumbbell. 2. Pull the weight up toward the side/chest, keeping the elbow close. 3. Slowly lower. Focus on the squeeze in the mid-back.
Safety Cue: Supporting the chest eliminates low back and core fatigue, allowing maximal focus on the back muscles.

Goals: Improve Flexibility & Mobility, Rehabilitation & Injury prevention
Contraindications: Acute knee pain, severe sciatica
Health Benefit: Active Hip Flexor Range of Motion
Steps to Perform: 1. Sit upright. Bend one knee. 2. Hook your hands or a strap around the front of the ankle/foot of the opposite leg. 3. Gently pull the knee/thigh up toward the chest as high as possible without rounding the low back. Slowly release.
Safety Cue: Use the hands for gentle assistance to guide the thigh into high flexion.

Goals: Increase overall strength, Power and Speed
Contraindications: Acute spinal disc injury, shoulder pain
Steps to Perform: 1. Stand beside a high cable pulley. Grip the handle. 2. Pull the handle diagonally down and across the body toward the opposite hip, pivoting on the back foot. 3. Control the handle back up slowly.
Safety Cue: Allow the back foot to pivot (heel lifts) to enable safe rotation through the hips and torso.

Goals: Improve Flexibility & Mobility, Rehabilitation & Injury prevention
Contraindications: Acute hamstring strain, severe sciatica
Health Benefit: Deep Trigger Point Release & Soft Tissue Health
Steps to Perform: 1. Sit on the floor. Place a tennis ball/lacrosse ball under one hamstring. Use hands for support. 2. Roll slowly back and forth over the ball, searching for tender spots. 3. Pause on very tender spots for 10-15 seconds.
Safety Cue: Use caution. The ball applies intense pressure; control the pressure by leaning on your hands.

Goals: Increase overall strength
Contraindications: Acute wrist pain, severe tennis elbow
Steps to Perform: 1. Stand tall. Hold dumbbells at sides, palms facing in (hammer grip). 2. Curl one dumbbell up and across your body toward the opposite shoulder. 3. Slowly lower.
Safety Cue: Combining the cross-body path with the hammer grip maximizes the contraction of the outer bicep and forearm muscles.

Goals: Increase overall strength, Flexibility & Mobility
Contraindications: Acute spinal disc injury, severe low back pain
Steps to Perform: 1. Lie on your back, legs straight up (perpendicular to floor). Arms spread wide. 2. Slowly lower both straight legs to one side, only as far as you can without the opposite shoulder lifting. 3. Pull the legs back to the center using the core. Alternate sides.
Safety Cue: The straight legs create a maximal lever, demanding high rotational strength and core control.

Goals: Increase overall strength, Improve Posture and Balance
Contraindications: Acute knee pain (use cushion), shoulder pain
Steps to Perform: 1. Kneel in a half-kneeling position facing the anchor. Grip the handle with a neutral grip. 2. Pull the handle toward your side/ribcage, squeezing the back muscle. 3. Slowly return the handle, resisting the forward pull.
Safety Cue: The half-kneeling position increases core stability and ensures a vertical pull angle.

Goals: Rehabilitation & Injury prevention, Balance
Contraindications: Severe dizziness, acute ankle sprain
Steps to Perform: 1. Stand on one leg (use support). Lift the opposite foot slightly. 2. While balancing, slowly raise the heel of the standing foot (calf raise). 3. Slowly lower the heel back down, maintaining balance.
Safety Cue: Use the support to challenge the single-leg stance without risk of a fall.

Goals: Rehabilitation & Injury prevention, Improve Posture and Balance
Contraindications: Acute wrist pain, low back pain
Steps to Perform: 1. Start on hands and knees. Simultaneously lift and extend the opposite arm and leg. 2. Hold the fully extended position rigidly for 5-10 seconds. 3. Slowly return to the floor.
Safety Cue: Focus on remaining perfectly still during the hold; any wobbling indicates instability.

Goals: Increase overall strength
Contraindications: Acute shoulder pain, wrist pain
Steps to Perform: 1. Lie on a bench. Grip the bar much wider than shoulder-width. 2. Lower the bar slowly to the chest. 3. Press the bar straight up. Requires good shoulder mobility.
Safety Cue: The wide grip places increased stress on the chest (pecs) but can be stressful on the shoulder joint; use with caution.

Goals: Increase overall strength, Power and Speed
Contraindications: Acute spinal disc injury, shoulder pain
Steps to Perform: 1. Stand beside a low cable pulley. Grip the handle. 2. Pull the handle diagonally up and across the body toward the opposite shoulder, pivoting on the back foot. 3. Control the handle back down slowly.
Safety Cue: Allow the back foot to pivot (heel lifts) to enable safe rotation through the hips and torso.

Goals: Increase overall strength, Improve Posture and Balance
Contraindications: Acute shoulder instability, severe neck pain
Steps to Perform: 1. Stand tall, holding one dumbbell overhead and the other at your side. 2. Walk slowly. After 5 steps, seamlessly switch the dumbbells (the one at the side goes overhead, and vice versa). 3. Maintain perfectly vertical posture.
Safety Cue: The alternating load creates a constant, dynamic challenge to the core's anti-lateral and anti-rotation capacity.

Goals: Increase overall strength, Rehabilitation & Injury prevention
Contraindications: Acute spinal disc injury, unhealed hernia
Steps to Perform: 1. Lie on back, knees bent, feet pulled close to glutes. 2. Gently curl the pelvis up, lifting the tailbone slightly off the floor. 3. The feet tuck closer to the glutes on the ascent. Slowly lower back down.
Safety Cue: Tucking the feet close reduces the lever arm of the legs, making the movement highly focused on the lower abs.

Goals: Improve Flexibility & Mobility, Rehabilitation & Injury prevention
Contraindications: Acute hamstring strain, severe sciatica
Steps to Perform: 1. Sit near the edge of a chair. Extend one heel forward. 2. Keeping the back straight, slowly hinge forward, reaching hands toward the foot/shin. 3. Immediately sit back up and repeat smoothly on the same side.
Safety Cue: Focus on hinging from the hips (chest toward thigh) rather than rounding the low back.

Goals: Increase overall strength, Improve Posture and Balance
Contraindications: Acute neck pain, shoulder impingement
Steps to Perform: 1. Lie chest down on a steep incline bench (head resting on top). Hold dumbbells. 2. Let arms hang. Shrug your shoulders straight up toward your ears. 3. Hold the squeeze briefly, then slowly lower.
Safety Cue: The incline bench eliminates low back strain and fully isolates the trapezius muscles.

Exercise Name: Single-Leg Stork Stance (Closed Eyes, Arm Circles)
Goals: Improve Posture and Balance, Rehabilitation & Injury prevention
Contraindications: Severe dizziness, acute ankle sprain
Steps to Perform: 1. Stand on one leg. Lift the opposite foot. Close your eyes. 2. Slowly perform arm circles while maintaining balance.
Safety Cue: Use extreme caution and have a spotter or wall nearby. Closing the eyes removes visual feedback, making this highly advanced.

Goals: Rehabilitation & Injury prevention, Improve Flexibility & Mobility
Contraindications: Acute hip joint pain, knee instability
Steps to Perform: 1. Anchor a band low and loop it around the outside of your knee. 2. Stand on the same leg. Slowly pull the knee inward against the band tension (internal rotation). 3. Slowly release and repeat.
Safety Cue: The band pulls the knee outward, forcing the hip internal rotators to work harder than in the bodyweight version.

Goals: Rehabilitation & Injury prevention, Increase overall strength
Contraindications: Acute knee pain, severe sciatica
Steps to Perform: 1. Sit upright near the edge of a chair. Extend one leg straight out in front of you, heel on the floor. 2. Lift the heel a few inches off the floor, contracting the quad. 3. Tap the heel gently back down. Repeat continuously on one leg.
Safety Cue: Keep your back straight and avoid leaning back. Focus on the squeeze in the front of the thigh.

Goals: Increase overall strength, Power and Speed
Contraindications: Acute low back pain, shoulder instability
Steps to Perform: 1. Stand over a dumbbell. Hinge down and grip it. 2. Explode up (hip drive), quickly flipping the dumbbell to the shoulder (the clean). 3. Immediately press the dumbbell overhead (the press). Lower with control.
Safety Cue: The clean and the press are two distinct, powerful movements. Maintain a tight core brace throughout.

Goals: Increase overall strength, Stability
Contraindications: Acute wrist pain, shoulder impingement
Steps to Perform: 1. Place feet on a box/bench. Hands on the floor. Push hips high, forming a rigid inverted 'V' position. 2. Hold the position perfectly still.
Safety Cue: Ensure the legs and back are straight. Focus on maintaining the high hip angle and pushing the head through the shoulders.

Goals: Improve Posture and Balance, Rehabilitation & Injury prevention
Contraindications: Acute low back pain, shoulder impingement
Steps to Perform: 1. Stand on the middle of the band. Hinge at the hips with a flat back (bent-over position). 2. With arms mostly straight, raise them out to the sides (reverse fly motion) against band tension. 3. Slowly lower the hands back down.
Safety Cue: Keep the back flat and the hinge constant. Focus the movement on the rear of the shoulders.

Goals: Improve Flexibility & Mobility, Reduce Stress
Contraindications: Acute knee pain, severe hip stiffness
Health Benefit: Lateral Spinal Stretch & Inner Thigh Opening
Steps to Perform: 1. Kneel. Extend one leg straight out to the side, foot flat. 2. Lean the torso to the side of the extended leg, letting the hand rest on the leg. 3. Extend the opposite arm over the head, reaching for the foot.
Safety Cue: Maintain the knee/foot alignment of the extended leg. Avoid crunching the torso forward.

Contraindications: Acute shoulder impingement, neck tension
Steps to Perform: 1. Sit on a bench (no back support), holding dumbbells at your sides. 2. Raise arms out to the sides until they reach shoulder height (no higher). 3. Slowly lower the weights back down, controlling the descent.
Safety Cue: Sit tall and avoid using momentum or leaning back. Focus the lift purely on the side of the shoulder.

Contraindications: Acute wrist pain (use fists), severe low back pain
Steps to Perform: 1. Start in a reverse plank position (hips lifted, body straight). 2. While maintaining the plank, slowly lift one heel off the floor (calf raise). 3. Lower the heel and switch.
Safety Cue: Keep your hips lifted high and level throughout the alternating heel raise movement.

Goals: Increase overall strength
Contraindications: Acute shoulder pain, severe low back pain
Steps to Perform: 1. Lie on your side, holding a light dumbbell. Extend the arm holding the dumbbell straight up. 2. Slowly lift the dumbbell and the torso/upper body off the floor (side crunch motion). 3. Slowly lower back down. This is a weighted side-lying crunch.
Safety Cue: Keep the body straight and the movement slow. Focus the contraction on the side of the torso.

Contraindications: Severe dizziness, acute ankle sprain
Steps to Perform: 1. Stand on one leg. Lift the opposite foot slightly. 2. Slowly nod your head "yes" (up and down) 10 times, then nod "no" (side to side) 10 times, while maintaining balance.
Safety Cue: Keep the standing knee soft and the core braced. Go slowly to avoid dizziness.

Safety Cue: Use the support fully. The movement should be controlled, pain-free, and focus on lubrication of the hip joint.

Contraindications: Acute wrist pain, shoulder instability
Steps to Perform: 1. Start in a high reverse plank position (hands and heels on floor, hips lifted). 2. While maintaining the plank, slowly tuck one knee toward your chest. 3. Extend the leg back to the plank position and alternate sides.
Safety Cue: Keep your hips lifted high and level; avoid letting the hips drop or tilt during the tuck.
