Exercise Name: Lying Tricep Extension (Dumbbell, Single Arm, Neutral Grip)
Goals: Increase overall strength
Contraindications: Acute elbow pain, wrist pain
Steps to Perform: 1. Lie on a bench. Hold one dumbbell straight up over your chest with a neutral grip (palm facing in). 2. Keeping the upper arm vertical, bend the elbow to lower the dumbbell toward the ear. 3. Extend the arm, squeezing the tricep.
Safety Cue: The neutral grip often reduces stress on the elbow joint compared to the standard pronated grip.

Goals: Rehabilitation & Injury prevention, Stability
Contraindications: Acute wrist pain, low back pain
Steps to Perform: 1. Start on hands and knees. Simultaneously lift opposite arm/leg. 2. Focus intently on squeezing the glute of the extended leg at the top, ensuring the foot lifts no higher than the hip. 3. Control the return.
Safety Cue: Avoid arching the low back. The lift should stop at hip level, driven by the glute, not the back.

Goals: Increase overall strength, Power and Speed
Contraindications: Acute knee/ankle pain, severe osteoporosis
Steps to Perform: 1. Stand on one leg. Perform a large, forceful jump sideways onto the opposite foot. 2. Land softly, absorb the force, and immediately jump back to the starting side.
Safety Cue: Focus on maximizing distance and vertical height. Requires excellent joint health and control.

Goals: Rehabilitation & Injury prevention, Increase overall strength
Contraindications: Acute knee pain, post-op recovery
Steps to Perform: 1. Sit on floor/bed, leg straight. Place a small rolled towel under the knee. 2. Press the back of the knee down into the towel, simultaneously tightening the thigh muscle as hard as possible. 3. Hold the maximal tension for 5 seconds. Relax and repeat.
Safety Cue: This is an isometric exercise. Focus solely on the intensity of the muscle contraction, not on lifting the leg.

Goals: Increase overall strength, Rehabilitation & Injury prevention
Contraindications: Acute shoulder instability, wrist pain
Health Benefit: Chest Strength with Neutral Shoulder Position
Steps to Perform: 1. Lie on the floor. Hold dumbbells with palms facing each other (neutral grip). 2. Press the dumbbells straight up. 3. Slowly lower until upper arms lightly touch the floor.
Safety Cue: The neutral grip often places the shoulder in a more stable, comfortable position than the standard grip.

Goals: Rehabilitation & Injury prevention, Improve Flexibility & Mobility
Contraindications: Acute ankle sprain, severe stiffness
Reps: Write 1 set of the alphabet / foot
Steps to Perform: 1. Sit tall in a chair. Lift one foot slightly off the floor. 2. Use the ankle/foot to slowly "write" the letters of the alphabet in the air. 3. Focus on large, distinct letters.
Safety Cue: Keep the knee and shin still. The movement should be concentrated only at the ankle joint for mobility.

Exercise Name: Lying Tricep Extension (Single Dumbbell, Two Hands)
Goals: Increase overall strength
Contraindications: Acute elbow pain, shoulder pain
Steps to Perform: 1. Lie on a bench. Hold one dumbbell with both hands (palms under the weight) extended over your chest. 2. Slowly lower the dumbbell behind your head by bending both elbows. 3. Extend the arms forcefully back overhead.
Safety Cue: Using two hands on one dumbbell is great for heavier loads with a single weight, increasing tricep focus.

Goals: Rehabilitation & Injury prevention, Increase overall strength
Contraindications: Acute knee pain, severe ankle stiffness
Steps to Perform: 1. Place a mini-band around your knees. Get into a slight quarter-squat stance. 2. Step sideways (laterally), pushing the leading knee out to maintain band tension. 3. Complete all reps in one direction, then reverse.
Safety Cue: The band placement at the knees increases the leverage and demand on the glutes compared to the ankles.

Goals: Improve Posture and Balance, Rehabilitation & Injury prevention
Contraindications: Severe dizziness, acute ankle sprain
Steps to Perform: 1. Stand on one leg. Lift the opposite foot slightly. 2. Place both hands behind your head (like a crunch starting position). 3. Hold the balance rigidly.
Safety Cue: Shifting the hands overhead significantly raises the center of gravity, increasing the difficulty of the balance.

Goals: Increase overall strength, Improve Posture and Balance
Contraindications: Acute shoulder pain, elbow pain
Steps to Perform: 1. Sit at the cable row. Grip the wide straight bar. 2. Pull the bar toward the upper abdomen/chest, flaring the elbows out wide. 3. Focus on squeezing the middle of the upper back. Slowly extend arms.
Safety Cue: The wide grip emphasizes the outer lats and middle trapezius muscles. Control the forward stretch.

Goals: Rehabilitation & Injury prevention, Stability
Contraindications: Acute spinal disc injury, unhealed abdominal separation
Steps to Perform: 1. Lie on back, knees bent 90. Arms straight up. Towel under low back. 2. Keep arms straight up. Slowly extend only one leg toward the floor. 3. Focus on crushing the towel with the low back. Return the leg and alternate.
Safety Cue: The arms stay static and the tension is maintained by resisting the lever of the moving leg.

Goals: Increase overall strength, Balance
Contraindications: Acute low back pain, severe hamstring tightness
Steps to Perform: 1. Stand on one leg, holding a dumbbell in the hand on the same side as the standing leg. 2. Hinge at the hip, keeping the back flat. 3. Drive through the heel to stand up.
Safety Cue: Loading the same side significantly increases the core's anti-rotation challenge and standing glute demand.

Goals: Increase overall strength, Improve Posture and Balance
Contraindications: Acute shoulder pain, elbow pain
Steps to Perform: 1. Stand facing the anchor (mid-chest height). Grip the opposite cable handle. 2. Pull the handle across and back, aiming to pull the arm straight out to the side (reverse fly motion). 3. Slowly resist the cable back to the start.
Safety Cue: Keep the arm mostly straight and focus the squeeze on the rear of the shoulder blade.

Goals: Increase overall strength
Contraindications: Acute Achilles pain, severe foot pain
Steps to Perform: 1. Sit on a bench, balls of feet elevated on a plate. Place a heavy dumbbell across your lower thighs near the knee. 2. Lower the heels deep. Slowly push up onto the balls of your feet. 3. Squeeze the calves at the top.
Safety Cue: Keep the back straight. The seated position isolates the Soleus muscle, which is key for endurance.

Goals: Increase overall strength, Power and Speed
Contraindications: Acute knee/ankle pain, severe osteoporosis
Steps to Perform: 1. Stand beside a low box/step. Jump laterally (sideways) up onto the box, landing softly on both feet. 2. Step or jump back down to the start and immediately jump up to the opposite side.
Safety Cue: Focus on a stable, centered landing on the box. Control the lateral push-off.

Goals: Increase overall strength, Improve cardiovascular fitness
Contraindications: Acute knee pain, severe weakness
Steps to Perform: 1. Stand tall. Step one foot straight back and lower into a lunge. 2. Drive through the front heel to return to standing. 3. Maintain a quick, continuous pace with strict form.
Safety Cue: Focus on keeping the torso vertical and the front knee tracking over the foot.

Goals: Rehabilitation & Injury prevention, Improve Flexibility & Mobility
Contraindications: Acute shoulder instability, severe impingement
Steps to Perform: 1. Stand holding a mini-band anchored at elbow height. Elbow bent 90 degrees, upper arm pinned to side. 2. Slowly pull the forearm across your stomach against the band tension (internal rotation). 3. Slowly return to the starting position.
Safety Cue: Keep the upper arm stationary. The movement is small and focused only on the internal rotation of the shoulder.

Exercise Name: Lying Straight Leg Raise (Assisted, Eccentric Focus)
Goals: Rehabilitation & Injury prevention, Increase overall strength
Contraindications: Acute spinal disc injury, unhealed hernia
Steps to Perform: 1. Lie on back. Use a strap to assist in raising one leg straight up. 2. Once at the top, remove strap and slowly lower the leg to the floor, taking 5 seconds. 3. Do not let the low back arch.
Safety Cue: The focus is on the slow, controlled lowering without spinal movement, maximizing lower ab control.

Goals: Increase overall strength, Stability
Contraindications: Acute shoulder instability, low back pain
Steps to Perform: 1. Sit with back support. Hold dumbbells racked at shoulder height. 2. Press one dumbbell overhead. As it descends, press the opposite dumbbell up. 3. Maintain a continuous, controlled alternation.
Safety Cue: The alternating load increases the core's demand for trunk stability throughout the set.

Goals: Improve Posture and Balance, Rehabilitation & Injury prevention
Contraindications: Severe dizziness, acute ankle sprain
Health Benefit: Dynamic Balance & Center of Mass Shift
Steps to Perform: 1. Stand on one leg. Lift the opposite foot slightly. 2. Extend the opposite arm straight up and slowly perform a small circle or reach as far as possible in a continuous motion.
Safety Cue: The arm reach shifts the center of gravity, challenging the standing ankle and core.

Goals: Increase overall strength, Rehabilitation & Injury prevention
Contraindications: Acute wrist pain, carpal tunnel flare-up
Steps to Perform: 1. Sit and rest forearm on thigh/bench, palm up, wrist hanging off. Loop mini-band around hand/fingers and under foot. 2. Slowly curl the wrist up against band tension. 3. Slowly lower.
Safety Cue: The band provides accommodating resistance, maximizing tension at the top of the wrist curl.

Goals: Increase overall strength, Stability
Contraindications: Acute shoulder pain, spinal disc injury
Steps to Perform: 1. Kneel facing the anchor. Hold handles at chest height. 2. Lean forward, letting arms extend overhead (like a kneeling plank). 3. Slowly pull handles back to the chest, resisting the urge to arch the low back.
Safety Cue: Maintain a perfect plank (straight line from shoulder to knee) throughout the entire movement.

Goals: Increase overall strength, Improve Posture and Balance
Contraindications: Acute shoulder pain, elbow pain
Steps to Perform: 1. Lie chest down on an incline bench. Hold one dumbbell. 2. Pull the weight up toward the side/chest, keeping the elbow close. 3. Slowly lower. Focus on the squeeze in the mid-back.
Safety Cue: Supporting the chest eliminates low back and core fatigue, allowing maximal focus on the back muscles.

Goals: Improve Flexibility & Mobility, Rehabilitation & Injury prevention
Contraindications: Acute knee pain, severe sciatica
Health Benefit: Active Hip Flexor Range of Motion
Steps to Perform: 1. Sit upright. Bend one knee. 2. Hook your hands or a strap around the front of the ankle/foot of the opposite leg. 3. Gently pull the knee/thigh up toward the chest as high as possible without rounding the low back. Slowly release.
Safety Cue: Use the hands for gentle assistance to guide the thigh into high flexion.

Goals: Increase overall strength, Power and Speed
Contraindications: Acute spinal disc injury, shoulder pain
Steps to Perform: 1. Stand beside a high cable pulley. Grip the handle. 2. Pull the handle diagonally down and across the body toward the opposite hip, pivoting on the back foot. 3. Control the handle back up slowly.
Safety Cue: Allow the back foot to pivot (heel lifts) to enable safe rotation through the hips and torso.

Goals: Improve Flexibility & Mobility, Rehabilitation & Injury prevention
Contraindications: Acute hamstring strain, severe sciatica
Health Benefit: Deep Trigger Point Release & Soft Tissue Health
Steps to Perform: 1. Sit on the floor. Place a tennis ball/lacrosse ball under one hamstring. Use hands for support. 2. Roll slowly back and forth over the ball, searching for tender spots. 3. Pause on very tender spots for 10-15 seconds.
Safety Cue: Use caution. The ball applies intense pressure; control the pressure by leaning on your hands.

Goals: Increase overall strength
Contraindications: Acute wrist pain, severe tennis elbow
Steps to Perform: 1. Stand tall. Hold dumbbells at sides, palms facing in (hammer grip). 2. Curl one dumbbell up and across your body toward the opposite shoulder. 3. Slowly lower.
Safety Cue: Combining the cross-body path with the hammer grip maximizes the contraction of the outer bicep and forearm muscles.

Goals: Increase overall strength, Flexibility & Mobility
Contraindications: Acute spinal disc injury, severe low back pain
Steps to Perform: 1. Lie on your back, legs straight up (perpendicular to floor). Arms spread wide. 2. Slowly lower both straight legs to one side, only as far as you can without the opposite shoulder lifting. 3. Pull the legs back to the center using the core. Alternate sides.
Safety Cue: The straight legs create a maximal lever, demanding high rotational strength and core control.

Goals: Increase overall strength, Improve Posture and Balance
Contraindications: Acute knee pain (use cushion), shoulder pain
Steps to Perform: 1. Kneel in a half-kneeling position facing the anchor. Grip the handle with a neutral grip. 2. Pull the handle toward your side/ribcage, squeezing the back muscle. 3. Slowly return the handle, resisting the forward pull.
Safety Cue: The half-kneeling position increases core stability and ensures a vertical pull angle.

Goals: Rehabilitation & Injury prevention, Balance
Contraindications: Severe dizziness, acute ankle sprain
Steps to Perform: 1. Stand on one leg (use support). Lift the opposite foot slightly. 2. While balancing, slowly raise the heel of the standing foot (calf raise). 3. Slowly lower the heel back down, maintaining balance.
Safety Cue: Use the support to challenge the single-leg stance without risk of a fall.

Goals: Rehabilitation & Injury prevention, Improve Posture and Balance
Contraindications: Acute wrist pain, low back pain
Steps to Perform: 1. Start on hands and knees. Simultaneously lift and extend the opposite arm and leg. 2. Hold the fully extended position rigidly for 5-10 seconds. 3. Slowly return to the floor.
Safety Cue: Focus on remaining perfectly still during the hold; any wobbling indicates instability.

Goals: Increase overall strength
Contraindications: Acute shoulder pain, wrist pain
Steps to Perform: 1. Lie on a bench. Grip the bar much wider than shoulder-width. 2. Lower the bar slowly to the chest. 3. Press the bar straight up. Requires good shoulder mobility.
Safety Cue: The wide grip places increased stress on the chest (pecs) but can be stressful on the shoulder joint; use with caution.

Goals: Increase overall strength, Power and Speed
Contraindications: Acute spinal disc injury, shoulder pain
Steps to Perform: 1. Stand beside a low cable pulley. Grip the handle. 2. Pull the handle diagonally up and across the body toward the opposite shoulder, pivoting on the back foot. 3. Control the handle back down slowly.
Safety Cue: Allow the back foot to pivot (heel lifts) to enable safe rotation through the hips and torso.

Goals: Increase overall strength, Improve Posture and Balance
Contraindications: Acute shoulder instability, severe neck pain
Steps to Perform: 1. Stand tall, holding one dumbbell overhead and the other at your side. 2. Walk slowly. After 5 steps, seamlessly switch the dumbbells (the one at the side goes overhead, and vice versa). 3. Maintain perfectly vertical posture.
Safety Cue: The alternating load creates a constant, dynamic challenge to the core's anti-lateral and anti-rotation capacity.

Goals: Increase overall strength, Rehabilitation & Injury prevention
Contraindications: Acute spinal disc injury, unhealed hernia
Steps to Perform: 1. Lie on back, knees bent, feet pulled close to glutes. 2. Gently curl the pelvis up, lifting the tailbone slightly off the floor. 3. The feet tuck closer to the glutes on the ascent. Slowly lower back down.
Safety Cue: Tucking the feet close reduces the lever arm of the legs, making the movement highly focused on the lower abs.

Goals: Improve Flexibility & Mobility, Rehabilitation & Injury prevention
Contraindications: Acute hamstring strain, severe sciatica
Steps to Perform: 1. Sit near the edge of a chair. Extend one heel forward. 2. Keeping the back straight, slowly hinge forward, reaching hands toward the foot/shin. 3. Immediately sit back up and repeat smoothly on the same side.
Safety Cue: Focus on hinging from the hips (chest toward thigh) rather than rounding the low back.

Goals: Increase overall strength, Improve Posture and Balance
Contraindications: Acute neck pain, shoulder impingement
Steps to Perform: 1. Lie chest down on a steep incline bench (head resting on top). Hold dumbbells. 2. Let arms hang. Shrug your shoulders straight up toward your ears. 3. Hold the squeeze briefly, then slowly lower.
Safety Cue: The incline bench eliminates low back strain and fully isolates the trapezius muscles.

Exercise Name: Single-Leg Stork Stance (Closed Eyes, Arm Circles)
Goals: Improve Posture and Balance, Rehabilitation & Injury prevention
Contraindications: Severe dizziness, acute ankle sprain
Steps to Perform: 1. Stand on one leg. Lift the opposite foot. Close your eyes. 2. Slowly perform arm circles while maintaining balance.
Safety Cue: Use extreme caution and have a spotter or wall nearby. Closing the eyes removes visual feedback, making this highly advanced.

Goals: Rehabilitation & Injury prevention, Improve Flexibility & Mobility
Contraindications: Acute hip joint pain, knee instability
Steps to Perform: 1. Anchor a band low and loop it around the outside of your knee. 2. Stand on the same leg. Slowly pull the knee inward against the band tension (internal rotation). 3. Slowly release and repeat.
Safety Cue: The band pulls the knee outward, forcing the hip internal rotators to work harder than in the bodyweight version.
